PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 21 March, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That the order of the Senate of 29 November 1994, relating to the consideration of legislation, be amended as follows:
Omit paragraph (1), substitute the following paragraph:
`(1)For the reasons set out in this resolution, where a bill:
(a)is first introduced in the Senate by a minister in a period of sittings; or
(b)is received from the House of Representatives and was introduced in the House of Representatives in the same period of sittings,

and a motion is moved for the second reading of the bill, debate on that motion shall be adjourned at the conclusion of the speech of the Senator moving the motion and resumption of the debate shall be made an order of the day for the first day of sitting in the next period of sittings without any question being put.'.

PROCTEXT.PARA: upon which Senator Chamarette had moved by way of an amendment:
After paragraph (b), insert the following word and paragraph:
"; or (c)is received from the House of Representatives after the expiration of two-thirds of the total number of days of sitting of the Senate scheduled for that period of sittings"

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe we adjourned the debate on this matter just after I had moved an amendment to the motion Senator Faulkner had proposed. I will try not to belabour this and go over history. For years there have been problems about the way in which legislation comes to this place from the House of Representatives—it all tends to come at once, without sufficient time for scrutiny.

PARA.TAB: The motion moved by Senator Faulkner allowed the problem of scrutiny to be dealt with. It indicated that, if a bill had been introduced in the House of Representatives in the last session, we would be free to debate it here at the next session; if not, it would be adjourned automatically to the first day of the next sitting. I believe that allows for community consultation and some kind of preparation time for senators in relation to the legislation. The reason it allows for that is that the House of Representatives does not amend much or give much scrutiny to legislation and it just passes through on an automatic basis.

If in debates significant amendments were made, I would not be able to agree with this motion. We should request that the consideration of a bill be completed in the House of Representatives in the session prior to its being introduced in the Senate. That would allow us to give scrutiny to the completed bill. Because there is no appreciable difference between the introduced bill and the completed bill as it currently comes from the House of Representatives, the stipulation that it be introduced in the other place should be sufficient to warrant community consultation and scrutiny time.

However, the motion does not deal with the problem of log jams which occur because the House of Representatives has fallen into the very undesirable practice of pushing through large numbers of bills in the very last days of its sittings. This means that an even greater number of bills that have not been adequately considered could be introduced.

The Senate is in danger of being inundated with significant bills that require considerable debate and amendment. We will ourselves suffer from a log jam at the end of our sittings. I might add that we seem to be doing it in any case. The procedural motion which I proposed over a year ago would have addressed that. However, that motion has not been accepted and we now have this slightly different measure that has been introduced by the government.

My amendment seeks to deal with that log jam problem by saying that the Senate does not have to be inundated with bills just because the House or Representatives has a log jam of legislation in its last week or day of sittings. My amendment seeks to insert after paragraph (b) of Senator Faulkner's motion the following word and paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: "; or (c) is received from the House or Representatives after the expiration of two-thirds of the total number of days of sitting of the Senate scheduled for that period of sittings"
Senator Faulkner's motion then continues:

and a motion is moved for the second reading of the bill, debate on that motion shall be adjourned at the conclusion of the speech of the Senator moving the motion and resumption of the debate shall be made an order of the day for the first day of sitting in the next period of sittings without any question being put.

The wording of the amendment may seem a bit clumsy. However, the amendment seeks to ensure that debate on bills that are not received from the House of Representatives by two-thirds of the way through the estimated time of our sittings will automatically be adjourned to the first day of the next sittings. Any exemption to that will have to be sought by the agreement of the chamber. That is all I intend to say about this amendment.

PARA.TAB: I was very tempted to withdraw the amendment because it was rather clumsy and to seek the opposition's support in opposing the motion. I believe that the principle we have in place of a bill introduced and passed in the House of Representatives in one session being considered in the Senate the next session is far more preferable than what we have now before us. However, because I understand that the opposition is not prepared to vote against the new motion and support that principle, I ask opposition senators and any other senators to support my amendment. I believe that the amendment addresses a twofold problem—allowing the opportunity for community scrutiny and trying to redress and limit the operation of the log jam effect in the Senate. Having moved my amendment, I seek the support of my colleagues.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —We interpreted the principal motion as meaning that the Senate would be given adequate notice of the government's intention to bring legislation to the Senate. We accepted that the changes the government was seeking to make were not unreasonable. They would have meant that a bill would have had to have been introduced into either the House of Representatives or the Senate in the sittings previous to that in which it is debated in the Senate. We accepted that as giving the Senate reasonable notice of the government's intention, and thus allowing senators to prepare themselves for the subsequent debate.

PARA.TAB: I said at that time, however, that I recognised that the motion that we were debating did not overcome the habit of this government of stacking legislation at the end of a sittings and thus inhibiting proper debate. I said that was a major problem that we had been seeking to address over a long period of time. It could be simply resolved by the government better ordering its own program and ensuring the more effectual functioning of the parliament. But the government has not acted in that way.

Therefore, over the years we have attempted to put in place a number of different mechanisms to try to discipline the government to bring before the parliament an orderly program. Those attempts have failed. This is yet another attempt—in this instance by Senator Chamarette. It is a fairly modest attempt but, nevertheless, an attempt. As I interpret her amendment, the government has got to bring matters to the Senate no later than two-thirds of the way through a sittings. That will not entirely solve the problem because, without goodwill, the government can still stack—it can bring in bills before the two-thirds cut-off date and then not proceed to finalisation until the last sitting week.

I can see from the look on your face, Madam Acting Deputy President West, that you do not believe the government would act in bad faith. I do not share your confidence in this government. Its record in relation to the management of the Senate's legislation program has been deplorable. That is something that could be so easily overcome with just a little bit of competent management.

Senator Faulkner reminds me that he has been so distracted, trying to get himself out of the awful mess he is in with administration of the environment portfolio in this session, that there has been no management of the government's program at all. That is part of the problem.

Nevertheless, I concede that Senator Chamarette's attempt is a useful one. I urge the government to respond to it positively rather than in its usual negative way. If we implement this amendment—if the government accepts it as a positive contribution and acts accordingly—the Senate would be better able to function and that would be in the interests of the Australian parliamentary process. Therefore, the coalition will support the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have long been concerned to get orderly business in the Senate. I was working as a staffer in 1978 when Malcolm Fraser's government had control of both houses of the parliament. I well remember that we used to get bills about an hour before we had to debate them. Senator Hill may not remember that but I remember it well.

PARA.TAB: I remember extremely well having to go around to a minister's office, holding out my hand and saying, `Excuse me, can I have a copy of the bill?' It was very difficult. When a bill was introduced in the Senate we had a lot of trouble getting hold of it, in some cases before it was passed. It probably was not quite that bad, but it was pretty bad. From that moment on, the Democrats, who had a great deal of trouble getting hold of legislation then—Senator Harradine, who has been here a lot longer than I have, would remember the situation—have been concerned with making sure that we have the bills a long time in advance.

I agree that Senator Faulkner's motion, with Senator Chamarette's proposed amendment, will solve the problem of scrutiny because bills will come up a long time before debate. I must admit that I came into this chamber thinking that was all we needed but I have not checked the figures on log jams coming from the House of Representatives. The Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) does not like being regularly gratuitously and offensively abused by anyone from the opposition—none of us do—and tries to avoid it. However, although he understands the way this works, he is not assisted particularly well by his colleagues in the House of Representatives.

As I said, I do not have the figures but I suspect there may be a bit of a log jam at the end and it might be sensible to move it. Still, I would like to see how this works over time, because if it is not essential we may not need to keep it. Certainly, the first part of the motion, as moved by Senator Faulkner, is very useful, fixing a problem that we have had for quite a while. For that reason, the Democrats will be supporting the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by Senator Chamarette, but I do so reluctantly in that it is a fall-back position. I think it has been very generous of Senator Chamarette to even contemplate moving that particular amendment. We have to remember the genesis of the cut-off motion, which was the clear undertaking by the government, through the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, that so far as is possible the government would abide by the principle of introducing legislation one session and debating it the next. That was the genesis of the motion that was eventually moved by Senator Chamarette and adopted by the Senate in November last year.

PARA.TAB: We thought this would be part of the accountability package that was being discussed at the time of the sports rorts affair. Be that as it may, I understand that there are difficulties. In his calm and reasonable way, Senator Faulkner has indicated them to the chamber. We have had to give them consideration. However, as Senator Hill has mentioned, there are two problems. One problem is that of adequate time for members of parliament and the public to consider the ramifications of bills that are introduced into the parliament. The second problem is that of log jams.

This compromised solution in the form of the amendment moved by Senator Chamarette addresses the latter problem. She is proposing her amendment to go some of the way towards addressing the former problem; that is, the problem of giving adequate time to senators and to the public to consider the ramifications of legislation. Under those circumstances, I am reluctantly prepared to go along with the amendment. I hope that the government can see that this amendment is put forward in good faith and in an attempt to address both of those problems, which we all agree should be addressed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be supporting Senator Chamarette's amendment, which she has claimed is aimed at avoiding the log jam in the Senate in the last week of sittings. These so-called log jams—I would not argue with that name; it is as good a name as you could give—generally arise because of the low rate of legislative activity in the first weeks of the sittings and because such a large number of bills are referred to committees. That causes delays in reporting dates, and the program consequently becomes back loaded.

PARA.TAB: The solution is not Senator Chamarette's amendment, even though it is possible that she has moved it in good faith. That is not the solution. The solution is to ensure that senators spend time examining legislation over the break between sittings and that, where referrals are necessary, they are done before the end of the sittings. That is the real solution. Otherwise, at the end of the day, no useful purpose is served by introducing legislation in the sittings before it is due to be debated.

So the government will not support this amendment. I have indicated in my speech in moving this motion our strong commitment to the introduction of legislation in one session for debate in the next session. That is an objective and a principle that the government has honoured and, I can assure you, intends to continue to honour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look at the next motion on the Notice Paper.

—The next motion on the Notice Paper, Senator, deals with this very point of the unintended consequences of the motion that Senator Chamarette was originally responsible for, which I believe was very badly worded. Whilst the government opposes Senator Chamarette's amendment, it is not its intention to call for a division. I suspect that, given the nature of the contributions we have heard here, Senator Chamarette is going to be successful with this amendment. As a result, I indicate that the government's strong and principled position remains unchanged.

—by leave—I have to reply to one comment that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) made. It is galling to have to seek leave to do this. I agree entirely with him that the real solution lies in a different direction. We should deal with the business of the Senate in an orderly manner week by week. He did admit that we do have a log jam; and he did admit that that log jam comes at the end of the sittings. All this motion does is to put off that log jam, or to give us seven extra sitting days in which to give consideration to the log jam. It does not actually deal with the log jam—it will still come. It will simply come seven days before the end of the sittings instead of at the end of the sittings.

PARA.TAB: I insist that, clumsy though the wording may be, it is an effort to do our job more adequately in the last week of sittings than would be the case if this were not in place. I explain that this means that any legislation that has not been received before 9 March should be properly put off to the next sittings. If that is not done, then we will have to vote to exempt bills. I think that is perfectly appropriate because that is some way of prioritising what we do in the time we have available.
Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate--Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek your guidance on this matter. I am happy to move the motion standing in the name of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins)

TALK.START.PARA: , but I refer to the motion that has just been agreed to by the Senate and seek your advice. The motion of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy will now apply only to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4), I think.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—That is correct. You can move the motion on the understanding that it affects only that bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to explain to senators that the amended motion, as agreed to, takes account of the other pieces of legislation. Does that clear up the point that you

SPEECH.PARA: were making, Senator Hill?

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, that is a correct interpretation.
—It has just been a ruling. That is what I was trying to say.

—by leave—Is it the intention of this motion that the minister indicate pursuant to the cut-off motion, the most recent motion that we have just passed, that the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) and the Social Security (Non-Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill need to be exempted from the cut-off?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to clarify the point I was making so that all senators are clear on this. The Social Security (Non-Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 no longer requires the order of the Senate of 29 November. There is a new order. As a result of the new order, that particular bill is no longer—
—It came in before 9 March.
—Yes, it is no longer caught.
—It was introduced here before two-thirds of the way through this session.

—Yes, Senator. That is what I was trying to clarify. I seek leave of the Senate to amend the motion to now read, as a result of the previous decision that the Senate has made, that the order of the Senate of 29 November 1994, as amended, relating to consideration of legislation not apply to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion now reads:

PARA.TAB: That the order of the Senate of 29 November 1994, relating to the consideration of legislation, be amended as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit paragraph (1), substitute the following paragraph:
`(1)For the reasons set out in this resolution, where a bill:
(a)is first introduced in the Senate by a minister in a period of sittings; or
(b)is received from the House of Representatives and was introduced in the House of Representatives in the same period of sittings,

and a motion is moved for the second reading of the bill, debate on that motion shall be adjourned at the conclusion of the speech of the Senator moving the motion and resumption of the debate shall be made an order of the day for the first day of sitting in the next period of sittings without any question being put.'.
And on the amendment moved by Senator Chamarette—After paragraph (b), insert the following word and paragraph:
"; or (c)is received from the House of Representatives after the expiration of two-thirds of the total number of days of sitting of the Senate scheduled for that period of sittings".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the order of the Senate of 29 November 1994, as amended, relating to the consideration of legislation, not apply to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill is one of the central planks of the announcement made by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) on 30 December last year of measures to prevent abuse of our asylum laws and procedures. At the time these announcements were made, the minister indicated that the government intended to enact these measures as soon as possible. This was the minister's intention to ensure that our refugee determination process continues to be able to operate and to deal expeditiously and fairly with genuine claims for asylum and that it is not prevented from doing so by the clogging of the system by unfounded claims.

PARA.TAB: The bill is part of a package of bills introduced in the first week of the current session. The first bill, the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), has already been passed by the parliament following the Senate's agreement to waive the arrangements which call for introduction in the session prior to that in which the bills are debated and passed.

This explanation was prepared by way of the amendment, so I suppose we could say that it may have been near enough to legitimate. The point is that the Senate has already given permission to waive its own rule for the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). What Minister Bolkus would like to see is that same exemption extended to this piece of legislation because it is essentially part of a package: not one bill stands by itself. This bill needs to be included with the others that have gone with it.

The Senate agreed on that occasion with the government's contention—that is, for the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2)—that the bill was of such importance and urgency that the motion we today seek to set aside should not prevent the urgent passage of that bill. Would the Senate, having considered that way once before, consider that way once again, particularly as it is part of the same package of legislation? The government does appreciate that on occasions the Senate recognises bills will need to be legislated urgently, and this is one such occasion.

The government takes its obligations under the refugee convention very seriously, as it does with all relevant international legal obligations. It is the government's desire to ensure that our determination process embodies our total commitment to these obligations. Equally, it is also true that the government's desire is to ensure that our process is not abused—that it is a fair, just and quick process, but not one that is open to abuse such as that which has been evidenced by the tendency for continuous, repeated applications that some so-called asylum seekers make in order to prolong their stay in Australia.

Our determination process must also fully and fairly apply our protection obligations under the refugee convention. Australia played a prominent role in the drafting of the refugee convention and that convention restricts its protection obligations to those falling within its definition of a refugee. That definition is not as wide as some people might like, and that is why some of those people have opposed this bill.

This bill seeks to preserve the integrity of the refugee convention definition of a refugee by ensuring that it is not interpreted in such a way as to deprive it of any meaning. The bill reaffirms our commitment to providing protection to anyone who has a well-founded fear of persecution on the basis of race, nationality, religion, political opinion or membership of a particular social group. This could include people who fear forceful sterilisation or abortion by a government because they fit into one of the above convention grounds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I am reluctant to intervene, but I remind the minister that this is a debate about urgency, not a second reading debate on the merits or otherwise of the bill. What we are listening to is the reasons why the normal time requirements for legislation should be waived by the Senate. Why is this matter so urgent that it must be dealt with now? What is the evidence of urgency? Therefore, I rise on that question of relevance, Mr Acting Deputy President, and respectfully suggest that you might request the minister to address that issue, which is the issue of the debate.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: I would not like any truncation of the debate which would not enable the government to make out a case of urgency. I agree with what Senator Hill said. I think what is being said by Senator Crowley is background, and I am, as Senator Hill is, obviously waiting for an indication by Senator Crowley as to why this particular bill should be exempted from the cut-off motion of November as amended by us today. I feel that it might be a little premature to rule that Senator Crowley is not in order at the moment.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—I accept the point and draw Senator Crowley's notice to the fact that the matter of urgency is being considered. I am sure she will come to that point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I will. I thank Senator Hill for his assistance in this matter. We have had this debate a number of times about just how much of the substance that is being debated should be allowed to be included in the debate for urgency. If Senator Hill had waited one second more, I would have said, `These matters are urgently required.' I also have to remind him that these notes have been prepared to assist me today because—
—Because?

—Yes, I am getting to that. These notes have been prepared to assist me today. I am sure this whole debate would have been much easier if the minister had been able to be here. But, unfortunately, he has another obligation and cannot be. So I ask for a little tolerance.

PARA.TAB: I think the point that Senator Harradine makes does balance this. It is a matter of urgency. But, to make it clear for anybody listening or any senator who is not completely across all this, this is a matter of urgency particularly in relation to the two points that I have just gone through to highlight the main substance of the bill. The reason those points are urgent is that the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) is being considered by the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. This bill is in substantially the same terms as that bill, but it incorporates some amendments which clarify, in light of some of the contributions made to the committee, the intended operation of the bill. So we do have the opportunity here to take account of the Senate's further input through that legal and constitutional committee.

The government has taken the course of introducing this bill in the House of Representatives to reaffirm its commitment to the urgent passage of the measures contained in it. The opposition has since indicated that it will support the bill with amendments, which we have not yet seen, and that it is committed to the principle underlying the bill. On behalf of the government I would have to say, especially to Senator Hill, that the government welcomes this and the opposition's recognition of the urgent need to pass this bill. I ask those opposite whether I am right in saying they are proposing amendments that we still have not seen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Possibly. We have foreshadowed amendments.

—I would have thought that, if the opposition is proposing some foreshadowed amendments possibly to this bill and in light of the fact that it has also given its support for this bill or indicated its inclination to support this bill, we should not spend too much time debating whether or not the bill is urgent. There is considerable agreement about the importance of this legislation.
—You haven't made a case for it.
—I have made a case, Senator. If you were too busy talking to Senator Short to hear it, I am not going to trawl over it again.
—It was a pretty small case, Rosemary.

—We are not necessarily going on the size; it is the quantity. The point is that it is part of a package of bills. Senator Bolkus indicated in December last year the intention to do these things. Some of the bills have been passed. It is one important addition to that—an urgent addition to those amendments—to make clear the points that I have just raised, particularly the clarification of the definition of `refugee' so as to ensure that people are not slipping through that sloppy definition, I suppose you could say.

PARA.TAB: What we are doing with this piece of legislation is what we do with all pieces of legislation: come to the most appropriate balance that we can find between protecting rights of world citizens and at the same time maintaining the integrity of a system that, on the one hand, protects and allows proper and correct refugees into the country and, on the other hand, tries to close down the options so that people do not abuse the refugee system to get into this country. The government believes, and I certainly strongly support the argument, that this definition is needed urgently to close that loophole and to make beyond doubt the government's intention in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many cases are before the courts? What's the evidence?

—I conclude my contribution by saying by way of response that Australia, as I was just making the point, is not assisted at all by continuing to have a system that can be subject to abuse. The Sackville decision needs to be addressed as soon as possible. Senator Hill and the opposition have called for steps to be taken to prevent abuse. They have indicated their support. They have even foreshadowed, possibly, amendments. I think the word `possibly' is a very telling one in the course of this debate. It is a matter of importance to the government to make quite clear its intentions in this matter and not to allow the possibility and the confusion in the community as well as the prospects of abuse under this system. So I think there is a very good case to be made for why this piece of legislation should be brought on.

—I want to make a couple of comments at this stage and to support the questions that my leader, Senator Hill, has put to Senator Crowley as to why precisely this is urgent, what cases are before the courts on the matter and how many people the department or the government really expect to be making use of any loophole that may exist at the moment in the definition of `refugee'. It is very questionable as to whether there is a loophole. No other country in the world is proposing legislation on this of the nature that the government is putting forward.

PARA.TAB: I want to make it clear, Senator Crowley, because I think you may have misrepresented the coalition's position a little, that we support the intent of the legislation. We have also made it clear, however, that we believe certain amendments are necessary. We have foreshadowed that. In public statements by me on behalf of the coalition I have expressed the type of amendment we believe has to be considered by this parliament. I have to say that that has met with a deafening silence from the government. Certainly no-one from the government has come to me as a result of my statements of a couple of weeks ago and said, `Let's get together and see what you are actually proposing.' I would have thought that, if you thought this was as urgent as you say it is, then the government would at least have had the wit to do that.

The coalition does not want to hold the legislation up. It is correct that we said at the end of last year that the government was very tardy in taking the actions that we believe are necessary to give a clear signal, particularly to potential boat people from southern China, that it was just not on to get on a boat and come to Australia. So our credentials are absolutely clear and clean on that. Indeed, it was the government that was belated in taking any action at all.

Having said that, we have said that we want to make sure the legislation is fair and just and does not put Australia in a situation where we are ignoring some quite fundamental and basic human rights concerns, including such issues, particularly in this instance, as forced or coerced sterilisation or abortions. That would be regarded by a tolerant society such as ours as a situation too intolerable to contemplate.

We want certain undertakings in the legislation, or in the form of amendments or statements by the minister in the course of debate, to allay the fears of not only ourselves but a very wide range of people throughout the Australian community. So do not come in here and say that we are trying to delay the matter. What we are saying is that the government, up to date, and the minister might have been caught in a difficult position—

TALK.START.PARA: —Caught short.

—She might have been caught short, as my colleague Senator Hill says, because it is not her portfolio and therefore it is perhaps hard for her to argue it. But I have to say that, up to date, she has not really gone too far in making a convincing argument that it is urgent. Having said that, we will not be holding up the legislation's consideration. But we do want—and this gives an opportunity to put the government again very clearly on notice, not that it should need to be put on notice—a sensible discussion with it on possible amendments to the legislation or very clear undertakings in the debate to address the concerns that we have had on our behalf and on the behalf of many other Australians about the intent of the legislation. It seems to me that those are the issues the minister has not addressed this morning.

—The Australian Democrats also do not wish to hold up the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4), but in its present form we find it unacceptable. In my dissenting report to the report by the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee, I have foreshadowed that the Democrats want amendments. We will move those amendments, but we would like the government to consider the issue and to indicate whether it is prepared to agree to the basic principle that we are putting forward; that is that, while we agree that the repressive fertility policies of the PRC should not, of themselves, mean that Australia should give blanket acceptance as a refugee to every former citizen of the PRC who turns up in Australia as an asylum seeker, we, nevertheless, want to ensure that whatever persecution citizens of the PRC experience as a result of those repressive policies is taken into account when the refugee status of individual asylum seekers is assessed.

PARA.TAB: The situation at law is far from clear. The Sackville judgment has been handed down and it is now on appeal. It has not yet been decided. It is incumbent upon this parliament to clarify the position. There are statements from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) on record which seem to indicate that he accepts that particular position as I have outlined it. If that is so, then the government should have no difficulty in accepting the thrust of the amendment that I have suggested. It would be helpful, Minister, if we could have the government's reaction. At this stage we have had no reaction from the government following the report of the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee which contains the amendments that I have suggested. In one sense, as certain statements from the minister are on the record, a reaction from the government should be only a clarifying or declaratory statement. It would certainly assist us all if the government were to make its position clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to the Senate that Senator Crowley said something which shows that this legislation should not be the subject of exemption from the cut-off date. She said that the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) is substantially the same as the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3)—and so it is. The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) is still before us. It does not need a cut-off date.
—It has been here for two months and has not been brought forward.

—As Senator Short has said, it has been here for two months and has not been brought forward. Today the government can, if it wishes to, bring forward the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). Why doesn't it? It does not have to get an exemption. But the government is playing dirty politics with this matter. The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), so roundly condemned by human rights groups throughout Australia, is not being proceeded with by the government because it was introduced into the Senate and could not be a trigger for a double dissolution.

PARA.TAB: The government was intending to leave that bill lie on the table without being debated. It introduced into the House of Representatives another bill which could become another trigger for a double dissolution in substantially the same form as the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). Let the minister deny that that is the case.

Why did the government not proceed here with Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) and amend it as it intended to do? I saw the amendments the government wanted to make on Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). They are the same as those that now have been incorporated into Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4). That is the simple reason, surely, why we should vote against this.

Let the government bring Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) back. Let us debate that and let the amendments be put to No. 3 as the government had proposed. The government does not want to do that, because it wants to play politics with this legislation. That is what it is all about. Let us make no error about that. The government might make all sorts of excuses about having to take into account this, that and the other thing, but the gist of it is that the government is playing politics.

Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4), like No. 3, is an attempt to overturn a Federal Court decision. That Federal Court decision was made in December by Justice Sackville, who ruled that a married man and woman who had a well-founded fear that they would be forcibly sterilised if returned to China were refugees. There was no argument that the persons did not face coerced sterilisation—no argument at all. Justice Sackville found that China's fertility control policies helped identify the couple as part of a particular social group. The couple had arrived in Australia in 1993. The woman was eight months pregnant and gave birth to a son. The independent Refugee Review Tribunal, which considered the issues on their merit, had ruled that the couple were genuine refugees.

That goes to the point that was made by Senator Crowley. She says that there is a problem, that non-genuine refugees are being dealt with. The government makes the judgment. Why not leave it to the independent Refugee Review Tribunal, which in this case found that the couple were genuine refugees and that their human rights would be grossly violated if they were forced back to China?

Under the Convention on the Status of Refugees, it is just not sufficient for people to establish a well-founded fear, both subjectively and objectively, that they would face persecution. It is not enough to prove that. A person must not only have a firmly established and well-founded fear of persecution if returned, but also establish that the persecution is because of the person's race, religion, nationality, political opinion or membership of a particular social group.

In the case I am referring to, the judge said that the persecution was not for any of the first four reasons but was because the couple were part of a social group—that is, parents with one child identified and targeted by China's fertility control policy. Do honourable senators follow?

This bill is making it impossible for some refugees to jump that second hurdle. They will already have had to establish a well-founded fear. They are facing virtually certain forced sterilisation or forced abortion but, unless they can jump that second hurdle—that is to say, unless the persecution is because of one of the convention-related reasons—they will not be regarded as refugees in accordance with the convention and they will be subjected to return.

This bill says that, in determining whether a person is a member of a particular social group, the persons determining that, including the courts, shall disregard the fertility control policies of the PRC. So their case falls to the ground unless, as the minister said, they can prove it under some other convention ground—that is to say, race, religion, political opinion or nationality.

The coercive population control policies, the fertility control policies, of the PRC are widespread. They are not directed at people because of their race or their religion. The judge found it was not directed at those other four categories, but that it was directed at people because they were identified and targeted by the fertility control policies of the PRC.

The minister has indicated that one part of the bill, repeat applications, was of concern. From memory, I think Senator Spindler dealt with that matter in his dissenting report. I have certain other suggestions to make as well in that regard. I am quite happy to discuss with the minister, the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens my interest in that matter. I think it can be logically gone through.

On the other matter the government has said some very strange things. In the House of Representatives Mrs Crosio on behalf of the minister said something which, on the face of it, gives some hope that the government is prepared to ensure that persons who have established a well-founded fear of coerced abortion, coerced sterilisation or other grave sanction will not be forced back to their persecutors. But, because this legislation is substantially the same and has the same intention as the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), we have to listen to the people who know the legal advice that has been given to us—not only the legal advice but also advice from persons we should listen to.

This legislation has been roundly condemned. The representative of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees has publicly branded this bill as `unusual, unfortunate and without precedent'. In an interview with AAP on 9 March he said further things which I suggest honourable senators should have a look at. If you read between the lines, you will see what the UNHCR is saying about this particular matter. I do not think you have to go to the letter that the representative wrote to the department to see that; you can see it in the public statements.

The bill has been roundly condemned by a former High Court judge and President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, Sir Ronald Wilson; Amnesty International; the Law Council of Australia; the Australian Law Reform Commission; the Catholic Bishops of Australia; the Bar Association of New South Wales; prominent feminists and researchers, Dr Renate Klein and Dr Lynette Dumble; the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia; and the Refugee Council of Australia. Are we listening to these people? What they are saying is encapsulated in what Sir Ronald Wilson said.

One reason I am concerned that the government is trying to push ahead with this is that coerced sterilisation or abortion is a flagrant disregard of a fundamental human right. Sir Ronald said, `In my submission, it is wrong for the government to ask the parliament and the people of this country to condone the exclusion of asylum seekers from refugee status based on a well-founded fear of that kind of persecution.' Sir Ronald is saying it is wrong—I also believe it is wrong—for the government to ask the parliament and the people to pass legislation which will deny asylum seekers refugee status based on a well-founded fear of coerced abortion, coerced sterilisation or other grave sanctions.

Should this bill be adopted and result in the forcing back of persons who have a well-founded fear of coerced abortion, coerced sterilisation or other grave sanctions into the hands of their tormentors, into the hands of their persecutors, I would feel ashamed to remain a member of this federal parliament of Australia with a government which would then be an accessory to that gross violation of human rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to add the Green's comments on this issue. We do not support the exemption being granted to Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) for two reasons. Firstly, despite any resemblance it might have to Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), which Senator Harradine pointed out was introduced into the Senate and still is available to us, my understanding is that, because it was introduced on 31 January this year, it does not comply with the rule `introduce one session, debate the next'.
—It applies to yours as amended.
—Does it?
—Yes, 9 March.

—Secondly, this kind of legislation and the content of it are an illustration of the valuable reason to delay until legislation is done in a fashion that gives all the community and all the implications the consideration they deserve.

PARA.TAB: The Sackville judgment has given us something more to think about. Consideration is still being given to this because of the appeal that has been made in respect of that judgment. Sections of the community are deeply outraged at the form of this legislation which it is proposed to push though in the hothouse of debate. Therefore, I believe that this matter warrants deferral to the next sittings.

It is for that reason that we are opposed to exempting this bill from the order of the Senate. I want to put that on the record. I agree totally with the comments that have previously been made by Senator Harradine and Senator Spindler. I will not add any more but just indicate where the Greens stand.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 22 March.

PROCTEXT.PARA: COMMONWEALTH AUTHORITIES AND COMPANIES BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: The bill.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Herron)—Order! We are considering the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1994 and amendment No. 1 moved by Senator Chamarette.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was mid-speech when progress on this matter was reported yesterday, commenting on two concerns—one held by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) and one by Senator Kernot—about the reasons for the amendment that the Greens have proposed. The proposed amendment would add a clause to the bill relating to public interest.

PARA.TAB: The minister felt that, instead of inserting that reference into this bill, we should insert it into each of the pieces of legislation that relate to it. That is a very fragmented way of doing things, especially when we are considering umbrella legislation and in view of the outline provided by the government to explain the purpose of the legislation.

That outline says that, broadly, the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill will provide a single set of core reporting and auditing requirements for directors of Commonwealth authorities and set out standards of conduct for executive officers. In other words, it is an attempt to deal in some coherent way with all those provisions. That is why it is perfectly appropriate to add a clause that goes to the public interest motivation that these authorities and companies should have. It is much better to put it in this legislation rather than in any separate legislation that might be enacted in relation to these particular authorities and companies.

Senator Kernot basically said that such companies would always act in the public interest. She felt that did not need to be stated; that if it were stated, it would in some way disadvantage those particular companies. I cannot agree with that. I believe that these particular organisations, because they originate from statutes passed by this parliament, have a very privileged position in relation to obligations under federal, state and local government laws and by-laws. They actually have an advantage over private companies. With that privilege should go the added responsibility of being seen to act and acting in the public interest. That should be required by the legislation to ensure that the public has some recourse should they feel these organisations are failing in that respect.

The third comment I wish to make is a more general one and it also relates to a comment by the minister. He felt that, because this primarily is to deal with financial management, accountability and audit of Commonwealth agencies, authorities and companies, the whole area of public interest and social responsibility is out of place. I disagree very strongly on that point. I believe financial integrity is not the only integrity that should be of concern to us. I believe this parliament holds a much wider brief than that.

As this outline adds, the bill is to provide a single set of requirements for ensuring that wholly owned Commonwealth companies keep ministers and the parliament informed of their activities. Whether the ministers only want to know about financial and auditing requirements is a different question. I would not presume to give that position, but I know that the parliament wants to be informed on a far wider basis than simply an economic basis. We want to see the public interest activities and accountability of these companies demonstrated for the benefit of the people of this country. That is why we believe this amendment actually enhances this bill and should be included within it.

In conclusion, unless there are any further comments, I urge my committee colleagues to support amendment No. 1, which places an obligation on Commonwealth authorities and executive officers and wholly owned Commonwealth companies and directors to act in the public interest. I seek leave to move amendments Nos 2 and 3 together. They are essentially the same amendments, and the same principle is involved.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2Before clause 42, page 19, insert the following clauses in Subdivision C:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Wholly-owned Commonwealth companies and directors to act in the public interest

SPEECH.PARA: "42AA.(1) A wholly-owned Commonwealth company must, at all times, act in the public interest.

"(2) A director of wholly-owned Commonwealth company must, at all times, act in the public interest in the exercise of his or her powers and the discharge of his or her duties in relation to the company.
"(3) In this section, `acting in the public interest' includes meeting the reasonable expectations of the public that:

PARA.TAB: (a)the company will, over time, and consistent with its other statutory obligations, act to maximise the extent to which it benefits the public; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b)a director will use his or her best efforts to ensure that the company will act in a safe, ethical, efficient, effective and accountable manner.".
3After clause 46, page 20, insert the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Injunctions to protect the public interest

SPEECH.PARA: "46A.(1) In this section `defaulter' means a Commonwealth authority or its subsidiary, or a wholly-owned Commonwealth company or its director, or an executive officer.

"(2) If a defaulter has acted, or is proposing to act, in a way that was not or would not be in the public interest, within the meaning of section 21AA or 42AA, a court of competent jurisdiction may, on the application of a person affected or likely to be affected by that conduct, grant an injunction restraining the defaulter from engaging in the conduct and, if in the court's opinion it is desirable to do so, requiring the defaulter to do a particular thing.
"(3) If in the opinion of the court it is desirable to do so, the court may grant an interim injunction pending determination of an application under subsection (1).
"(4) The court may discharge or vary an injunction granted under subsection (1) or (2).
"(5) The power of the court to grant an injunction restraining a defaulter from engaging in conduct may be exercised:

PARA.TAB: (a)whether or not it appears to the court that the defaulter intends to engage again, or to continue to engage, in conduct of that kind; and
(b)whether or not the defaulter has previously engaged in conduct of that kind.

SPEECH.PARA: "(6) The power of the court to grant an injunction requiring a defaulter to do a particular thing may be exercised:

PARA.TAB: (a)whether or not it appears to the court that the defaulter intends to refuse or fail again, or to continue to refuse or fail, to do that thing; and
(b)whether or not the defaulter has previously refused or failed to do that thing.".

TALK.START.PARA: —I expect that senators may be a little surprised to see me instead of Senator Kernot rising to speak to these bills. I submit Senator Kernot's apologies; she has other pressing engagements. I was handed these bills at 10 o'clock last night, so I ask forbearance if I am occasionally a little slow on the uptake. When Senator Chamarette commented on the amendments, she was kind enough to say that she did not exactly remember what Senator Kernot said.

PARA.TAB: My understanding was that we were concerned that similar amendments in other legislation contained a quite extensive regime of implementation related to the public interest issue. What is being proposed by Senator Chamarette does not do so. In some ways, therefore, it is more often exhortation than a clearly defined provision that carries detailed implementation provisions. Nevertheless, the Australian Democrats are going to support the amendments moved by Senator Chamarette. We believe that these companies, corporations and authorities have a responsibility to take account of the public interest. We believe that it is useful to have such a provision in this particular bill, and the Democrats will therefore be supporting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst sympathetic to the intentions of the Western Australian Greens' amendments which we are now discussing, the opposition will not be supporting them. In essence, we believe that `in the public interest' is really a matter which belongs here in the parliament rather than being set in the CAC Act. We also agree with the government's point that it is more appropriate to set extra conditions on particular enterprises in the bills which set up those enterprises. I have no problem about clearer definition of obligations in the particular bills, but I have a problem with this general one which covers a whole range of enterprises.

PARA.TAB: One problem relates to what is actually meant by `the public interest'. I think it is up to us in the parliament to define that rather than leaving it in this general legislation, the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill, to eventually be interpreted by the courts. For those reasons, the opposition does not support these amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not support the amendments either. In saying that, though, I want to say with all the force and power I can bring that the sentiments in the amendments are not something with which we disagree. The reason we do not support the amendments as such is that this is not the place to do it. It is already done, and done effectively, throughout this bill and elsewhere in other legislation. I guess that will invite the rejoinder, `Why can't we do it again?' But if we keep cluttering up Commonwealth legislation with noble sentiments peppered throughout, we will actually distort the legislative base, misdirect attention from what the real purpose of that legislation is and confuse people as to its meaning. It is better to keep things simple and clear and to set out the requirements in the appropriate place rather than simply to centralise the requirements for all government authorities in one simple bill.

PARA.TAB: When people look at a particular government authority and ask what its purpose in life is, what the obligations on its directors might be and how it should conduct its affairs ethically and honestly, they reach for the bill that gives life to that government agency. They expect to find set out therein what the obligations are, what the principles might be and the privileges that organisation might have. That is where they expect to find it; that is where it should be; that is where it is.

This is a bill that springs from a review which commenced over a year ago in order to reform the Audit Act. It is a bill which has widespread support in this chamber. It was introduced in the House of Representatives in June of last year and underwent scrutiny by the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts between June and September—a quite extended period of time. It has been subject to a report by that committee and has been through the scrutiny of a Senate hearing. There is a widespread view as to how we should proceed in a technical way.

I say, with the greatest of respect, to the proposers of the motion and the supporters of it that, for them to come through at the last minute after all of that process, and not having participated in it, and put up an amendment—no matter how nobly motivated it might be; and I do not deny the noble motivation—and then to not accept advice as to what the best way of implementing it might be is to ignore the whole process of rational debate and discussion and the formation of legislation and to ignore the obvious fact, which stands like a pikestaff before our eyes, that in the legislation for the particular government authorities lie the requirements, in code, of public good, public decency and public office.

As I have said, the general sentiments of this amendment are okay; I do not in any way resile from that. But the authorities are already expected to operate and act in the public interest. The authorities under this bill must be established for a public purpose. The statutory objectives and responsibilities that they have are designed to achieve that purpose. When we debate bills relating to them, we decide what that purpose is and how we can best achieve it.

The authorities under this bill require executive officers to exercise proper `care and diligence' to ensure that public purpose objectives are met and that the responsibilities that they have are carried out. Many of the organisations' provisions deal with accountability of executive officers. This is the main purpose of the bill. The proposed reference in the amendment to safety is not appropriate for financial legislation in this package. It should be in enabling acts or other legislation. In other words, this is an extension of the Audit Act and the requirements of the Audit Act. To extend the canvas more broadly, you ought to look to the bill—not to the Audit Act—to see what the other obligations might be.

The proposed requirements in this amendment for ethical conduct of executive officers is not necessary. The authorities already require executive officers to act honestly, which is the legal term. They preclude improper use of inside information and they preclude involvement in matters where directors have a `material personal interest'. That does cover the widest possible scope of responsibility in public office.

The proposed reference to efficiency and effectiveness is not essential here either. The necessary incentive will be provided by enhanced accountability requirements leading to more effective scrutiny of performance. Accountability requirements include regular reports to ministers, new annual reporting requirements and interim half-yearly or quarterly reports to parliament.

The proposed emphasis in this amendment on public interest would be difficult to administer in practice because it is subjective. This point of view was just made by the opposition. What is the public interest is a subjective judgment that each of us makes. For example, if the ABC showed a program which contained some violence, would it breach the public interest obligation? All of us will have a different view about that. To drag the ABC back and argue our personal subjective public interest view about that type of thing means that we would be interfering in the running of these organisations in a way that can be capricious and not go to the good running of those organisations. The purpose of this amendment is to ensure that we do not subject Commonwealth authorities to capricious subjective judgments; rather, there is a broad understanding of public interest which is best able to be raised in the holistic context of those reports when they come down.

If government business enterprises maximise benefits to the public, they would need to forgo profits and not provide a return to the Commonwealth. This is a very important point. The obvious reason why government business enterprises operate is to provide benefits to the public. They do it in two ways—by providing the services that they provide as a public service and by providing an income that they earn by providing that service to the tax office which can be redistributed as revenue on the outgoing side of the budget; that is, in programs administered by the Commonwealth. To simply take a one dimensional view rather than a two dimensional view of their role is unnecessarily inhibiting.

I refer to proposed clause 42AA concerning Commonwealth companies. Obligations to act in the public interest and maximise benefits to the public conflict with the Corporations Law. Under the Corporations Law, directors must act in the best interests of the company; that is, its shareholders. They must act legally. The Commonwealth is the shareholder in the case of government business enterprises. We must ensure that the standards of ethics and accountability of company executive officers are dealt with in the Corporations Law. We ensure those standards in our own law.

Finally, proposed clause 46A could be troublesome in practice. Persons with sufficient means could obtain injunctions, causing disruption and impeding efficient and effective operations. The vagueness of the meaning `public interest' would create considerable uncertainty, be a province for endless litigation and turn us into a litigious society. The authority may have a different view of public interest from the government, creating an impossible situation for executive officers in the practical administration of their authority.

I conclude by saying that I understand the sentiments. They are picked up elsewhere and in the appropriate place. The long scrutiny at committee level under both houses of this parliament has acknowledged that over the period. It is wrong now to come in at the last minute and try to change that. The sentiments are appropriately picked up elsewhere, and I have comprehensively answered those points. I ask that the amendment not succeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not intending to call a division. I will take some time to comment on what the minister has said. I appreciate his repeating and also adding to what he said yesterday. I thank Senator Spindler for his clarification and support of this amendment. I am very disappointed that the opposition is not able to support it at this time.

PARA.TAB: I totally refuse to apologise for any lateness of the introduction of this amendment or this concept because I believe it is the role of the parliament and of the Senate to endeavour to address bills and to improve them. As everybody in this chamber would be aware, it is not possible for Senator Margetts and I, as the two Green senators in the Senate, to engage in the long process—and I do appreciate the effort and the work of all the people who have contributed—and it is quite outrageous to suggest that, because of some lateness of introduction of the concept, it is illegitimate. It may well be producing difficulties for those who have to consult with members in party rooms and it may be difficult if arrangements have already been made. It is your problem if you have difficulty adjusting to the parliamentary democratic process.

It is not inappropriate to introduce a new concept or an amendment in this place; in fact, that is why we are here. I reject any kind of responsibility or acceptance of the criticism put forward by the minister. It is not wrong because it has been introduced now. While I appreciate the argument that maybe this should go in individual bills, I look forward to the time when the government introduces that into each of the bills that might be operating. It will take up a lot of the Senate's time to do that, but the minister can be assured of our support when the government seeks to introduce that in the individual bills—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the problem? The point is that it is in there now.

—The minister implies that it is within that already, and I will go on to talk about that. The minister has made the point that including it within this bill is inappropriate because it is more appropriately placed in the other bills. I would like to say that, as this is a package of accountability bills that replaces, in a sense, the Audit Act 1901 with modern legislation, it distorts this bill not to include some kind of clause about the fact that an audit responsibility includes looking at the public interest and not simply restricting it to financial accountability. Exclusion of this amendment distorts it if the general intention is there that accountability should involve public interest accountability as well as financial accountability. Unfortunately, if it is excluded because it adds to that, it does not distort but it is a grave problem.

PARA.TAB: The Greens were appalled to discover that when there was a package of this kind being introduced there was no mention of Commonwealth-owned instrumentalities being obliged to operate in the public interest. That is a very valid and important statement. It is not just to be assumed. I believe that the minister, later in his comments, revealed two major problems to the introduction of this concept. The first problem is that it does allow people who have been affected by the actions of Commonwealth instrumentalities to take out injunctions restraining them from engaging in those activities if they have a case—and that means a reasonable case—that those companies are not acting in the public interest. I believe that is a very valid reason for including them.

The second problem is that this concept conflicts with the Corporations Act and the need for these particular companies to be accountable to their shareholders. I believe that, because of the accountability to parliament and the responsibility being given under this legislation, there should be an accountability to the public as well. It is not simply good enough to say that the accountability in the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill is the equivalent of that which is available to private companies. It has to be a greater responsibility because much greater privileges are given. We need to have scrutiny of that aspect.

I cannot agree with the comments. I am not planning to call a division. I thank the Australian Democrats for their support and leave it on the public record that this is a measure that should be appropriately included. I regret that this amendment will not succeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add a couple of comments on the basic issue that I think has arisen from Senator Chamarette's amendment, and that is the position of government business enterprises and the conflict that may exist, and I suspect it does exist—the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) acknowledged it in his comments—between the strict objective that we expect private companies to have, and that is returning the maximum possible profit in terms of money dividends to their shareholders, and the additional obligation that government business enterprises have or they would not be government business enterprises. They have obligations that are related to the public interest. They usually have obligations that relate to policy areas that are of importance in the area in which they operate. I think it is a balance that needs to be struck as privatisation and corporatisation continue in our business community as they affect public authorities and government business enterprises.

PARA.TAB: I put on record that it is for that reason that we support this amendment. It is an issue that the government will have to deal with. I think an issue this parliament has to deal with is the need for government business enterprises to remain fully accountable on public interest criteria to this parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statements by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) need to be qualified. I think it is fairly amazing that the minister should state that there was ample opportunity for anyone to be involved at any stage during the process because I am hearing from a number of sources that along the way people have had great difficulty finding out what was going on in the process—the reason being that it is a very complex process and that the information about the realities of the total process is something that only few people hold.

PARA.TAB: So the reality is that many people within even the bureaucratic process in this place were unable to get full access to the process and have told me so. A number of people have told me that they feel the difficulties have been caused by being closed out of the system. For me, as a senator working through the aspects which are of concern to the Greens (WA), it has been like wading through a bowl of porridge.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a four-month public hearing. It was all out in the open.

—As the minister says, yes, there was a four-month public inquiry. It is fine having a public inquiry if the information that is necessary for the public to make realistic comments in the process is made available. But the problem is that the number of people in this place who have a realistic working knowledge of how this particular package of bills is to operate is very few. It is extremely difficult for not only us as parliamentarians but even the bureaucracy and the general public to get a handle on what is going on in this package. A public process is fine if the public knows or has access to what is actually going on.

PARA.TAB: As we know, the number of bodies involved in this process or likely to be drawn into this entire process are huge. As I mentioned before, there is not even anyone who can tell us the list of these bodies, let alone the impact on each of them. To say that public interest cannot be incorporated is amazing. When we have built into a publicly funded body shareholders who at an annual general meeting have the ability to vote out their board and to ask questions about the way their funds are being managed, they have the ability to question whether or not their interests are being met. When the owners of those enterprises, however semantically you may argue it—that is, the people of Australia, the people we represent—do not have that access because those enterprises are answerable only to a minister, and even that is sometimes questionable, who can choose whether he passes on information to us, the elected parliamentarians of this place, you have a real problem.

What we are suggesting is not outrageous. If you cannot or if nobody is able to judge what is in the public interest, one wonders on what basis government business enterprises operate. Which particular government business enterprise would you think is inappropriate to operate in the public interest? Can you tell me which ones would not suit a public interest clause? Which ones would you be prepared to operate against the public interest? Which ones would not be appropriate to operate in the interests of the people of Australia?

Is it appropriate that a government is prepared to let government business enterprises—those enterprises operating with public funds and the profits of which, if you sell it, eventually go into government general revenue or maybe do things which may financially affect the general coffers or the lifestyle of people in Australia—operate against the public interest? How can you suggest leaving things secret so that shareholders are not able to check their own interest in relation to this enterprise—that is, taxpayers are unable to assess whether these enterprises which are using their money are acting in their interest? What kind of level playing field is this? Perhaps you can let me know. Which enterprises would you be prepared to allow to operate against the public interest?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to reply, but I have been asked some questions so I will keep my reply brief but to the point. It simply comes down to the following points. Firstly, the enterprise is set up under an act of this parliament. That act comes through this chamber. The reason for setting it up is to give expression to the public interest. This chamber and the other chamber jointly vote and decide on that. That then becomes the public interest purpose of that enterprise.

PARA.TAB: So the first part your dissertation, which obviously you feel passionately about, is wrong, with respect, for the reason that there is ultimate control of parliament because the parliament gives birth to these enterprises, decides what their purpose is and sets down the criteria on which they operate. It may be that you disagree with the view of parliament in some cases. It might be that so do I, but the will of the parliament is the highest expression of the will of the people in this democracy and that is how it should be.

Secondly, the enterprises put down an annual report saying what their purpose is, how they have performed and that their accounts are duly audited and presented for the people of Australia. That is available to every citizen of this country. Thirdly, those reports and the appropriations that this parliament might provide go through a series of scrutinies by this chamber in estimates and by debate in appropriations. That is ultimate scrutiny. That is openness and transparency in government. That is what you would expect of a government and that is what the government does.

There may well be conspiracy theories and worries about imaginary secret deals and so on. We set up the system in order that it works perfectly and properly. If it can work better, let us set it up better. We think this is the best way of doing it. That does not mean to say that some people who work in the system may not be dishonest. In every large organisation some people are dishonest and do bad things, but we are not setting it up so that is encouraged. We are setting it up so that is able to be identified and dealt with—discouraged and penalised where it is found to be the case. That is the appropriate responsibility of government. It is in a particular bill that the public interest is expressed. I do not think I have anything further to say on this subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer, but I do not think he is addressing the full situation. Yesterday I was pleased that the minister clarified the situation in relation to government business enterprises which receive an appropriation. He talked about accountability. But let us just take for interest's sake the example of Telstra, the annual report of which has been tabled in the parliament. We can get very angry if we think that the public interest may not be being served by the way this particular body is operating, but what right do we have, as the elected parliament, to call evidence from this body if it does not receive an appropriation in this year? What parliamentary scrutiny is there of this organisation if there are problems about its operating or not operating in the public interest? What right do we have as elected parliamentary representatives if it receives no appropriation in this year?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —You have absolute right because its annual report comes down and you can scrutinise it then.
—With all due respect, Minister, are you now saying that a government business enterprise which does not receive an appropriation this year may also be called to scrutiny by a standing committee?
—The parliament scrutinises the annual reports of all government bodies.

—Can I just clarify this? A government business enterprise which does not receive an appropriation in one year may be called to present evidence to a standing committee even if it does not receive an appropriation in that year?
—I am saying that the parliament, under a committee system in this chamber, among other means, scrutinises the annual reports of all government bodies and that is the appropriate way to proceed.

—The minister is not deigning to stand to answer this question, but it was very specific. It is not an unreasonable question. I am asking whether a standing committee of this place has the right to require evidence of a government business enterprise which does not receive an appropriation in any particular year. That is the specific question. I ask the minister to respond.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—The minister has responded by way of interjection.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me respond by way of an answer so that we can lower the level of temperature in here. The answer is the same answer I gave you yesterday, Senator, to the same question—yes.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1Clause 28, page 13, insert the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Exemption of Australian Broadcasting Corporation from policy directives

SPEECH.PARA: "28A. Section 28 has no application in relation to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.".

This is a very important amendment designed to protect the statutory independence of the ABC. The ABC is a unique body in a statutory sense. Under its act and charter, it is guaranteed statutory independence from government. Under section 8 of the ABC Act, the government is entitled to propose policies to the ABC board, but it is up to the board to decide whether those policies should be adopted. I am advised, though, that in basically all cases the policies are adopted.

PARA.TAB: But there remains the power to refuse to adopt a policy where it conflicts with other charter responsibilities of the ABC. This could affect, for example, having dealings with particular foreign governments. It could affect staff allocations to particular issues or bureaus. It could affect the general procedures for appointment of staff or even of the chief executive of the organisation.

In short, independence goes much further than the scheduling and broadcasting proposed in the present government amendment.
