The result of the Democrats' amendment will be that the ABC will continue to be bound by the rest of the CAC Bill in relation to financial accountability and reporting—in other words, it does remain fully accountable in those areas—but in relation to policy directions, which might not be just financial, the current provision of section 8 of the ABC Act, allowing the government to propose and the board to consider, will continue to stand as well.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the amendment standing in Senator Kernot's name and moved by Senator Spindler relating to the ABC. The government has no difficulty with the intent of this amendment, but again we have difficulty with where the amendment is placed. Senators will notice that I have put down notice of an amendment to the Audit (Transitional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill, which is to come on after this, that achieves the same end, I believe, as Senator Spindler is seeking—that is, to omit item 120 and add at the end another provision, the explanatory memorandum of which refers to the ABC Act and to the issue that Senator Spindler has just raised.

PARA.TAB: I do not disagree with the amendment. The government has a motion down to do this itself. We believe the appropriate place for doing it is in the transitional and consequential bill, the Audit (Transitional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition is in favour of the intention of Senator Spindler's amendment, but as things stand we are happy with what the government has proposed in the transition bill, which I believe does affect what the Democrats are asking. We are happy to go along with that when we get to the bill later today. I would like to ask a question of the minister with regard to clause 28. Does that apply to the Reserve Bank?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer is `Not yet', but it would be a matter for determination under the bill that is yet to come—the No. 2 bill. Our position on that is that normally clause 28 would then apply unless there is some particular reason why we should change that.
—I ask because of current concern about interest rates. As you read section 28 now, the government may send in writing—

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—How is this relevant to Senator Spindler's amendment?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the clause which he was asking to amend.
—All right. He is putting in a new clause.

—I am just using this as an example to tease out. If this goes through as is, will the government be able to send a direction in writing to the Reserve Bank to put a cap on interest rates, for instance?
—While the minister is looking for that, does Senator Spindler have further questions in relation to his amendment?
—In view of what has been said by the minister and by the opposition, I am happy to not proceed with my amendment and to accept the government's amendment in the other bill.

PARA.TAB: Amendment—by leave—withdrawn.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand the question from Senator Gibson, it relates to whether the Commonwealth government would direct the directors of the Reserve Bank. Obviously the government, as in the case of all statutory authorities, makes known its broad policies. In the case of interest rate adjustments, Senator, you would know that the views of the government are taken into account but the decision is made on its merits by the board of directors of the Reserve Bank, and it is certainly the government's intention not to change that arrangement. The decision is the decision of the Reserve Bank board, not of the government, and the Reserve Bank directors in making their decision have to have regard to the charter under which they are appointed and the obligations that they have as directors of the Reserve Bank. They therefore take into account a wide range of issues, one of which of course is what views the government might wish to convey to them.

—In regard to the same point, does that mean that the particular provisions in specific acts like the Reserve Bank act take precedence over section 28 in the CAC Bill? Which has precedence—section 28 in the CAC Bill or particular directives within the particular bill governing that body?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The latter. We are talking here about very broad policy issues. On page 10 of the explanatory memorandum, `Division 5—Miscellaneous', the description there, `Clause 28—Compliance with the general policies of the Government', sets out, I think, reasonably succinctly what the position here is, but these are broad policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now proceed to amendment No. 2 in its new formulation standing in the name of Senator Kernot for the Australian Democrats. The changed wording has been distributed to the chamber this morning. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 45, page 20, after subclause (1), insert the following subclause:
"(1A) Regulations referred to in subsection (1) must not take effect before the time within which they may be disallowed by each House of the Parliament has expired.".

The amendment, like a similar amendment to the Auditor-General Bill, affects the regulation making power which affects the application of the act to security and intelligence organisations. It ensures that the regulations must be properly debated by parliament before being enacted. Clearly that is an important requirement.

PARA.TAB: The FMA Bill and the Auditor-General Bill are about accountability of organisations back to parliament. It should be parliament and not security or intelligence organisations, or the government for that matter, that decides in what circumstances and to what extent these reporting functions should be modified. I commend this amendment to the committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —We had this debate yesterday under the FMA Bill and, for the same reasons I gave yesterday, I oppose it today.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1994 seeks to create part of a new regulatory and accountability regime for Commonwealth authorities. The point that must be made is that, at the end of the day, the enforcement of that regime is dependent upon the willingness of the government for those officers to be accountable. By way of example, clause 22 of this bill says that executive officers must act honestly. The heading reads `Executive officers must act honestly etc.'—which, in itself, is an interesting concept. Subclause 22(1) says:

PARA.TAB: An executive officer of a Commonwealth authority must at all times act honestly in the exercise of his or her powers and the discharge of his or her duties.

SPEECH.PARA: It goes on to outline a maximum penalty. It does not quite tell us what `acting honestly' is. I think that is something the government wishes to leave to the courts.

PARA.TAB: At the end of the day ministers, to whom government authorities are accountable, also have a large part to play in determining what is `acting honestly'. Many senators would be of the view that there have been times when officers of government departments and authorities have gone into estimates hearings with the view that they will not exactly answer all questions in as forward and accurate a fashion as is possible. From some of the estimates hearings Senator Margetts has attended she will probably have formed that view herself in relation to some of the matters she sought to raise.

I seek to give an example of how obligations to act honestly are dependent upon the willingness of the minister to enforce accountability within the particular entity in question. I wish to refer to the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service. As honourable senators would be aware, this service has been under close examination since the last election as a result of revelations of financial impropriety.

One of the Senior Executive Service officers at the heart of those investigations, Mr Phillip J. Corrigan, was charged with six counts under the Public Service Act in May last year. The estimates committee was told on 15 February this year that those charges were only finalised that day and, therefore, the committee could not be apprised of the outcome of the charges because Mr Corrigan himself had not been. Why was Mr Corrigan not apprised of the outcome of the charges that day? Because he happened to be in the United Kingdom, where he is enjoying a #50,000 a year post whilst on extended leave of absence from the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service.

On 17 March—over a month after I received an undertaking that I would be advised of the outcome of those charges as soon as possible—I wrote a letter to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), again seeking advice as to which charges, if any, were proved and the penalty imposed. I seek leave to incorporate the text of that letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA—THE SENATE
BILL O'CHEE
SENATOR FOR QUEENSLAND
17 March, 1995
Senator the Hon Bob Collins
Minister for Primary Industries and Energy
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Facsimile Number: 2734120
Dear Minister
Phillip J. Corrigan
As you would be aware, undertakings were given to advise forthwith the outcomes of charges of the abovenamed Mr Corrigan of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service.
It is my understanding that those matters were dealt with this week, but I am yet to receive advice as to which charges, if any, were found proved, and the penalty imposed.
I would be grateful if you would advise urgently the outcome of these matters by facsimile to my Parliament House office, as well as to my Brisbane office on (07)2299735.
Yours sincerely
(Signed) For
SENATOR BILL O'CHEE
Senator for Queensland and
National Party Whip in the Senate

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The point is that I still have not been advised by Senator Collins of the outcome of the letter. What is very clear is that Mr Corrigan, who was under some substantial degree of suspicion, otherwise there would not have been six charges preferred against him under the Public Service Act, has left a job in Australia, which I understand was an SES band 1 post—I am happy to be corrected if it was not—and which attracted a salary of between $60,000 and $69,000 a year and, whilst he is under suspicion, he gets a reference from the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service which enables him to take up a post in the United Kingdom that pays him $40,000 a year more.

PARA.TAB: The leave application for his extended leave of absence was signed by the secretary to the department after undertakings had been given by the previous minister responsible for this matter that it would be investigated thoroughly and that there would be a new broom of accountability go through AQIS. If this is the standard of accountability that ministers require, then all the fine words and all the legislation that the government may wish to bring before this Senate is for naught if this is allowed to happen.

But the saga becomes worse. Not only has Mr Corrigan managed to duck out of the country with a reference written by AQIS and get an extra $40,000 a year in salary, but in addition to that Mr Corrigan is now at the centre of a scandal in the United Kingdom. His appointment may well hold up the implementation of a new meat inspection service in the United Kingdom. From information available to me, a number of members of parliament have sought to delay the implementation of the meat hygiene service over there, inter alia on the grounds of Mr Corrigan's appointment and the references that were provided to him by the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service.

It is more now than simply a matter of the government having an obligation to account to this parliament through the estimates committee as to the disciplinary charges against Mr Corrigan—my concerns that were expressed in my letter to Senator Collins on 17 March remain. Because of the international scope of this matter, it is now also incumbent upon the government to provide answers in relation to Mr Corrigan so as to avoid further damage to the operations of the United Kingdom's Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food.

It is very clear that the government should now urgently advise: what was Mr Corrigan's previous rank within the Senior Executive Service—was he an SES band 1 officer or SES band 2 officer? And what references were provided? Copies of those references should also be provided. An answer given last week in the House of Commons to a question on notice indicated that Mr Corrigan came with a reference from the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service. It does not sound like the government is taking the issue of financial accountability terribly seriously when it writes references for officers so as to get them high-paying jobs overseas whilst they are still under investigation on charges in this country.

What were the six charges? What were the outcomes of the six charges? The minister has to recognise that it is a matter of the utmost urgency to answer these questions, that his delay is contributing to concern about the operation of the meat hygiene service in the United Kingdom and that further delay may prevent the United Kingdom government from implementing that service.

It is not just a matter of accountability to the parliament; it is a matter of common decency, given that the United Kingdom government is suffering the consequences of Mr Corrigan's appointment. The government does have an obligation to account. I believe that this is a threshold test of accountability.

It is fine to have all the legislation, it is fine to have all the words, but, at the end of the day, it is the government's willingness to see that accountability occurs which is the most important factor. I urge the government again to address these problems. Today is the last sitting day of this week. I certainly would welcome a statement by the minister after question time, if he wishes to respond to these things. If he does not do so, I would certainly be wondering why, given the level of concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what we have heard from Senator O'Chee is exactly the proof of what Senator Chamarette was talking about in relation to public interest. There are very good reasons why particular authorities are public authorities. Often it is because the service they provide is something more than the matter of dollars and cents. There are values involved and there are services which require that people not only make a profit but also act in the public interest.

PARA.TAB: We all know that operations in relation to such things as quarantine may have devastating effects on both industry and perhaps even our wildlife species in Australia. There is no dollar figure that can be placed on that. If there is a disaster within a private company, you could take people to court and sue them. Maybe you can do that with a government department. However, the private damage to the individual is more difficult to pull out and isolate.

The problem is that when you are dealing with a public entity which possibly has responsibility for the existence of an entire industry—whether it is a rural industry or a whole set of species which might be wiped out by incorrect application of such things as important quarantine rules—you have to take into account the public interest. Might I say that our ability to deal with these kinds of things becomes more difficult in relation to the new rules of lowest common denominator under Codex Alimentaire of GATT.

It is even more important that these kinds of bodies are seen—and can be challenged in this respect, before things go terribly wrong—to be acting in the public interest. It is, therefore, amazing that the opposition did not support Senator Chamarette's amendment when it is now giving proof of why it is necessary for enterprises operated by the government and wholly owned by the public to be required to act in the public interest.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —With the greatest respect to the two previous speakers—Senator O'Chee and Senator Margetts—no `proof' has been adduced here, nor should it have been. Allegations have been made and when we are dealing with allegations versus proof we, as a legislative chamber, should be very careful.

PARA.TAB: We do not decide what is true; courts do. If there are five or seven charges of misconduct preferred against an officer of the Commonwealth, that is not a matter for this Senate chamber to determine. It is a matter for the Senate chamber to uphold the principle of justice: people are innocent until proven guilty and the matter goes to a court of law to be properly dealt with. I am not suggesting that Senator O'Chee is arguing otherwise; I am simply clarifying that no proof has been adduced.

We are debating framework legislation for the Auditor-General in conducting audits of government authorities. The branch of government that has been referred to, the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service, AQIS, does not come under this bill; it is not a Commonwealth authority or a Commonwealth company. AQIS is a branch of the Department of Primary Industry and Energy so, whatever the amendments to this bill, it does not deal with this specific case.

However, as often happens—I do not complain about it—when we are debating broad issues of legislative principle, specific cases of concern are raised. They are not always to the point of the legislation but the debate provides an opportunity for honourable senators to make points about issues of concern to them.

I know that Senator O'Chee has been pursuing this line of investigation. I have a distant memory of it from an occasion when I represented the Department of Primary Industries and Energy before a Senate estimates committee at which he directly questioned the officer, Mr Corrigan. I understand the political use that these phrases are put to but I object when Senator O'Chee says that the government issued Mr Corrigan with a reference.

It would not be appropriate for me to go to the details of a particular case at law, and I do not intend to do so. However, to the ear of a common listener the statement that the government issued Mr Corrigan with a reference may lead to the assumption that the ministerial representative of the government in that instance—the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins—wrote a reference. I do not understand that to be the case but someone in the department who had knowledge of Mr Corrigan as an officer wrote an evaluation of that officer in the form of a reference. That reference was later used by that officer in finding another job.

Obviously, that is not something that any government can necessarily have control over. We are not always in a position to decide who writes references for whom within the bureaucracy, nor to evaluate the accuracy of those references. It may well be that the reference referred to—I have not seen it—was entirely accurate. Usually, with applications for high positions, people check references and contact the originating officer. But, in a way, that is going to the details of a specific case, and I do not intend to do that.

I make the observation, though, that the broad brush word of government does not mean that we have made a political decision to endorse a particular officer; rather, that someone in the bureaucracy has written a reference for a particular officer. That can be characterised as government, but I think it needs to be differentiated here. Whatever the rights and wrongs of this particular case, the bill before the chamber would not address it. It may well be that Senator Collins has his monitor on in his office and has heard the comments of Senator O'Chee. Perhaps he will be in a position to say something after question time. I do not know. I am sure that the issue will be pursued by Senator O'Chee, and I will certainly bring it to the attention of Senator Collins.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Cook for the undertaking to draw the matter to the attention of Senator Collins. Just for Senator Cook's elucidation, I point out that this is not a matter of proof or otherwise. The estimates committee has been told that the charges have been dealt with; that the matters have been finalised. There was an undertaking to advise me and the estimates committee of the outcome of those findings. That undertaking has not been met. I am not attempting to prejudge it. I am saying that that undertaking having been given, the matters having been finalised, it is important that there be a proper answer in relation to those questions. That is what I seek.

—I seek clarification from the minister with regard to clause 28, which we were talking about earlier. I have been advised since our earlier discussion that precedence, whether it is for the general act or the particular act, resides with the latest act in time. Is that correct, Minister?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was expecting Senator Gibson to go on to clause 45. I did not catch the last part of his question. Perhaps he could ask it again.

—Earlier we were discussing clause 28, which requires responsible ministers to notify in writing the directors of commonwealth authorities of general policies. I used the Reserve Bank as an example and asked whether the government could give a directive to the Reserve Bank. I asked which took precedence: the particulars in the Reserve Bank Act or clause 28 in the CAC bill. Minister, I think you said that the particular act took precedence. I have since been advised that the act which is the latest in time has precedence. In which case, when this bill is passed, it will have precedence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer I gave earlier was really a synopsis answer to what is set out on page 10 of the explanatory memorandum attending this bill. Under clause 28 of that explanatory memorandum, it reads:

PARA.TAB: In interpreting what is a general policy of the Government, a reasonable test would be whether the policy is capable of being applied to the majority of, or all, Commonwealth authorities; if capable of being applied only to one or a very few, it would not reasonably be regarded as falling within the meaning of "general policies" and should, if necessary, be addressed in the authority's enabling legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: That highlights the point that I was labouring to make about the broadness and sweep of government policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook). I have one final matter to raise whilst we are in committee. Minister, are you aware that I received a letter two days ago from Blake, Dawson and Waldron concerning possible amendments to the CAC Act? This firm wrote on behalf of the grains industry. Last month it also wrote to the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee for the committee's hearing on these bills on 3 March. On that occasion, the firm was representing the 14 research and development primary industry corporations.

PARA.TAB: The point Blake, Dawson and Waldron made, and made earlier to the Public Accounts Committee, was that the CAC Bill does not reflect here and there the exact wording of the Corporations Law, and it recommended that it should. I think you, Senator Cook, gave me an answer at the Senate committee hearing on 3 March that it did not matter. Mr Conley of Blake, Dawson and Waldron, who wrote the letter of 21 March—and I know you have a copy of it—disagrees with that interpretation. I seek leave of the committee to have this letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Facsimile transmission
Blake Dawson Waldron
Solicitors
21 March 1995
From: W C Conley, Tel No (06) 234 4017
To: Senator B Gibson
Parliament House, Canberra
Copy to: Senator P Cook
Parliament House, Canberra
Dear Senator Gibson
Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill ("CAC" Bill)

I understand from representatives of the Grains Industry that you would like my view in response to comments of the Department of Finance concerning amendments to the CAC Bill which were enclosed with my letter of 23 February 1995 by way of submission to The Senate Finance and Public Legislation Committee.
I note the comments which you made in the hearings of the Committee and the exchange you had with Mr Carter from the Department of Finance.

As you no doubt also concluded I believed, after having read the Hansard Report of your exchange, that those of my proposed amendments dealing with the duties of Directors of Commonwealth Authorities to take various steps, would be accepted.

The nature of the various drafting amendments I proposed was to bring the provisions of the CAC Bill into line with the similar provisions of the Corporations Law relating to reporting requirements of Directors. This seemed sensible, if for no other reason, it was in line with the Government's declared intention in relation to the Bill, to have similar duties imposed on Directors of Commonwealth Authorities.

I now understand that the Government does not intend to accept many of my proposed amendments and that you have been informed they are regarded as only subsidiary matters and that their incorporation would not make any difference to the interpretation of the Bill.

I disagree with the Government's opinion. The provisions of the Bill in relation to the preparation of reports, interim financial statements, estimates of receipts and expenditure, delivery of these documents and notification of significant events, as well as generally keeping relevant Ministers informed, are all drafted on the basis that they provide that the Directors must personally take the action, the subject of the section. I understand the Government believes that Courts will interpret this wording along the lines that the obligation on the Directors will be to cause these actions to be taken.

In my opinion, there is a real risk Courts will not be prepared to depart from the clear wording of the Bill, if and when a report is not provided on time or a relevant notification is not made. The Bill does not provide for Directors to be subject to penalties based on whether or not they have failed to take reasonable steps or whether or not they have failed to cause something to be done. Rather the Bill proceeds on the basis that if a report is not delivered or a notification is not made, the Directors are criminally liable for not delivering the report or not making the notification.

As you know, the provisions of the Bill have caused a great deal of concern amongst Directors of Commonwealth Statutory Corporations. It is a pity that a number of minor amendments of a drafting nature which would have substantially allayed the concerns of so many Directors, have not been agreed to by the Government, particularly when by the Government's own admission the amendments would have made clear and beyond doubt the intention of the Government and the Parliament when these new personal duties, punishable by criminal sanction, were imposed on Directors of Commonwealth Corporations.
Yours sincerely
W C Conley

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I understand that the government has the intention of taking these matters into account in the near future. Would you indicate to me whether that is so, please?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gibson, I understand your concern, and I acknowledge that this is not the first time you have raised the issue. You have been persistent in pushing this issue, which is to your credit. Your concern is that the provisions of the CAC Bill require directors to do certain things, whereas similar provisions in the Corporations Law require directors to cause those things to be done. Therefore, there is a perception that, under the CAC Act, directors must perform obligations personally, whereas, under Corporations Law, they employ other persons to do it.

PARA.TAB: I know it has been argued that this would be onerous and would deter persons from taking up appointments on boards of Commonwealth authorities, which is the general point. From my perspective, as Minister representing the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley), we have advice that the Office of Parliamentary Counsel has assured us that the meaning is the same in both cases—that is, in both cases, the director may employ other persons but the director still remains responsible. However, there would be no harm in adopting the phrase `cause to be done' where the corresponding Corporations Law requirement uses it.

Up until now, though, in the time available since the matter was raised, drafting resources have not been available to make the necessary amendments. But—and this is the `but' I think you are searching for—in order to clarify the intent of the bill, the government will include the necessary amendments in the second round of consequential amendments to the CAC Bill. These will be introduced in the next parliamentary session. That is the undertaking that I have now read into Hansard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Minister, for that undertaking. I can assure the minister and the committee that there are a lot of directors on government boards who would be pleased to hear the reassurance that those changes will be made.

PARA.TAB: Bill, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: AUDITOR-GENERAL BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Clauses 1 to 4—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 5.

SPEECH.PARA: 1Clause 5, page 2, before the definition of "Minister" insert the following definition:
"'Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit' means the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit established under the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951;".

This amendment, which simply inserts the definition that the `Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit means the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit established under the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951', is dependent on amendments to the next bill to be pursued.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is similar to amendment No. 1 of the Democrats standing in Senator Kernot's name. It is a consequential amendment which would follow if the Democrats' or opposition amendments to establish a Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit are agreed to. The Democrats will support it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first of Senator Short's foreshadowed amendments. It proposes to change clause 2, page 2, by inserting the definition of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit and providing a meaning to that definition. All I can say about this is that it seems very much to us that it would be better to wait and see whether the provisions of the transitional bill are amended before we include this. That is the preference of the government.

—I have great confidence in this amendment, having had earlier discussions with the other parties. I do not think there is any doubt about what is going to happen with the following bill. In the interest of saving time, I think it would be easier to just plough through it now; I really do.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Then I suggest we move quickly to the vote.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 6 to 8—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Proposed new clause 8A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment essentially inserts reference to the Auditor-General and the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit with regard to audit priorities and reports of the committee. It puts into the bill directives, if you like, that the Auditor-General must take into account in doing his work. In other words, it just makes it clear what the parliament thinks, and I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2Page 3, after clause 8, insert the following new clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Auditor-General and Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit

SPEECH.PARA: "8A. The Auditor-General should, so far as is practicable:

TAB.TAB: (a)have regard to audit priorities advised by the Committee in accordance with paragraph 8(1)(h) of the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951; and

PARA.TAB: (b)have regard to any reports of the committee made in accordance with paragraph 8(1)(j) of the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951.".

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are supporting this amendment. In its original form, it sought to require the Auditor-General to have regard to the priorities of the audit committee. We thought that probably went a bit too far. After all, we have to remember that at the end of the day the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit will have a government majority. Through this provision the Auditor-General could well have ended up more under the thumb of the government than is possible under the current legislation.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats believe that the Auditor-General should have regard to the priorities of the committee. This is made clear in the proposed terms of reference of the committee, which include advising the audit priorities of the parliament. These matters have been discussed with the opposition. The opposition has revised its amendment, and we are pleased to support it in its present form.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this amendment. In view of what has just been said, we recognise that we are out-gunned by numbers and that the amendment may therefore pass. However, we remain opposed to this amendment. The reason for our opposition to this amendment is that, if carried, it would erode something that senators in this place have held as sacred: the independence of the Auditor-General. The assumption behind this amendment is that the Auditor-General ought to be able to be directed and that the Auditor-General can be directed by a committee of this parliament. Our contention is that that is not appropriate. The Auditor-General has and should have his responsibilities, is independent and should not be able to be directed, and that applies to both the parliament and the executive wing of government.

PARA.TAB: The opposition we have is on the principle that this would erode the specific powers of the Auditor-General. The Auditor-General should be functionally independent. He should not be a creature of either the executive or the parliament. To require that a committee of the parliament be able to decide what the Auditor-General must have regard to is, in our contention, wrong in principle and should be rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not agree with giving directives to the Auditor-General. The wording is `so far as is practicable have regard to audit priorities advised by the committee'. We believe that the Auditor-General and the audit office basically are answerable to the parliament—the parliament representing the people—and this just reinforces that.

—In support of what Senator Gibson said, the amendment says quite clearly `as far as is practicable' in addition to the phrases that Senator Gibson outlined. I certainly agree with the minister that the executive should not be giving directions to the Auditor-General—after all, the Auditor-General is reporting to parliament. If parliament has notice of some matter that it thinks the Auditor-General should turn his or her attention to, I believe it is perfectly appropriate for that to be provided for. It is on that basis that the Democrats support the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —We still remain opposed. While the words fudge it, nonetheless the amendment puts an onus on the Auditor-General to have regard, and act accordingly, to what a committee of the parliament thinks the Auditor-General should do. From reading the amendment, the onus is quite clear in that respect. That does erode the functional independence of the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: The view can be held that the parliament is the shareholder and that, therefore, we should be able to point the Auditor-General in specific directions. The Auditor-General is a person who is wise in the ways of the world and knows what life is about. As an independent entity he can decide for himself whether or not those things should or should not apply without the onus being put on him to do so in an act of the Commonwealth. If the auditor is to be seen as what he should always be seen as—purely an independent, fearless examiner and reporter—then he should not have an obligation to tip his hat in any direction. He should be able to decide for himself which way to go, be wise in the ways of the world and take advice without having the obligation imposed on him by legislation to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to hold up the committee unduly, but I feel it is incumbent on me to respond to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook). Either words mean what they state or they do not. We haggle over words and clauses in this chamber as to whether they should or should not be included on the basis of what meaning they have. This amendment quite clearly says `so far as is practicable' and `have regard to'. It does not mean that the Auditor-General shall consider, shall undertake investigations, shall do this or shall do that. It simply is a capacity for parliament to draw to the attention of the Auditor-General a matter, and it is then entirely up to his or her discretion whether or not to proceed.

—I indicate that the Greens support this amendment. At least the government is being consistent in its interpretation of these clauses that it does not want to have any constraints being applied. That is its rationale for objecting to the phrase `should, so far as is practicable, have regard to'. However, an alternative position can be put, and that is the one the Greens hold: spelling out some of the directions relating to the parliament and the Auditor-General can assist the Auditor-General in knowing in advance the information or kinds of priorities which are expected by parliament in terms of providing that assistance to the parliament. For that reason, I do not agree with the comments of the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) and indicate our support for this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make just one last foray on behalf of the government to try to deter the chamber from doing something that would damage the independence of the Auditor-General. I could agree broadly with Senator Spindler's contention were it not for the fact that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts also has the power to then review the Auditor-General's reports. So we have one committee saying to the Auditor-General that it thinks he should do something, and we have another committee asking the Auditor-General whether he has done it and what the outcome is. That would surround the Auditor-General with obligations which tarnish his standing as an independent officer.

PARA.TAB: Let me now put myself in the shoes of those senators who are supporting this amendment and offer what they may regard as—I hope they do not—gratuitous advice. It seems to me that the position from which they come is a reasonable one. That position is: we should retain a healthy suspicion anyway about whether any of these things are accurate, and we should commence a scrutiny of these reports from a sceptical standpoint. That is what scrutiny is about.

I think it strengthens the hand of the sceptic if it cannot be argued that the Auditor-General has been unduly influenced by obligations imposed on him by legislation and it can be argued that the Auditor-General is an honest, totally independent reporter. He is then the true witness. For sceptics to try to turn the Auditor-General into an agent of their scepticism to do and follow the avenues of investigation they want, whether or not it meets the needs of the Auditor-General, and then review the outcome and offer a report card with a distinction, pass or fail is the wrong way for this chamber to act.

I suggest that the hand of the honest sceptic is best strengthened by an Auditor-General who is fiercely independent and unencumbered by these sorts of obligations so that the report that he then puts will still their scepticism or in fact encourage it but do so in the most independent way—otherwise he will be surrounded in a way in which it is open for some person to say, `Maybe he did it in this way because he was placed under a political obligation.'

I will say one final thing about this and then I will have said everything. The parliament is a political body selected by the people. It is a political house. Committees of the parliament are political. Committees of the parliament offering directions for inquiry and then examining and reporting on those directions of inquiry for an independent officer can be seen to be, in specific cases, acting politically for political purposes. You do not want that stain in any way to be attached to an independent officer such as the Auditor-General—you do not want it. To invite that type of allegation is to diminish the office. It is in the interest of holding the integrity of the office that I ask you not to proceed with your amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual, I am grateful for the advice offered by the minister. I do not regard it as gratuitous. It is a point of view that the minister offers on behalf of the government. Seeing that he mentioned the matter of suspicions, that is where the area of suspicions lies. There must be a suspicion or at least a very sound scepticism about the influence that can be exerted over the Auditor-General by a minister or by the government—the executive as a whole. I am not casting aspersions on the present government; I am saying that the government of the day must have a counterbalance that this house can offer.

PARA.TAB: I cannot see anything wrong in the chamber of the people—if I can use that grandiose term—saying to the Auditor-General, `There is something that we think you might like to turn your attention to.' The Auditor-General can still decide not to do so. Another committee may then say to the Auditor-General, as the minister foreshadowed, `Why didn't you look at that?' It is perfectly proper, firstly, to ask that question on behalf of the parliament and, secondly, for the Auditor-General to give his or her reasons why that particular matter was not taken up. We have a very sound accountability process which comes back to where it should be—the parliament, this house.
Amendment agreed to.
Clauses 9 to 13—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 14.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3B.Clause 14, page 4, lines 24 to 27, omit subclause (2), substitute the following subclause:
"(2) The Auditor-General may at any time conduct a performance audit of a Commonwealth authority that is a GBE or any of its subsidiaries.".

We actually put up two alternatives. After discussions with the Democrats, we reached agreement that the simpler version, which is amendment 3B, should be the one moved. This clause allows the Auditor-General the freedom to make his own decision about whether or not he should do a performance audit of a GBE. This is going to be a rare event; it is not going to be a normal procedure. We believe the parliament would be chopping off its options for information by preventing the Auditor-General from doing this. As the bill stands now, the Auditor-General is prevented from doing a performance audit of a GBE unless there is agreement from the minister or both houses of parliament. We believe that is too restrictive. We believe the Auditor-General should have the right to make the choice of whether to do a performance audit of a GBE.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to put on the record that not only is this amendment supported by the Democrats but also it was moved jointly by us and the opposition. It is indeed a vitally important amendment. It seeks to ensure that the mandate of the Auditor-General is extended across the full range of Commonwealth GBEs. We are in full agreement with the opposition that all GBEs should be subject to performance audit unless there is a substantial private sector ownership.

PARA.TAB: In the absence of proper accountability of GBEs to shareholders through the stock exchange, it is important that parliament establish a clear level of accountability over the GBEs. As shown with the recent ANL case, the current ministerial discretion over efficiency audits for GBEs creates a very serious accountability owed. This amendment is broadly in line with the recommendations of the JCPA in both its reports, the recommendations of the WA Inc. royal commission and of the Queensland Electoral and Administrative Review Committee, and best practice in both states. The royal commission and the Electoral and Administrative Review Committee both highlight the vital importance of giving the Auditor-General free range.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to support the Anzac Day Bill, which officially enshrines Anzac Day as `the national day to recognise and commemorate those who have served Australia in war and warlike conflicts'. I am delighted to say that this legislation has bipartisan support and I hope it will receive unanimous support from the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Although originally on 25 April 1916 it was intended to commemorate the Anzac landing at Gallipoli one year earlier, Anzac Day has become accepted as the national day for remembering the sufferings and the sacrifices of all Australians as a result of war. This bill will formalise that recognition—a worthwhile move, particularly as the world makes ready for the 50th anniversary of the end of the 1939-1945 conflict in Europe, Asia, Africa and the Middle East.

Anzac Day is unique in that it is a national day of commemoration based on what ultimately proved to be a military defeat. Some countries and some individuals may find that rather strange, but the reality is that this point undermines that this is a day of genuine reflection on our past. It is not merely some grandiose exercise to celebrate a military victory or to glorify war. It is about the losses and the sacrifices made by the people of this nation when they were called on to take up arms or to make some other contribution to restoring peace around the world.

It has never been about glory, whether on the part of individuals or on the part of the nation as a whole. Anzac Day is about the commemoration and remembrance of the sacrifices made by generations of Australians in defence of the nation and of our beliefs in democracy, and it is the commemoration of one of the major milestones in creating our national character.

Australia's history of involvement in overseas conflicts is decades older than the federation itself. The first military action seen by Australians in any organised fashion occurred in New Zealand in 1860 during the second Anglo-Maori war. About 2,500 soldiers and a Victorian ship fought in support of New Zealand regiments. This came 55 years before the Gallipoli landings. Those are the landings which many historians have described as the real forging of Australia's national identity.

If you look at the figures, it is rather incredible for such a small nation which has experienced only limited attacks on its own soil to have lost over 100,000 of its sons and daughters in war service, with some 225,000 wounded and 34,730 held as prisoners of war. During World War I more than 400,000 Australians enlisted—more than 10 per cent of the total population. More than 60,000 of those died and another 150,000 were wounded. This meant that virtually no family in the whole nation was unscarred by that conflict. These casualties were horrendous even on the scale suffered by many of the great military powers at that time, but they have deeply burned into the soul of our country, which was then so small and at that time was only beginning to find its feet as an independent nation.

There is a reflection of Australia's multicultural heritage in the fact that almost one-third of the personnel in our units in Gallipoli had originally come to this country as migrants. Migration has always been the backbone of Australia's development, and the fact that so many of our Anzacs were migrants is something which should be made better known to all Australians. To do so would be to ensure that the aims of this bill—the official creation of a national day of commemoration—would attract the interest and support of many of our migrant communities as well as those whose families have lived here for generations.

This bill is also another opportunity for the nation to recognise the contribution of our Aboriginal community in the service of the nation's defence and to promote the ideals of reconciliation through jointly celebrating Anzac Day.

Like most members of this chamber and the other place, I personally have been very struck by the solemnity, dignity and importance of Anzac Day to our communities. It is a source of great amazement to me that often at four or five o'clock in the morning hundreds of people of all ages—young and old—will get up to attend dawn services around this country, some with just a handful of people, some with thousands of people. Many of them—and increasingly so more recently—are wearing their fathers' medals on the opposite breast. The spirit which is present at those services has often been commented on by overseas visitors as something which amazes them.

In this bill we should also recognise the amazing contribution made by the diggers, not only as soldiers but, since their return, as members of the RSL. The RSL has done much for our community, not only in inspiring mateship but also in looking after the needy in our society and providing an ongoing spirit of comradeship. I think that is something we should recognise—indeed, we should shout it from the rooftops.

I am pleased that this bill is an example of how parliamentarians can work together to ensure something worth while for the community, despite the many pressures of the day-to-day political battles. This legislation is the result of direct cooperation between the government and the opposition, and has emerged from a flood of petitions from ex-service groups across the nation. It is a very sad reflection on the mind-set of our media that they have shown virtually no interest in this legislation, despite its overwhelming community support and the level of political cooperation behind its advancement.

This legislation is designed to achieve its stated purpose—to enshrine Anzac Day as a national day of commemoration. But I should point out that it in no way impinges on the Australia Day celebrations which occur on 26 January each year. The bill has been widely—and wrongly—interpreted by some groups as some kind of threat to Australia Day's place as our national day. It will do no such thing. It will do no more than officially recognise 25 April as our national day of commemoration.

This bill is meant to formally recognise the national significance of 25 April to all Australians—as a day to remember, a day to pay our respects to those who died, suffered or served in war. It should, once and for all, remove any thoughts that Anzac Day is simply an excuse for a public holiday or a long weekend.

All the things that go towards making the traditional Australian character—mateship, tenacity, a sardonic humour and a sense of a fair go—were forged on the battlefields of Gallipoli. The legendary Anzac spirit and Anzac Day itself are a representation of what this nation is about. It is certainly overdue that these great traditions be set into formal legislation. I commend this bill to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are also honoured to support this Anzac Day Bill to provide for Anzac Day to continue to be observed on 25 April each year and to declare Anzac Day as the national day of commemoration for the contribution of all those who served Australia, including those who died, in time of war and in warlike conflicts. It is particularly apt that this bill is being enacted this year, the year of Australia Remembers.

PARA.TAB: No-one can fail to be moved each Anzac Day when we see our veterans marching so proudly, and it is very pleasing to see the increasing number of young people attending Anzac Day services and, in many cases, actually taking part. It is fitting that in this special year we enshrine the celebration of Anzac Day on 25 April into legislation.

While we honour our veterans who served their country in time of war, and we especially remember the more than 100,000 Australians who made the supreme sacrifice and gave their lives in service overseas, we have to remember that we should not be glorifying the wars in which they served. War is pointless. The way to stop the killing of innocent civilians is not by the killing of more innocent civilians.

The men and women who serve in our military services, and those who have served in the past, have shown themselves to be courageous, committed, devoted and professional in their approach and they have the reputation of being amongst the best in the world. However, we should not aspire to see ourselves in any sense as a nation of warriors; we should be aspiring to be seen as a nation of peacekeepers.

While we honour our fighting forces, we should not forget those who have a conscientious objection to military service. The Democrats in the past have moved amendments to grant our defence personnel the right of conscientious objection to combat duties except in the time of attack or threatened attack on Australia. Many Australians, including some in our defence forces, have strong moral objections to service in overseas conflicts, and we believe that they should not be compelled to so serve in these cases.

We have also moved to require conscripts whose claims of conscientious objection have been upheld to perform community service. This would remove the supposed soft option of conscientious objection and is a far more equitable approach to ensure that all objectors still serve Australia during times of national crisis.

Thirdly, we propose that any deployment of Australian forces to participate in combat operations overseas must be approved by parliament, except during any actual attack or threatened attack on Australia. The government should not be able to unilaterally commit military personnel to combat in overseas operations. It is ridiculous that while parliament has the right to disallow conscription in the dire circumstances of a direct threat to Australia, it will not have control over a cabinet decision to risk Australian lives in an overseas conflict. Having said that, the Australian Democrats are proud to support this legislation, and we commend the government's initiative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Anzac Day Bill 1994, which will set aside 25 April each year as the national day of commemoration to recognise and commemorate the contribution of all Australians who serve this nation in times of war and warlike conflict. The impetus for this bill was a notice of motion by the honourable member for Melbourne Ports, Mr Clyde Holding, in the other place last year. As he rightly stated, the national importance of the commemoration of Anzac Day, which currently comes under state legislation, should more appropriately become a federal responsibility.

PARA.TAB: Every year sees a reduction in the ranks of those Australians who served as Anzacs in the First World War and also a thinning of the ranks of Second World War veterans who, on average, I now believe to be around 77 years of age. In the face of ever-dwindling numbers, it is important that this nation preserve for ever more, through the Anzac Day Bill, 25 April as the national day of commemoration for those who served and for those who made the ultimate sacrifice for this country.

As has been asserted before, the Australian nationhood was shaped through the Anzac experience at Gallipoli. It was the first time Australians had fought together as united Australians rather than as colonists. It came, however, at a huge cost in Australian lives. The fatally flawed Gallipoli campaign saw the death of 7,600 Australians and 2,500 New Zealanders. The rationale for this ill-conceived plan was to weaken Turkey by forcing a passage through the Dardanelles and bombarding Constantinople. As Manning Clark wrote, rather charitably:

SPEECH.PARA: It was a plan for romantics, a plan for those who believed a rich prize outweighed the suffering, cruelty and losses. It was a grand design of a swift end to the war in the Middle East that ended in a military disaster.
On 3 April 1915 the Australian and New Zealand forces of around 50,000 men, comprising the 1st, 2nd, 4th and 5th Divisions, departed Cairo for Alexandria and then the Dardanelles.

PARA.TAB: Before dawn on 25 April the advance party rowed for shore. The cove where it landed was enclosed by steep cliffs which were defended by massive Turkish firepower. From April to December the diggers valiantly hung on in the trenches as they continued their assault on the Dardanelles. Finally, after eight grim nightmare months, with a huge toll extracted in human life and suffering, the word finally came from London to abandon the campaign. Again, Manning Clark encapsulates it so well:

SPEECH.PARA: The soldiers were in part apotheosised by the ashes of defeat, for from that year, the landing at Gallipoli became Anzac Day. For some it symbolised the noblest aspirations of the people. For others it was the bond of those who had been through the fiery furnace and uplifted by it.

After the Gallipoli campaign the general staff moved the forces from Egypt to the western front in north-eastern France and Belgium for the remainder of the war. The first war saw a generation of young Australians perish. There has been enough written of that war, from the poetry of Wilfred Owen and Siegfried Sassoon to the memoirs of Albert Facey and most recently Robert Malloy, as testimony to its horrors to guard against its glorification. However, our war experiences will always be remembered and the brave Australians who served and those who paid the ultimate price should be forever honoured in our collective memories on our national day as provided for in this Anzac Day Bill.

PARA.TAB: As a grandson of an Anzac who rests in France, I am particularly proud to take part in this debate today. As Senator Woods mentioned, I was proud when my son marched in Anzac Day parades wearing his great grandfather's medals over a period of years when he was a student at Iona College. I support the bill on behalf of the National Party and the coalition.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank senators for their contributions. On behalf of the government I pay tribute to the initiator of the Anzac Day Bill, which came from a notice of motion moved by the Hon. Clyde Holding in the other place. I am the grandson of an Anzac. My grandfather landed at Anzac Cove on 25 April 1915, was severely wounded and was repatriated after only about 10 minutes of action. He was a founding member, as I understand it, of the RSL in South Australia. As do other senators, I see Anzac Day as being of particular significance, both in the broad sense for Australia and in the personal sense for one's families and one's own family history.

PARA.TAB: We have had a debate in this country now for some time about the republic, national identity and so on and about what day should be celebrated as the appropriate national day. At the moment it is 26 January, which celebrates the arrival of the First Fleet to establish the colony of New South Wales.

I think the debate is a healthy one at the moment and irrespective of the argument about the republic, on which most people know my view—I am a very strong advocate of an Australian republic—it may well be that if we are looking for a national day that unites Australia, Anzac Day may be a more appropriate day than 26 January, which celebrates the establishment of the colony of New South Wales rather than the establishment of the Australian nation—which, as we know, with Federation occurred on 1 January 2001. Minister Sciacca, in the House of Representatives, quoted an editorial—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was 1901.

—Thank you for making sure I get my dates correct. I thought I said the founding of the nation was on 1 January 1901. Mr Sciacca in the other place quoted an editorial that appeared shortly after Anzac Day. He quite rightly pointed out that the events of Anzac Day and the extraordinary sacrifice of the Australian soldiers there and subsequently in the First World War, the Second World War and in other places really defined Australia in many ways.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, this bill is appropriate in that we commemorate and establish Anzac Day as the national day of commemoration. It is also part of the debate that may lead others to think that Anzac Day should be the national day for Australia. I think that is a very legitimate suggestion by many people in Australia. As I say, as one who had a grandfather who was severely wounded on 25 April 1915, I may be a little prejudiced about that. But I still think it is a very valid suggestion. Of course, this bill is being supported by all sides of parliament. This is a move by the national parliament of Australia to introduce appropriate legislation to commemorate the day on which all of us in Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you also remove the holiday on 26 January?

—I do not think we will remove the holiday. Senator Watson, if you want to remove the holiday, you are a braver man than I, to put that proposal forward or even suggest it in passing. I think this is a very appropriate occasion. The government thanks those on all sides who made contributions. Whether or not Anzac Day is the national day in the future, its special significance in Australia will always be remembered. I hope, at some stage in the coming years, that I have an opportunity to remember one Anzac Day at Gallipoli. I understand that many Australians make the effort to be there on 25 April.

PARA.TAB: I am told that what is quite moving is the large number of young Australians who make the effort to get to Gallipoli on 25 April each year to commemorate Anzac Day. I think that is a sign that young Australians, as well, are understanding the identity of Australia and the contribution of Anzac Day to the Australian identity. I think those of us who have not made it there yet—I am one of them—certainly want to do so in the coming years. I commend the bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY CONTRIBUTORY SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 27 February, on motion by Senator Schacht:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge my contribution to the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill as a trustee of the Parliamentary Retiring Allowances Trust. The trustees were faced with the difficulty of a former member returning to parliament who had not, within the statutory time frame, entered into a contract with the trust as required under the act.

PARA.TAB: One solution could well have been the exercise of a trustee's discretion in arbitrarily extending the time frame but this would have the downside of being open to challenge. Therefore, the only open, honest and fair approach was by way of amendment to the principal act which effectively extends the discretionary period from six to 12 months—and this is what this bill purports to do.

The amendment will allow certain former members and senators who re-enter the parliament to repay lump sums paid under the principal act and to receive recognition of prior parliamentary service for future benefit purposes. The principal act actually provides that these members may enter contracts with the trust to repay the actual lump sum received within three years of re-entering parliament and the trust has discretion to offer contracts on such terms as it thinks fit. The current provision, prior to this amendment, allows the affected member to re-enter such a contract within three months of re-entering the parliament, with the trust having the discretion to extend this period to six months.

This bill extends the period during which the trust has a discretion to extend the contract from six to 12 months. Importantly, the proposed amendments in no way alter the basic design of the existing parliamentary superannuation scheme, have no financial impact and do not cost the taxpayer additional moneys. Under the circumstances, the Liberal-National party coalition supports the amendment bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill is another example of the inability of the present Labor government to negotiate treaties and other agreements and keep Australia's interests to the forefront.

PARA.TAB: It was unfortunate that it was the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, who dashed the Australian and New Zealand hopes of a removal of a major impediment to trans-Tasman investment to recognise New Zealand company franking credits. I remind the Senate that since 1988 committees have been continually looking at harmonisation.

It is unfortunate that we have not made more progress with CER especially when we are starting to talk about closer ties to the north under APEC. First, we must get our relationship with New Zealand right. I put this parliament and the people of Australia on notice that one of the first things the Liberal and National parties will do, on return to government, is to speed up the harmonisation process, not only of tax but of trade and all other aspects of our relationship with our closest neighbour, New Zealand.

This bill gives the force of law in Australia to a comprehensive double tax arrangement which was signed with New Zealand on 27 January 1995. The provisions of the agreement closely follow and correspond with those in Australia's other modern double tax agreements. It replaces an earlier agreement concluded in 1972 and reflects major tax reforms in both countries since then.

Naturally, the agreement ensures that all forms of income flowing between the two countries are taxed only once and provides for cooperation between the tax authorities to prevent tax evasion and it certainly clarifies certain trans-Tasman tax issues. It also provides for a clarification of which country has the tax rights over categories of trans-Tasman income flows. It updates the double tax agreement and closer cooperation between the two revenue authorities which is designed to enhance trade and investment opportunities and to protect both countries' revenue bases.

It is true that Australian companies investing in New Zealand have received a boost following the signing of what the government at the time referred to as a historic double tax agreement, because it did, I acknowledge, remove a number of costly barriers. But it is important to spell out to this Senate what the bill does not do. It does not deal with the vexed issue of sharing dividend imputation credits. The inability of Australian companies to use New Zealand tax credits and the New Zealand withholding tax on dividends paid back to Australia are major frustrations for Australian groups with trans-Tasman operations.

It is also opportune to remind the Senate of a recent statement by one of Australia's leading tax accountants from Price Waterhouse, Geoffrey Leeman, who said that it was ironic that Australia and New Zealand could not get mutual recognition of each other's tax credits, when Ireland and Finland had agreed to theirs. It makes a joke of our government's preaching internationalisation to business if it cannot negotiate completely open commercial relations with our nearest neighbour. That is in an environment when the government is talking about having closer relations under an APEC regime, which will create many more difficulties than a proper harmonisation with our closest neighbour, New Zealand.

The bill purports to clarify which country has taxing rights over various categories of trans-Tasman income and income flows. I suppose one issue that I should draw the Senate's attention to is fringe benefits tax. The fringe benefits tax regime we have in Australia is unique around the world and causes a lot of problems in terms of international tax treaties. But the new treaty does provide taxpayer relief from the double taxation of fringe benefits. The country with the sole or primary taxing right to the remuneration of the individual taxpayer associated with the fringe benefit will have the sole right to tax the fringe benefit.

For example, where an employee's assessable income is taxable in New Zealand, fringe benefits provided to that employee will, naturally, be taxable in New Zealand. Previously, such benefits were not taxable in New Zealand as fringe benefits although they may have been treated as ordinary income.

Other issues which are outlined and which I do not have the time to examine in detail are income from employment, dividends and trans-Tasman insurance business, interest, royalties, business profits and permanent establishments, capital gains, income from real property, substantial equipment and permanent establishments, pensions and annuities and permanent establishments and holdings in unit trusts, et cetera.

It is, however, important to highlight some of those aspects that affect dividends. In terms of withholding tax on dividends, Australia will reduce its rate of withholding tax on unfranked dividends paid by Australian resident companies to New Zealand residents from 30 per cent of the gross amount of dividends to 15 per cent. Franked dividends paid by Australian resident companies to New Zealand residents will continue to be exempt and trans-Tasman insurance business dividend withholding tax is limited to five per cent to reflect the five per cent branch profits tax equivalent to that which New Zealand imposes.

Perhaps of more significance in terms of the harmonisation which has happened in recent times is not only the result of this bill which is before us but also tax reform by the New Zealand government. We all know that the New Zealand government is very keen on promoting the liberalisation of trade and business in that country. It has removed a lot of red tape in New Zealand and, as a consequence, New Zealand business is thriving.

I point out the most recent initiative taken by the New Zealand government in relation to tax issues. The result of that initiative will be that Australian companies investing in New Zealand will now face significantly lower tax rates on dividends later in this year as a result of those particular reforms. For example, New Zealand non-resident withholding tax has effectively been removed for franked dividends. The initiative of the New Zealand government is not matched by Australia.

I acknowledge the Coopers Lybrand Sydney comment that `this New Zealand initiative does remove a huge obstacle that has been lying like a log across this motorway for years'. In fact, the proposals will have a dramatic impact on the profile of trans-Tasman investment and will force almost every Australian group with New Zealand operations to look at restructuring their particular financing arrangements. Many Australian based groups with profitable New Zealand subsidiaries will be able to bring profits back to Australia in the form of dividends with a more palatable overall tax cost even though, I must point out, mutual recognition of franking credits still has not been addressed.

As a result of this initiative from New Zealand, Australia will actually get millions of dollars through the New Zealand tax reform. It is providing initiatives which Australia is not matching. Therefore, the concept of harmonisation is pretty much one-sided.

I remind the Senate of a commitment made by John Hewson when he indicated that a Liberal-National coalition will certainly speed up the harmonisation concept and do everything that is reasonably possible to develop a common market between Australia and New Zealand. To that end he announced eight steps to improve CER and to enable that process to take place.

The bill before us was absolutely necessary in terms of an outdated agreement from 1972. I believe that we lost a great opportunity in the negotiations with New Zealand in not speeding up the harmonisation process and, as such, I think we have not done ourselves a great deal of service in trying to improve relationships between Australia and New Zealand. In many respects New Zealand is economically outstripping Australia's performance—and that is reflected in the dollar exchange rate movements in the respective countries. Australia has a lot to learn from New Zealand and I urge this government to speed up the harmonisation process. In the meantime, the Liberal-National Party coalition does support the steps that have been taken, albeit they are fairly inadequate in terms of what is really required.
