TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This is a continuation of the practice of this government to allow ministers to engage in whatever political benefit the government sees fit rather than meet parliamentary obligations. I would have thought the real question in relation to Senator Bolkus is: why could not Minister Bilney, for example, a South Australian minister, have met that obligation since the House of Representatives is not sitting? Why is it necessary for a Senate minister to do it, particularly in an area that has—
—Nothing to do with it.

—An area that has got nothing to do with his portfolio responsibilities. I might say in passing that I would have thought it would probably be more helpful for South Australian business if he stayed out of the state. What is the explanation for that? Why is it necessary for him to do it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Senator Bolkus is a cabinet minister and it was thought desirable, given the cooperative nature of this particular enterprise, which is a joint one, as I have said, between federal, state and local government aimed at assisting economic growth in Adelaide and surrounding regions—which I am interested to see Senator Hill contesting the utility and relevance of—for him to be present. He had given a longstanding commitment to be there. It was just one of those things that do from time to time compete with parliamentary obligations.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Could the minister also please explain why Senator McMullan needs to lead a trade delegation that coincides with a sitting of the House of Representatives and the Senate which has been scheduled for many months?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—That is a nonsensical suggestion. Senator McMullan is the trade minister of this country. He has extremely important obligations and very often it is very difficult to schedule these things in a way that you completely immunise yourself from parliamentary sittings. It has always been understood for ministers with external responsibilities—
—What's he doing in April?
—He is going on another trip in April; in fact, another two trips I think—and so he should. He does a damn sight more for this country than you would ever be able to do, Senator Macdonald.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask whether the minister is aware that, according to the latest Reuters survey, 21 of the 25 major Australian economists surveyed believe that interest rates will rise in April—just after the New South Wales election? Nineteen of them expect the next rate hike to be between three-quarters of a per cent and one per cent, with many believing that official rates could rise from 7 1/2 per cent to 10 per cent in the second half of this year. I ask the minister for the third day in a row: will he now categorically rule out an interest rate rise between the New South Wales election and the May budget?

—I have got absolutely nothing to add to what I have said on innumerable previous occasions about this. No government can ever rule out the need to keep a careful eye on the economy and take the steps from time to time that may be necessary to keep the economy moving at a sustainable rate without stop start, without the kind of boom crash cycle that we have had in the past. The whole idea is to get the—
—Your boom crash!

—No, it has been the case in the past. And that is the whole point of interest rate adjustments—to ensure that that will not occur. As I have said on innumerable occasions, we hope very much that interest rate adjustments will not be necessary and that such remaining economic management functions as do need to be performed in slowing down the economy a bit and simultaneously boosting domestic savings can be done through fiscal policy, can be done through the budget. That is what we are hoping.

PARA.TAB: The overall experience in the economy at the moment suggests that it is, in fact, slowing down. We will not be in a position to make a really firm judgment about the extent of that until we get the next round of national accounts figures which will come along, I think, in early April. This government will continue to behave with absolute responsibility. We reject absolutely any suggestion that our responses on these matters are in any way governed by transient political consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the third day in a row, the minister has failed to rule out a rate increase. I draw that to the Senate's attention. Why should anyone, anyway, believe Senator Gareth Evans's or Mr Keating's assurances that interest rates are unlikely to rise after May when ABARE, which is one of the government's own economic advisers, is saying that further increases of about 1 1/2 per cent this year and another one per cent next year are likely to be required in order to control significant inflationary pressures which, I would add, are occurring simply because of the government's economic incompetence?

—There are as many opinions on these things as there are professional economists in existence, including in government circles and government agencies. The government will be making the decisions on these matters based on the best available balance of advice from the sources available to us from multiple directions and taking into account, particularly of course as I have said, up-to-date, current information about the overall condition of the economy.

PARA.TAB: We cannot behave other than with absolute consistency and with absolute responsibility. We are very conscious of the need to keep this economy moving at a sustainable pace, at the same time generating the kinds of savings returns and so on that are necessary to help us address the current account deficit and such problems as we have while maintaining the fantastic phenomenal record that we have put into place so far as employment regeneration and creation is concerned, so far as investment momentum is concerned and so far as low inflation maintenance is concerned. This is an excellent shape for the economy to be in. We have got nothing whatsoever to apologise for. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. The minister would be aware of serious concern within the Aboriginal community about the mishandling of legally and culturally sensitive documents concerning the Hindmarsh Island case. What can the government do to respond to Aboriginal concerns and ensure appropriate respect for Aboriginal cultural matters?

—I am certainly aware of the intense concern among the Ngarrindjeri women about this issue. Why would they not be concerned? Why has it come up again? Why? It is because yesterday, the deputy leader of this so-called alternative government said publicly, in defending Mr McLachlan, that what he did was a technical issue. In fact, Mr Costello said that Mr McLachlan should be back on the front bench—sorry about that, Rod, but that is what your deputy leader said yesterday.

PARA.TAB: Not surprisingly, Sandra Saunders, the Director of the Aboriginal Legal Rights Movement in South Australia, has called upon Mr Howard, the leader of this so-called alternative government, to condemn his deputy. But he will not, of course. It is not going to be possible—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why should he?

—I will tell you why he should, Senator Alston. I am glad that you—a lawyer as you are and defender of civil rights and protector of CoT case victims, as you were yesterday—are defending, rightly, the plundering of people's civil liberties. Well how about their mail, Senator Alston?

PARA.TAB: This has been dismissed as a technical issue and a sideshow—your deputy leader said that. But what actually happened? I remind you—this is why this is of concern to every Australian, not just Aboriginal women—that the office of the member for Barker, Ian McLachlan, with his subsequent approval, opened a box of documents that they knew did not belong to them, plundered those documents, photocopied them and, with Mr McLachlan's assent, circulated them all over the place, including to the lawyers representing the parties in the case.

If you strip away all the cultural and legal considerations involved—I am not suggesting that you do—you have here a clear case of plundering someone else's mail, and that has been condoned and supported by the Leader of the Opposition, with the deputy leader saying yesterday it was a technical issue and that Mr McLachlan should be back on the front bench. Why is this action of illegally plundering someone else's mail, photocopying it and distributing it all over the place, being supported by someone who wants to be Prime Minister of Australia? I will tell you why.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order relating to relevance. Senator Collins would know what question he wanted asked, and the question was: what can the government do to alleviate certain concerns. We have had three minutes of diatribe, attacking the Deputy Leader of the Opposition—nothing whatsoever to do with the question. I would have thought, Mr President, that you were in a position to judge that from where you sit. You have had almost three minutes of this and you ought to bring the minister to order.

—Mr President, on the point of order, what the government is doing today is what we have been doing for several weeks, and that is calling on the Leader of the Opposition and the deputy leader to condemn the actions of a pretend minister, a shadow minister, in plundering someone else's mail. That is the relevance. The government is again calling on the Leader of the Opposition to publicly apologise for this action and to condemn it.
—Order! I do not think there is any substance to the point of order but I ask the minister to come to the point of the question.

—Mr President, the point of the question is that we are again calling on the Leader of the Opposition to publicly condemn Mr McLachlan, not only for plundering someone else's mail but also for knowingly photocopying it and spreading it all over the place, and to condemn the deputy leader for saying yesterday that plundering someone else's mail is a technical issue and a sideshow and we should not be worried about it. Why aren't they apologising?

PARA.TAB: The reason is quite simple. The Leader of the Opposition and the deputy leader were party to a strategy two weeks ago that blew up in their faces, and that was when Mr McLachlan got up in the federal parliament, accusing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs of being responsible for faults with mail security, while knowing that his, Mr McLachlan's, office had distributed this stuff all over the map.

The other strange thing about this is that while the Leader of the Opposition has publicly revealed that he knew about it 10 days before it happened, the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs said she did not know about it until it was tabled in parliament. Not only did Mr McLachlan ignore her, so did the Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise again on a point of order of relevance. The minister is not attempting to answer the question that he was asked. The hypocrisy of those opposite is absolutely incredible. They have a Prime Minister who lies to the Australian people, who accuses Mr Howard of a secret deal—
—Order! Come to the point of order. You are not to debate the question.
—Fewer double standards and less hypocrisy and the minister might have more justification for standing up. If he is going to stand up, he ought to answer the question that has been asked.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—The reason for our concern is that you people want to be the next government of Australia and I think it is important that if you are going to be in charge of Australia Post—if Mr Howard and Mr Costello are going to run Australia Post—it is about time—

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. On the issue of relevance and consistency, the minister might be able to tell us whether the Prime Minister ever apologised to the Australian people for lying to them about the l-a-w tax cuts at the last election.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I conclude by saying once again that it is a horrifying prospect to have Mr Howard and Mr Costello running Australia Post. I call on both of them again to condemn the actions of plundering someone else's mail.(Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. On this national day of protest by students against Labor's broken promises on education funding and fees in higher education, I remind the minister that the NUS president, John Graham, has said, `The government has lied to undergraduate students claiming they would be protected from up-front fees.' Remembering that the government conned student unions into a $100,000 campaign in its support at the last election, I ask the minister: why did the government lie to students, and how does the government justify its broken promises to students?

—It will be a national issue today, but I cannot remember every goddamn thing that is happening. This brief is about education funding in Queensland; that is not much use to me. I think I had better take that question on notice, Mr President. Sorry, I am looking at the wrong one. I will get the right one.
—Have you got the right brief?

—Well, I don't like just rabbiting on in this place. Far too much of that happens anyway. I take the view that it is a proper exercise of my responsibility to open my mouth only when I have something to say. Now I do have something to say, I am happy to say it.

PARA.TAB: During our term in office, we have overseen a dramatic expansion in the number of Commonwealth funded higher education places. Between 1983 and 1993, the number of students in higher education has grown by over 65 per cent, from nearly 350,000 in 1983 to over 575,000 last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many missed out?

—You don't like that information? You are going to have to live with it and lump it because it is true. In response to university wishes, the government has given institutions greater flexibility and responsibility in managing their financial affairs, including allowing the charging of fees for postgraduate students not receiving scholarships and allowing fees for non-award and professional extension courses. Universities have been responding to this increased flexibility in a whole variety of different ways.

PARA.TAB: An external review found that almost all research postgraduate courses were free of fees and that 75 per cent of postgraduate course work degrees also did not attract fees and were covered by the HECS income contingent loan scheme. Women were found to have increased their share of enrolments in both fee paying and non-fee paying courses. So claims that the government is allowing universities to charge undergraduate fees are quite unfounded. Australian undergraduate students who gain a place at a public institution cannot be charged tuition fees. In 1993 the number of non-award students was equivalent to just over one per cent of all students. I think those figures and that information demonstrate that any protesting going on about inconsistent fees, policies and so on around the place is utterly unfounded and without justification.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister is obviously unaware that, in fact, universities are charging fees to undergraduate students through commercial fronts—he has turned a blind eye to it. Minister, how do you justify the 16 per cent reduction in Commonwealth funding per student under your government? How do you therefore justify the consequent drop in the quality of education, including overcrowded classes, classes of up to 500 students, a tutorial system that has broken down because tutors can no longer be afforded and libraries that cannot cope? How do you justify this drop in the quality of education about which Australian students are protesting all over Australia today?

—I do not accept the premises of that question. I would not buy a used statistic from this leader. I certainly would not accept the basis on which that question was asked. If I have anything to add on the basis of further information, I will be happy to do so at a later stage.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. On 16 February in an estimates hearing I asked whether the Department of Employment, Education and Training had any contingency plans to deal with the possibility of a university charging full fees for its own undergraduate degrees. The department answered then that universities did not have that capacity. Now that we have been publicly given an example of the University of Western Sydney charging $55,000 for a first degree, what will the government do?

—The question from Senator Bell was at least asked in a specific way, unlike the previous question from the Leader of the Opposition to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, which was convoluted and confusing. I appreciate the fact that Senator Bell has raised this issue in the estimates committee; as a result, I am able to give him information about the specific case he raises.

PARA.TAB: The Department of Employment, Education and Training received a proposal dated 22 December 1994 from the University of Western Sydney for the funding of a course development cost for a fee-paying Bachelor of Aviation degree. Since then, the department has sought further information from the university and has sought legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department through its legal branch regarding the proposed arrangements. It has not yet received advice on that. No decision has been made to fund the proposal; a decision will not be made until the legal advice has been received.

I want to reiterate that it is government policy that public universities do not charge up-front tuition fees to students undertaking undergraduate courses. There is no proposal to change that policy. In October of last year, the Labor Party, at its 1994 national conference, reaffirmed its opposition to charging up-front tuition fees to Australian students undertaking undergraduate courses at universities.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the Liberals' policy?

—We know what it is. Whenever they bumble one, it is about up-front fees right across the board. Every undergraduate would be charged thousands and thousands of dollars a year in up-front fees. The Liberals may have dropped Fightback but, apparently, there has been no drop of that iniquitous policy.

PARA.TAB: It is a condition of receipt of Commonwealth funding under the Higher Education Funding Act that public universities do not charge up-front tuition fees for courses leading to an undergraduate award. Under this act, it is possible for separate companies owned or controlled by public universities to charge tuition fees for undergraduate level courses. This is clear from legal advice received by the department. However, the company must not act as an agent of the parent institution, and it can offer only its own awards. Such awards are not awards of the parent university but are awards of the separate entity. That is the government policy which has been made quite clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know how it works, do you?
—We have made it very clear that you cannot—
—You don't understand what you are saying.

—You may not be able to understand it, Senator Hill. You do not understand it. You did not understand it when you asked the question of Senator Evans. You do not understand the government policy, which is quite clear—that a subsidiary company cannot offer an award, a degree, of the parent institution. That is made quite clear. I have also had to make it quite clear to you, Senator Hill—and I thank Senator Bell for his question on this, which was at least to the point—that we are seeking legal advice to make sure that no university gets around the rules of the government policy. Until we get that advice back from the Attorney-General's Department, that policy will stand. If advice comes back which says that there is a way around it, the government will respond to ensure that the government's policy—
—All these students around Australia have got it wrong, have they, Schachty?
—I know that you are the shadow minister for education, but you clearly do not understand—
—Order! Senator Schacht, address your comments through the chair please.
—Thank you, Mr President. Unfortunately, Senator Hill does not understand the issue. We have made it clear that they cannot get an award for an up-front tuition fee. (Time expired)

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for confirming that the awards granted by the commercial companies or the other arms of the universities would be useless in being translated towards a degree. But I am concerned about the preparedness of the government to deal with the conflict in its policies regarding credit transfer or recognition of prior learning. One would imagine that universities would be hoping to be able to reach a situation where they could recognise these other awards. Either the universities are manipulating the ministerial guidelines to collect cash, or the legislation which prevents them from doing that is useless. I want to know from the minister what contingency plans the government has in the event that universities have to recognise the awards made by those commercial fronts.

—Very simply, the eventuality is that we await the legal advice from AG's, which is the proper process to take. When we get that legal advice, we will then be able to make that available to the Senate and to the estimates committee. But that in no way changes the government's policy that we oppose up-front tuition fees being charged for undergraduate courses.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and relates to international instruments generally. Specifically, I ask the minister: is he able to inform the Senate as to the position which the Australian delegation will be taking at the forthcoming Berlin conference of the parties to the framework convention on climate change? Will the government consider incorporating opposition policy prescriptions on international environmental objectives in deciding the Australian priorities for the conference?

—The government has consistently taken the view that the present commitments in the framework convention on climate change are inadequate. Quite apart from the question of the adequacy of the present implied commitments for developed countries up to the year 2000, there are no obligations in the convention—expressed or implied—reaching beyond the year 2000. There are no obligations upon developing countries to contribute to the solution to this problem, although there is increasing concern about the extent of the contribution they are now making to the problem. Generally speaking, the convention as it stands will not achieve the objectives we all to want to see of stabilisation of greenhouse gas concentrations in the longer term.

PARA.TAB: The main object of this first meeting of the parties in Berlin is to establish an acceptable negotiating mandate for further commitments under the convention. Australia's position is that no such mandate would be acceptable until it reaches beyond the developed countries to include all countries contributing to the problem. There are a number of ways in detail that we will be pursuing that objective.

A further important negotiating objective is to establish a workable process for joint implementation of commitments; in particular, one that would allow developed and developing countries to work together in the common good. Overall, we will be seeking outcomes that move the big problem solving effort forward, while at the same time not prejudicing our own economic trade and foreign policy interests.

Australia's effectiveness and credibility at this meeting will very much depend on our known commitment to solving environmental problems—especially those that are insoluble by any one country acting alone—through common international action. Crucial to our environment protection policy has been our participation in and membership of a range of treaties, including not only the present one but also biodiversity, ozone, wetlands, hazardous wastes, world heritage and treaties on endangered species. All of those are absolutely fundamental to our effort, to our effectiveness, to our credibility.

If Australia were to refuse to use the external affairs power given by the constitution, we would be effectively depriving ourselves of the capacity to play our part and, therefore, affecting our capacity to achieve outcomes in any one of the areas that are important. Yet this is exactly what the newly appointed shadow minister for the environment, Senator Kemp, is advocating—the bloke who on his first outing last night as environment spokesman was given a minus 10 by the ACT environment groups. For as long as I can remember, the opposition spokesman has been a strident critic of the government's use of the external affairs power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order on the issue of relevance. This is not a debate about opposition policy. This minister is responsible for a portfolio and we are very interested in hearing how he is going to administer his responsibilities, but it is not his place to be debating opposition policy.

—On the point of order, Mr President: I was expressly asked by Senator Loosley—I was listening very carefully to his question—about the extent to which I would be taking into account opposition policy on international treaties and international environmental obligations. I was expressly asked, and I am telling you why we will not.
—The answer is in order.
—Thank you, Mr President, I am indebted to you. For as long as I can remember, Senator Kemp, the new spokesman, has been a strident critic—
—What did you say to him yesterday?

—I thought he was statesmanlike yesterday and I think he is statesmanlike today. Senator Kemp has been a strident critic of the government's external affairs power over a whole range of areas, including environmental obligations, consistently reiterating the specious argument about Australian sovereignty. What he espouses, in effect, is environmental isolation from Australia—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order on relevance. The question did not relate to Senator Kemp at all. It is totally out of order. Even if Senator Evans wrote the question, he is answering the wrong question now apparently. Mr President, it is for you to decide whether the answer is relevant to the question that was asked. I put to you that there was no invitation in the question to start talking about the attitude of Senator Kemp. You should instruct this minister to answer the questions as asked.
—I am delighted to hear Senator Hill's concession that Senator Kemp's position is utterly irrelevant to the opposition's policy. If that is the case, that has made our point.
—I have already ruled that the answer was in order because it referred to the question that was asked precisely, and that is still my ruling. Senator Evans, do you want to complete that?

—Yes. If you have, as your environmental spokesman, someone whose attitude to environmental treaties is that they are inappropriate as a vehicle for policy formulation and for policy commitment, and if you appoint some ideologue who wants to leave these things to the states, which in practice means leaving them to bodies which will not make it happen at all, you are behaving in a fundamentally irresponsible way. The basic point I conclude on is simply this: Caligula's appointment of his horse as Roman consul was a triumphant act of enlightened statesmanship compared with John Howard's appointment of Senator Kemp to hold this particular crucially sensitive portfolio.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it true that the candidature of Mr Jim McKenzie, who is running under the banner of the no more Asian migration party in the marginal seat of Camden, has been organised and partly paid for by the New South Wales Labor Party? Could you explain why the no more Asian migration party candidate and your ALP candidate are swapping preferences on Saturday? Is it true that it is because of a deal struck at a meeting recently at the Sefton golf club, which included Laurie Brereton—there is that name again—Laurie Ferguson and a former state MP, Bill Loverley? Does this ALP government condone its senior ministers assisting and organising anti-Asian candidates?
—I do not believe that question relates to the minister's responsibilities, but I will leave it to the minister to judge whether he wants to answer that or not.

—I will answer it very briefly by saying I have no knowledge whatsoever of the particular alleged arrangement to which Senator Tierney is referring. I would not accept any information from Senator Tierney at face value. I would, of course, condemn anything which amounted to express or implied support for that particular policy. There are all sorts of ways in which preference arrangements can be struck to do with the flow of the ticket and so on—that may be taken as constituting support, but does not in practice amount to that.

PARA.TAB: In practice, I do not know what the circumstances of that are. I do not know whether there is any foundation for it. All I do know is that the only prominent Australian politician who has ever put a position in recent years on the public record about Asian immigration is your present leader, who ought to be absolutely ashamed of himself for the position that he took back in 1988 which set in train, in a very calculated and deliberate way at the highest policy levels within the party, an allegedly responsible mainstream Australian party, a position which was utterly out of tune with the ethics, the values and the interests of this country at this stage of the 20th century.

If you have got the values associated with a 1950s suburban solicitor behind a white picket fence with an F.J. Holden, you have not got the sorts of values that are relevant to this country in this day and age. You are the ones who ought to be ashamed for the policy position you took on that issue. I am very surprised indeed that you should want to raise that issue again, given the track record that you have got to defend of high level commitment to that particular absolutely indefensible, unpalatable and intolerable policy position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister: if your values are the correct values, could you explain why your ALP candidate and the no more Asian immigration candidate are swapping preferences one-two, two-one on the ballot paper on Saturday?
—I do not accept at face value any allegation of that kind that Senator Tierney makes. There has been enough evidence of dirty tricks.
—There's the ballot paper. One-two, two-one!

—You are the mob that is responsible for push polling. You are the mob that in New South Wales has a junior member of someone's staff threatening people in shops for holding ALP posters up, and you have the indecency to talk about ethics in the conduct of elections. You are a bunch of disgraceful hypocrites on that subject, as with everything else.
—Order! Senator Evans, you will withdraw that comment, please.
—Which one, Mr President?
—You used the word `hypocrites'. It is unparliamentary and I ask you to withdraw it.
—Which one?
—Hypocrites.
—I withdraw it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Will the minister advise the Senate of the outcome of the investigation by the Australian Federal Police into the allegations by the Liberal Party that the Australian Electoral Commission had included ALP election material with electoral information that the Electoral Commission had sent to electors in the seat of Canberra for this Saturday's by-election. Further, given the prominence of the apparent dirty tricks which have been coming to light in recent weeks, can the Commonwealth Electoral Act be constructed to safeguard democratic principles and protect voters from unethical conduct?

—It is true that the campaign director for the Liberal Party in Canberra made an allegation that the Electoral Commission had mailed out Labor Party propaganda in normal Electoral Commission mail-outs. I think most people in this chamber with experience of dealing with the Electoral Commission would know that is patent nonsense. Of courses it is nonsense, but we had to put the matter in the hands of the Federal Police because it was a serious charge. On Tuesday, 21 March the Federal Police reported back to government there was absolutely no evidence whatsoever to sustain this particular charge. Of course the effect was that the Liberal Party was able to obtain a few days cheap publicity. We know the motive for that. The motive for that was to cast around to find some distracter from the disgraceful push polling tactics the Liberal Party has adopted in this particular by-election.

PARA.TAB: The implication by the Liberal Party that the Electoral Commission would involve itself in this sort of behaviour is in line with the clear pattern of behaviour by the Liberal Party in perverse poll tactics adopted in the Canberra by-election and elsewhere. One of the things that it does is divert the attention of the Electoral Commission and others from the proper course of their duties.

The Electoral Commission has many things on its plate. For instance, it has to investigate how the $100,000 and $50,000 donations from shelf companies from Hong Kong and Singapore related to Gerard Industries happened to find their way into Liberal Party coffers. The commission should not be distracted from the investigation as to whether there was some coincidence between those donations from those shelf companies and certain contracts with the person who arranged those donations to the Liberal Party to be entered into with the state government of South Australia.

No doubt the Electoral Commission has to put up with investigations as to various apparatchiks from the New South Wales branch trying to threaten pizza parlour owners because they happen to put up a sign in their backyard. Maybe the Electoral Commission has to follow up other sorts of false claims from Senator Tierney about all sorts of invented deals and preference swaps. That is what the Electoral Commission probably has to do, but it is not entitled to have to bear a cheap accusation that it mailed out Labor Party propaganda.

What a brilliant tactic it would be from the Labor Party or Liberal Party to sneak some propaganda into Electoral Commission mail-outs! What possible use would that be for a political party? Yet, it did not stop the campaign director of the Liberal Party raising these matters publicly. This could be somewhat ameliorated if we had an apology for raising the false accusation, but of course we do not. It served its purpose as a distracter to try to cover up the Liberal Party's own dirty polling tactics which it has employed very disgracefully in the last four weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask the minister to table the police report to which he has referred in the light of the fact that the explanation which he just gave is inconsistent with what was put on the public record two days ago, which was that some of those who complained—who were not from the Liberal Party—may have been confused. Minister, that is very different from what you said today, so put the report on the table and let the public be the judge of who is telling the truth.
—Order! Senator Hill, you are not debating the point. You have asked for the document to be tabled. It is up to the minister whether or not he wants to do that.

—First of all, I did not quote from the document. I said `the Federal Police reported'. If the Minister for Justice sees fit, he may well release it. I have not had a chance to ask him. I did not quote from the police report.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woods Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Throughout the launch of the New South Wales Labor Party's forestry policy, Mr Carr referred to the roles of the Commonwealth government and various union leaders. One of these union leaders, Gavin Hillier, said on Radio National on 19 March:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . we had trucks running over picket lines. We used to follow them home, mate, and find out where they lived and when they want to make love to their wife before they go to Melbourne, that was the time we slipped in and you broke windscreens, too, because windscreens and tyres you don't get insurance for . . .
Every tyre's worth two thousand dollars to them. We had to hit them and hit them hard . . .
I'm telling you now . . . we told those contractors, you behave your (beeeep) selves or the same thing'll happen.
I ask the minister: does your government condone the violence, sabotage and intimidation boasted of by Mr Hillier?

TALK.START.PARA: —Everybody in this chamber knows that the government and the Labor Party have never condoned violence or intimidation—never—and never will. That is a perfect example of the fact that we don't.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ian Macdonald interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You would, you thug!
—Senator Collins, will you withdraw that.

—I reject the assertion that one of my colleagues just made that as Minister for Primary Industries and Energy I would want to spray the Flying Fruit Fly Circus! I actually concur with Senator Bourne; it is a national treasure. I must say in relation to the brief that I have been given by the Minister for Communications and the Arts that there has been a very significant amount of support given to the Flying Fruit Fly Circus.

PARA.TAB: Since 1984 the Commonwealth government has provided over $1 million to enable the Flying Fruit Fly Circus to establish itself. Within the communication and arts portfolio, the Australia Council has supported the circus since its establishment in 1979. The Australia Council currently provides a multi-year grant of $90,000 a year. This is more than twice the level of support offered to any other company in the youth arts program.

In addition, the circus is eligible for support for touring costs through the Playing Australia program. An application for a grant for tours to Brisbane and Sydney will be considered by the Playing Australia committee at its next meeting in early April. The company is also eligible for financial assistance through the department's new Festivals Australia program to support the touring of companies to regional festivals.

The majority of the Commonwealth's funding to the circus has been through the Department of Employment, Education and Training in recognition of the training services provided by the company. This has involved grants of up to $130,000 a year through the projects of national significance program. These funds were provided over the past 10 years as seed funding to meet the costs of the training and administrative staff of the circus. As seed funding obviously has a limited life, since 1993 the company has been aware that funding from this program would be phased out.

The circus has discussed this change of funding with the government. The Minister for Communications and the Arts, Mr Lee, met with the artistic director of the circus, Mr Charles Parkinson, last week to discuss future funding of the company. The Australia Council convened a meeting at which a number of options were canvassed which provided opportunities for additional support for the circus. These are also being currently pursued. As an established company, the circus now has access to other government programs such as those listed above, as well as seeking corporate and other sponsorships which an organisation of this nature deserves.

The circus is an annex of the Wodonga government high school. As a regional company and training provider, it also receives some support from the New South Wales and Victorian governments and the Wodonga Council. In this regard I will ensure that Senator Bourne's question is brought to the attention of the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training to see if there are other possible arrangements in addition to the ones that are currently under way for additional funding for the circus.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Health Funding in New South Wales

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. The minister's attention would have been drawn today to claims by the New South Wales health minister that New South Wales is not receiving $300 million in funding that it should be receiving from the Commonwealth and it has also been repeated in a National Party television ad for the election. How correct is this claim?

—I thank the senator for this question. The first and most important thing to say is that it is absolutely not true. I have seen the claims by Minister Phillips and I have been made aware of the advertisement—I do not think I have seen it. Both of those claims that the Commonwealth government is short-changing New South Wales health by $300 million are absolutely untrue. They are simply election lies by John Fahey's government and they are part of the dirty tricks in the run-up to this election.

PARA.TAB: It is very important to put the funding facts on the record. Commonwealth health funding to New South Wales has increased by more than $2 billion since 1988-89. Commonwealth funding to New South Wales for hospitals is also increasing—it has been for years—and will continue to increase under the terms of the Medicare agreements.

It is true that there have been cuts in health and hospital funding in New South Wales, but those cuts are entirely from the New South Wales government. They are cuts by the Fahey government; they are not cuts at all by the Commonwealth government. Since 1988-89 the Greiner-Fahey government has cut health funding by 0.4 per cent in real terms and New South Wales government funding for hospitals has been slashed too. In 1988-89 New South Wales spent $1.2 billion, while in 1993-94 it spent only $1 billion. In real terms, this is a drop of more than a quarter of a billion dollars to New South Wales hospitals by the New South Wales government.

Over the same period, the Commonwealth hospital funding to all states, including New South Wales, has been growing. In 1988-89 the Commonwealth provided just over $3 billion. These outlays have been steadily increased over each year to $4.45 billion in 1993-94. In real terms, this is an increase of more than three quarters of a billion dollars—over $752 million. Commonwealth increases, state decreases: they are the facts in New South Wales. During the 1994-95 financial year, the Commonwealth will increase funding to New South Wales hospitals by $80 million—an almost six per cent increase in Commonwealth funding for 1993-94.
Senator Herron interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures I have just put on the record have been jointly agreed by the Commonwealth and the New South Wales health department. If Mr Fahey wants to go to the electorate and say those figures are untrue, then he himself is duding his own Public Service. He is calling into question the integrity of New South Wales public servants. Those claims, as I have just said, are absolutely false. They are another example of the dishonesty of the coalition.

—Senator Herron interjected asking whether I was clear about these figures. For the record, I table the little graph that shows the increase in Commonwealth funding on the top line and the decrease in New South Wales funding on the bottom line, the sources from which those figures are drawn and the words of the New South Wales advertisement. There is no truth in those claims at all. The facts are that the Commonwealth has increased its money to New South Wales. The New South Wales government is the one which has cut $300 million from the people in New South Wales.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Labor Party: New South Wales Branch

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

—I am happy to read the lot, if you want me to. The last paragraph reads:

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Sydney, 22 March 1995: The Commonwealth Bank of Australia has sought and received the authority of its customer, the NSW Branch of the ALP, to make a statement in response to Senator Baume's allegations regarding financial arrangements with the Bank:

"The NSW Branch of the ALP has longstanding and current borrowing arrangements with the Commonwealth Bank. The Branch is meeting its obligations to the Bank under arrangements that were negotiated in a commercial manner and include a commercial rate of interest.
The Bank has received no approaches from either the Commonwealth Government or the national body of the ALP in relation to the funding of the New South Wales election campaign".

Senator Baume's allegation that the Bank has extended preferential treatment for political reasons is absolutely untrue and a matter of great concern to the Bank, which relies on commercial dealings in good faith with all its customers.
LYNDALL DEAVES ON "PM" ABC RADIO—22 MARCH 1995
SUBJECTS: State ALP Commonwealth Bank account, Coalition allegations

THOMPSON: Well, Barry Jones didn't help things along in the NSW election for his Labor colleagues last weekend, by speculating about a possible Federal intervention in the NSW branch of the ALP because of its debt problems. Now allegations have been raised in the Senate by the Coalition, that the Labor Party is getting preferential treatment from the Commonwealth Bank to help with the NSW election campaign. But in a statement released last night, the Commonwealth Bank says the NSW branch of the ALP is meeting its debt obligations, under arrangements that were negotiated in a commercial manner—including a commercial interest rate. Well, to talk about this now, joining me is the Commonwealth Bank's chief manager of Group Communications, Lyndall Deaves. Good morning.
THOMPSON: What is the Bank saying about these claims that the Commonwealth is giving preferential treatment to the ALP?

DEAVES: We've said the allegation that was made yesterday is absolutely untrue. It's a matter of great concern to us, because obviously we rely on commercial dealings in good faith with all our customers—and that's the approach we've taken.
THOMPSON: Has the Bank received any approaches from either the Federal Government or the National ALP, that is the Party structure in relation to funding the NSW campaign?
DEAVES: No, we've had no approaches at all.
THOMPSON: Any approaches from the NSW ALP?
DEAVES: No, not for funding of their election campaign.
THOMPSON: So, the overdraft or the debt—you might explain, is it an overdraft or is it a mortgage the ALP holds?

DEAVES: My problem as you would understand, is that I'm bound by the duty of banker and customer confidentiality. So, there's a limit to what I can obviously say. Our customer does know that we are prepared to say that obviously they are a customer of the Bank, and do have longstanding and current borrowing arrangements with the Bank, and that the branch is meeting its obligation, as you said, under arrangements that were negotiated on a commercial basis and at a commercial rate.
THOMPSON: Can you say whether the loan arrangement with the ALP has been extended for the NSW election?
DEAVES: No, it certainly hasn't been—so we haven't assisted and we haven't been approached to assist with the funding for the campaign.

THOMPSON: In the Senate, Senator Michael Baume says that the rate of interest on the $6 million mortgage held by the ALP is $10,000 a week—working out to be $520,000 a year or about 9%. That certainly seems to be less than the commercial rate of interest.

DEAVES: Well, unless you knew the way it was negotiated and the state of the debt, it would not be possible for you to draw that inference. They are paying a commercial rate and that's all we're prepared to say.
THOMPSON: So the ALP has been actively negotiating its mortgage situation or its debt situation with the Commonwealth Bank?

DEAVES: The State ALP would be like any customer, they would constantly be looking at their borrowings from the Bank, looking at rates—and I think that's a prudent practice that any business or anybody who is borrowing would adopt. It's been nothing more than that.
THOMPSON: Has the Bank threatened a notice of foreclosure on the ALP's debt?
THOMPSON: It's been claimed that essentially the ALP is in technical default on its loan. Is that so?

DEAVES: Well, if we've said they are meeting commercial obligations, then I don't see how you could draw that inference. It's just that. They are meeting a commercially negotiated arrangement at a commercial rate of interest. Really, we just wanted to put paid to some of the allegations that were being raised yesterday, to make clear the position. But really beyond that, it's probably best to talk to the State ALP.
THOMPSON: Have you, that is the Commonwealth Bank, have you had consultations or discussions with any of the Coalition Members about these claims?
DEAVES: No, not that I'm aware of. I'm not aware that we've been either approached or aware of any discussions with the Coalition on this.
THOMPSON: Can you say in general, is there any substance in the claims being made by the Coalition about preferential treatment?

DEAVES: It's absolutely untrue. There is no preferential treatment here. It's not in our interests, it's not in the interests of our customer. We rely on commercial dealings in good faith—that underpins prudent management of the Bank—and that's the way we like to conduct our business, and it's certainly the way we've been conducting it with the State ALP.
THOMPSON: Has the ALP's account been transferred to the Group Credit Control section of the Bank, which is a section which usually deals with potentially bad debts?

DEAVES: We have lending specialists, and from time to time various accounts will go to the lending specialists area—so that's really nothing to get excited about. I think somebody's drawn the wrong conclusion from that.
THOMPSON: So it has been handed over to the Credit Control section?

DEAVES: They're just an area of lending specialists. From time to time various borrowers are looked after by our lending specialists. They just look for particular expertise and that's all that we have here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on that same matter: would Senator Gareth Evans at the same time like to ensure that the Commonwealth Bank does respond in detail to matters raised, particularly the question of whether this account has been referred to the group control section, and a number of other serious matters to which the Commonwealth Bank has chosen to respond in a very partial and selective manner? If he is in the business of clarifying the situation, why will he not give an assurance now that he will ensure that all of those matters are fully addressed?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the specific matter to which Senator Alston refers: if he had listened to PM last night or seen the text of the transcripts that I have just incorporated, he would know that that matter is addressed.
—It is not.
—The specific question about group credit control is put and answered. I have got nothing to add.

—Senator Hill asked me a question about Commonwealth funding for universities. I have been given some supplementary information on that, which I now read into the record. Total funding per equivalent full-time student units, EFTSU—which includes operating grant, capital and research funds—did decline by seven per cent between 1983 and 1987. However, since 1987, over the last eight years, it has risen steadily, due in part to a sharp increase in capital allocations.

PARA.TAB: Total Commonwealth funding per student has risen from $11,457 in 1987 to $12,157 in 1996. In 1994, total resources per EFTSU of $12,156 were virtually at the same level as they were in 1983 at $12,186. This contrasts sharply with the period under the previous government which saw a steady decline in the total resources available per student. In 1983 total resources per student were 17.6 per cent less than in 1975. That, I think, is a complete answer to the further allegations that were made in Senator Hill's question today.

TALK.START.PARA: —In question time today, Senator Reid asked me a question on which I have further information. It relates to the Lake Burley Griffin tourist operation.

PARA.TAB: On 22 March 1995, the National Capital Planning Authority extended a permit enabling Canberra Cruises and Tours Pty Ltd to operate ferry services on Lake Burley Griffin until 30 June 1995.
