PARA.TAB: What is interesting to note is that in this statement the words `carrying on in a commercial manner' are used. The word `normal' is excised, excluded and does not exist because this is certainly not normal commercial behaviour. It is intriguing to look at the specific and very careful wording of the statement by the Commonwealth Bank. I quote from the statement that Senator Evans has tabled once again, `I incorporated it, I quoted it at length last night, I have already put before the Senate what this statement was all about.'

TALK.START.PARA: —And the interview? Did you do that with the interview too?

—Thank you, Senator, for prompting me. I will deal with that if you will keep quiet for just a bit. The arrangements include a mixture of longstanding and current borrowing arrangements with the Commonwealth Bank. The bank says that the Labor Party is meeting its obligations to the bank under arrangements that were negotiated in a commercial manner and include a commercial rate of interest. For the minister's benefit, because he obviously could not add up when he misled the Senate yesterday, $10,000 a week represents $520,000 a year. On a $6 million overdraft, that represents 8 1/2 per cent. What we were asking, quite properly, is why the Labor Party gets such a beneficial interest rate on such a loan when it is a risky borrower, a high risk borrower. It is such a high risk borrower that its liabilities massively exceed its assets. It has been put into a special category—which is dealt with later by the bank—where people who are having difficulties with clients are put. This category normally includes bad or doubtful debts and where provision is made against that debt by the bank.

PARA.TAB: I was intrigued to see the response of the bank person. I quote from the interview with Andrew Olle this morning. Mr Olle says:

SPEECH.PARA: Have you, as has been alleged by Michael Baume, transferred the debt from normal accounts into the hands of your group credit control, which is seen as a potential bad debt?
Deves responds:

No, we use our lending specialists from time to time with various clients, and being in difficulty or having unusual transactions or just customers that just need perhaps a bit of extra servicing and attention.
There is no doubt the Labor Party needs a bit of extra servicing and attention because it simply is a high risk borrower getting a special low interest rate deal.

PARA.TAB: Andrew Olle then asked, `Was there ever a time when they weren't meeting their payments?' It intrigued me when Ms Deves said, `Not that I'm aware of.' She did not say, `I don't know' or `No, definitely not.' It reminds me of the way Senator Evans responds when he is very uneasy about the answer and he says, `I am advised that'. Each time I put up an issue regarding this matter, he has said `I am advised that' or `I am told that'. It is because he has no confidence in the answers. We all know that he misled the Senate yesterday. He said that all his advisings were appropriate. He misled the Senate by cutting 75 per cent off the amount of repayment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Time's up.
—No, as I understand it, Mr Acting Deputy President Chapman, I did not seek leave to speak for five minutes; I sought leave to speak.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Senator Baume asked for leave to speak. He may continue speaking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly, the question asked was, `Was there ever a time when they weren't meeting these payments?' The reply was `Not that I am aware of.' Were they or were they not? Senator Evans, the reason I ask that is very simple. After your inaccurate statements of yesterday, I am intrigued as to whether you would like now to go on the record as denying that any interest payments on this mortgage have been paid in cash. You asserted yesterday that they were all being paid by cheque—I presume now; I assume your wording was very careful, and not going back into previous payments. I once again ask you to come clean. Will you deny that any interest payments on this mortgage have been paid in cash? Will you or your relevant colleagues authorise the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and the cash transaction centre, Austrac, which has to take a record of cash transactions, to make a public statement to test whether you are wrong again?

PARA.TAB: You have been able to go along with the Commonwealth Bank to answer selected questions. How about coming clean on the lot? Senator Evans, if you have got nothing to hide, come clean on whether there have been any cash payments and how much they were for. I can tell you that I am advised—and that is not one of your ducking phrases `I am advised'—and I am very well informed that substantial cash payments were made to make up for the fact that the Labor Party did not meet some of its interest repayments as they fell due last year. I am advised that that is the reason this account is in the close watch area of the Commonwealth Bank, and that these cash deposits were made to catch up on that failure to pay. Quite frankly, when cash deposits are made in such a situation, you may have a problem with the Electoral Act relating to donations in cash. That is just a by-the-way issue.

What I am particularly concerned about is that this statement by the bank assures us—and I accept that assurance—that it has not extended preferential treatment for political reasons. But I wonder what the reasons are for the bank extending this extraordinarily generous approach to the Labor Party, if they are not political. There must be some other reason for a high risk debtor being given extraordinarily friendly terms and a very generous interest rate when, in fact, it has at times failed to meet the payments. That has not been denied by the Commonwealth Bank. All the representative of the Commonwealth Bank said was, `Not that I am aware of.'
Senator Evans, I suggest that you draw your attention to the response by Ms Deves—I notice that you did not table this interview, naturally—in the interview this morning when Andrew Olle asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Have you had any concerns at all about the size of this debt and the ALP's ability to service it?
Her response included this remark:
We did at one stage, I think, express concern to them.

In other words, this is not the normal, lovely commercial transaction with no problems, as you have presented it falsely to this Senate. This is a matter which has caused the bank concern. You have pretended to this place that everything has always been lovely, that you have a wonderful relationship with your bank and that you always pay on time—instead of the reality that this transaction, this whole debt, has caused the bank concern.

PARA.TAB: You do not have to be an Einstein, or even an Evans, to recognise that the bank has concerns and that is the reason it has transferred the matter to the section of the bank that deals with bad debts. Senator Evans, I ask you once again: if you have nothing to hide, why don't you ask the bank to answer all the other questions, particularly the one about cash deposits?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I do not want to waste the time of the Senate for very long because no doubt this matter will be the subject of nauseous repetition during the MPI which will follow. I just make the point that Senator Baume is up to his old familiar tricks of dragging a trail of innuendo and imputation across the Senate in exactly the same way he did for months on end as far as the alleged deficiencies in the various financial transactions of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) or those of the company with which at one time he was associated are concerned. You were never able to establish anything in the nature of improper behaviour on the part of the Prime Minister or anyone else associated with that company, and nor will you be able to on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: You keep on asking questions that have been the subject of answers. The particular business about the reference to the group credit control section of the bank was the subject of an express question and answer in the interview which I have already tabled. I will read the relevant passage:

SPEECH.PARA: THOMPSON:Has the ALP's account been transferred to the Group Credit Control section of the Bank, which is a section which usually deals with potential bad debts?

DEVES:We have lending specialists, and from time to time various accounts will go to the lending specialist area—so that's really nothing to get excited about. I think somebody's drawn the wrong conclusion from that.
THOMPSON:So it has been handed over to the Credit Control section.

DEVES: They're just an area of lending specialists. From time to time various borrowers are looked after by our lending specialists. They just look for particular expertise and that's all that we have here.

Of course, it is a large debt. The bank being responsible, as it has to be, to its shareholders has to seek the best possible guarantees that that debt will be repaid and the best possible arrangements for its return.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday or the day before, Senator Baume made a public statement about the Labor Party being technically bankrupt. That is an outrageous allegation. He said that the Labor Party was technically bankrupt with liabilities massively exceeding assets. Even someone with your limited claim to financial expertise—your own career demonstrates the extent of the limit, with Patrick Partners and all the rest, Senator Baume—would well be aware that assets and liabilities balanced by themselves are not to the point when you are talking about bankruptcy, expressed or implied or technically or otherwise. What matters is your capacity to pay the debt in question. That depends on your income stream. It depends on the nature not only of the formal asset backing you have but also the quality of the resources and the extent of resources which lay behind your debt repayment capacity.

What you have with the ALP is a body which obviously is having difficulties as a result of a particular transaction which went wrong, as a result of a collapse of property prices. It did not go nearly as badly as the state superannuation scheme did when it lost property to the value of $1 billion over exactly the same period. It was $1 billion of taxpayers' money, as distinct from a few million dollars of private organisational money. That does not trouble you. We have not had a squeak from you about that. That was a product of exactly the same circumstances.

The ALP in New South Wales has obviously had to deal with that situation as best it can. It is making repayments at the rate of $10,000 per week, as I have said. I said yesterday on the basis of advice available to me—I have no further advice than that—that there is no truth in rumours that this $10,000 was being met in cash or some other improper way. As I said yesterday, the mortgage repayments are being made by cheque from New South Wales accounts that are in surplus.

The New South Wales ALP has met all of its obligations in this matter to the satisfaction of its bankers and its auditors. That is the information available to me. If you want some further information, you can whistle dixie for it as far as I am concerned. You are just on the kind of trail you have been involved in every year, every month, every day you have been in this place. You are trying to turn up by snide innuendo of one kind or other allegations of default, allegations of impropriety. You have been proven wrong on every occasion in the past. You will be proven wrong again. You have been expressly met with a clear-cut, straightforward response from the Commonwealth Bank saying:

Senator Baume's allegation that the Bank has extended preferential treatment for political reasons is absolutely untrue and a matter of great concern to the Bank, which relies on commercial dealings in good faith with all its customers.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Baume is doing is calling into doubt, with no evidence at all and with no material on which he can remotely justify it, other than some spurious reference to some advice he has received, some information he has received, from the usual holes, the usual corners, the usual dark places, the usual slimy muck barrels that he inhabits—with his head down there and his little legs waggling out the top of the barrel. They are holes that he inhabits; those are the sources of his information. He claims he has some information. We do not know its chapter and verse.

PARA.TAB: In reply to that we have a very explicit and very direct statement by the chief manager of group communication of the Commonwealth Bank—moreover, not only a denial of the innuendos and the allegations made by Senator Baume but a statement of how great a concern it is to the bank that Senator Baume should, by these allegations and innuendos and imputations, be putting at risk the bank's capacity to deal in good faith with its customers.

The bank must keep its credibility absolutely intact if it is to be commercially competitive with other banks dealing in commercial business with commercial customers. The bank cannot afford to behave otherwise than with scrupulous propriety in the protection of its shareholders. The bank has behaved with scrupulous propriety. There is one person in this place who has not, and that is Senator Baume.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), to questions without notice asked by Senators Hill and Bell this day relating to higher education funding and tertiary fees.

SPEECH.PARA: I would actually like to contribute to the last debate, but there would probably be some objection to that. This serious matter relates to the funding crisis in higher education and the deteriorating quality of education in this country as a result. It is a concern that is being expressed by Australian students to the extent that they are taking part today in what they refer to as a national day of protest—a protest which I note is also being supported by many of their lecturers.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that it is students who so strongly supported this Labor government at the last election who are now protesting about its policies in the strongest terms. As I said in my question today, students feel that they have been misled. In fact, students believe that they were lied to at the last election, so much so that their own president said, `The government has lied to undergraduate students claiming that they would be protected from up-front fees.' I understand that this president of the National Union of Students is, in fact, a member of the ALP.

That is the extent of disillusionment of students with this government's policies. This is only reflective of a wider community disillusionment with Labor and its performance in office—just another sector of the community that is now coming forward and saying, `We were misled. We were lied to in the last election. We will stick it no longer. We must go out there and protest. We must protest against the misrepresentations that were made by this government.' Again, the only response of those opposite is to laugh at them. The government is not laughing at us. It is laughing at the Australian students whom it conned at the last election and whom it will not be able to con again. The government misled them once, but it will not mislead them again.

Over the period of this Labor government, public funding per student has in fact decreased by about 15 per cent. If the government wants the authority for that, it should look at the DEET annual report 1994-95 and also the DEET Higher Education Council resource allocation paper on higher education. Public funding per student has been substantially reduced.

The result has been that Australian universities have been under enormous financial pressure.They are distressed about the quality of their product deteriorating. They are disturbed by the fact that they are having huge class sizes—over 500 students per class. Students are sitting in the aisles. They are distressed that the whole tutorial system is breaking down because there are simply too many students per tute to allow it to function properly. They are distressed by the fact that libraries in Australian universities cannot cope with the numbers and the quality of particularly undergraduate first degrees is deteriorating. Students are angry about that and they are taking out their wrath on this government, and so they should.

What are the universities therefore saying? They are saying they have no alternative but to seek to broaden their financial base in such ways as the government gives them a wink and a nod for. This government said that it was against up-front fees. But when the universities feel that they have no alternative but to charge undergraduate fees through commercial companies, this government gives them a wink and a nod. That is the way universities are supposed to go.

This government said to Australian students that it is against up-front fees but, of course, subsequent to the election, it would allow universities to charge such fees for postgraduate degrees—research and class degrees. It would open that door, and it basically expected the universities to pass through it. Why? Because the government wants universities to stand the political cost of having angry students. The government is not prepared to face up to its own responsibility. It is its policies—the policies that Senator Schacht talked about today—that have resulted in this crisis in higher education, the deteriorating quality in degrees and the anger that is being expressed by students and their teachers today.

As I said, those people will not be misled again. They have every right to feel disillusioned with this government. They have every right to say they were conned at the last election, but they will not be conned again. It is sad that they feel that they have no alternative but to join those other sectors of the Australian community that are also now saying they were lied to once and will not be lied to again.

On the next occasion, the Australian people will not believe the promises that the government makes. They will not believe the government in light of the fact that it has its National Union of Students pouring $100,000 of student money into a campaign to support it. Conned once, but conned twice they will not be. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Hill's remarks. What is happening with higher education at the moment is an absolute disgrace. The outcome of that disgrace is, of course, the fact that students, for the first time in history, have downed pens and are not going to lectures today because of the absolute failure of this government's higher education policy since the advent of the Dawkinisation of the universities.

PARA.TAB: That was supposed to be a marvellous panacea for higher education, but what have we seen in terms of outcomes? Senator Forshaw would appreciate the fact that, initially, 50,000 students were without places but that figure, even with the changes that this government has lauded over the last few years and since I came to this place, has only just been pushed to under 30,000.

That many students are still being turned away from our universities. Are they being turned away from universities where all the provision is there? No, they are not. What this government has done in the expansion of higher education has been done on an absolute shoestring. The government's back is now forced against the wall because tutorial class sizes have increased, lecture class sizes have increased and the buildings are so run down in a lot of places that they are not really fit for lectures. The government has not put enough money into capital works. One library in Adelaide banned students from other universities from using it because it did not have the people to stack the books again. That is the way this Labor government has allowed this system to become run down.

We have the cumulation of all those things today. Students have every right to be angry. If they have worked towards, made sacrifices for and got themselves a position on a university campus, they have the right to expect first-class treatment. We have in this country first-class academics, but we do not have first-class facilities. Class sizes are too big, buildings are run down and resources are diminishing.

With its back against the wall, what is this government's response to funding higher education properly? It has wasted so much money in budgets over the years it is obviously finding it cannot finance out of the budget further expansion. So it has come down to a point where more and more fees are being charged for courses.

The absolute hypocrisy of this government is demonstrated by comparing what it is doing now with what it promised before the last election. The government had students supporting it out there in the streets during the last election. It had great numbers of students voting for it in the last election. Students now feel they have been totally betrayed by this government because of what it has done in relation to fees since that time. In relation to students having to pay for full fees, we have seen a gradual encroachment into the higher education sector initially in the area of postgraduate degrees. People are now having to pay full fees for many courses where only a small fee was charged. We are also now finding that that also applies to undergraduate courses.

The government's spokesman in my area was Frank Walker. At a public meeting attended by 600 people he said, `If the Liberals get in, they will charge you full fees after the election.' That was not true. It was never our policy, but it is the reality today under this government. At the University of Western Sydney there is the case of a civil aviation undergraduate batchelor's course—$55,000 for the fees. The government is bringing it in by stealth. As Senator Hill said, the government does not want to take the odium for it; it is trying to put it on the universities. That will not wash. We know the responsibility is with the government. Undergraduate fees are coming in by stealth.

In estimates one month ago I asked the deputy secretary whether a number of institutions have set up companies where students are paying full fees. What did Mr Phillips say? He said that, if it were an award of the university, the university would be in breach of the act if it charged fees. I asked him the question in three different ways subsequent to that and, like Sir Humphrey, he came back and gave that exact answer again. The lie has been put to that.

In the case of the University of Western Sydney and a number of others, this government is allowing full fees for undergraduate courses. We have students marching in the streets against this. We have them marching in the streets against the poor facilities in the universities because of this government's underspending. The government deserves the odium that is coming upon it from students. Let us hope that the students wake up to the fact that they have been conned by this Labor government and that when they get to the polls next time they vote the government out. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Chris Evans this day, relating to confidential Aboriginal documents concerning the site for the proposed Hindmarsh Island bridge.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to concur with the minister's concern about the treatment of Aboriginal cultural and religious sensitivities in this issue by the Liberal Party. The whole episode has been nothing short of a disgrace. The Aboriginal communities and people I have spoken to are most concerned about the treatment of their culture in this whole issue. But more concerning of late has been the way that error, that disgraceful treatment of Aboriginal people, has been compounded by the defence of Mr McLachlan's actions offered by Mr John Howard and now by Mr Peter Costello.

PARA.TAB: Rather than saying that the resignation by Mr McLachlan was recognition of the error made and accepting that Mr McLachlan had made a mistake, they have gone out of their way to defend his actions. They have alleged that it is merely a technical breach and that he is an honourable man and would be welcomed back into the shadow ministry at any time. That does not concern me in the sense that Mr McLachlan did not fire a shot in all the years he was in the shadow ministry and no-one on this side fears his return; but, in terms of the principle at stake, it is a most concerning development.

Is John Howard, as the minister suggested, going to make Mr McLachlan shadow minister for Australia Post if he is returned to the shadow ministry and have him open the mail all around Australia? There is no contrition at all on behalf of the Liberal Party of the actions of Mr McLachlan. There is no rejection of his action. He not only opened the mail that was clearly directed to somebody else but also distributed that mail as far and as wide as possible and distributed that mail to persons who were in legal dispute with the parties for whom that mail was intended. That was a quite outrageous action on his behalf and it really does behove the Liberal Party leadership to disassociate itself from those actions.

But no, Mr Howard has defended those actions. In doing so, he has raised a real question mark in Australian society about his own performance, about his own morality and about whether or not he is able to distance himself from the right wing that seems to have taken over the Liberal Party in recent years. Clearly the treatment of Aboriginal issues by this Liberal Party would not have occurred under former Aboriginal affairs ministers, such as Viner and Chaney.

What we have seen is this extreme right wing view take hold in the Liberal Party. Obviously, John Howard is a captive of that view and represents that extreme right wing position. We saw what that influence did to Alexander Downer, who was beaten into confusing policy positions by Richard Court's insistence that he oppose the Native Title Act. He went to the Northern Territory and imploded as he was unable to come to grips with what was required of him in terms of Liberal Party policy on Aboriginal affairs because of the real conflicts within the party and the fact that it fails to have any sensitivity or appreciation of the needs of Aboriginal people in Australia. This issue has raised question marks not only about John Howard but clearly also about the opposition spokesperson on Aboriginal affairs, Chris Gallus. There can be only two answers to Chris Gallus's position.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! I would ask the honourable senator to use proper titles.

TALK.START.PARA: —There can be only two answers to the question about Mrs Gallus's status. One is that she is irrelevant and Mr Howard has no confidence in her. He clearly knew at least 10 days before the questions were asked. She claims to have had no knowledge of what was to be revealed in question time in the House of Representatives. Mr Howard knew 10 days beforehand. So either he has no confidence in her and refused to tell her, or she was an accomplice in and was part of that orchestrated decision to use that material—material illegally obtainedand released—in question time in the House of Representatives to try to attack the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner.As I have said, Mrs Gallus is either irrelevant and does not enjoy the confidence of Mr Howard or she was an accomplice in this abuse and she ought to resign as shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs.

PARA.TAB: The Liberal Party really has to come to terms with the redneck right wing element that drives it on Aboriginal affairs. It has to try to come to terms with moving into the 20th century in terms of the treatment of Aboriginal people and Aboriginal issues and it has to show some cultural sensitivity. If it cannot do that, it will never enjoy the confidence of the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to speak on this matter, but I think it is important that I do. What the Labor Party does not understand is that there are people on our side of politics—and Ian Mclachlan is one of them, a man of the greatest integrity and principle—
—We understand fully how youse can lie and cheat.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I ask you to request Senator Murphy to withdraw those words `lie and cheat'.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: it was not directed at a specific senator. I heard the word `lie', directed at the government, come from that side constantly during question time. What is good for the goose is good for the gander. Senator Abetz, you did not object on those occasions. Do not tell me you did not hear it. I think it is best that the words that Senator Murphy used not be used, and they would certainly be out of order if they were directed specifically to an individual in the Senate. I heard him say `youse'. You should correct him on his English but, leaving that aside, the words have not been ruled out of order in the past. If we are to uphold Senator Abetz's point of order, then it would have to be enforced rigidly and across the board.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Before you rise on the point of order, Senator Abetz, I must admit that I heard the word, but I could not hear the context in which it was said. If you wish to continue your point of order, I will obtain some advice while you are doing so.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand the situation, a senator cannot hide behind the fact that he did not direct it to one particular senator. If he applies it to a party of senators within the chamber, like `youse' as in the plural of `you', then that also is a breach and should also be withdrawn. I understand there are precedents for that. Although I cannot put my hands on them now, I am sure I could within a matter of minutes.
—I am not absolutely sure, but I ask Senator Murphy to withdraw his comments and then we can get on with the business of the Senate.

—I withdraw my comments. The reference was made purely on the basis that, if you open private mail and then proceed—in another chamber—to tell people that you did not do it, if that is not lying I do not know what is.
—Order! Senator Murphy, if you are asked to withdraw all you have to do is say you withdraw; anything else is disorderly. I ask you to withdraw.
—I withdraw.

—As I said, I did not intend to speak on this, but when I heard what Senator Evans said I could not resist it. Mr McLachlan is a man of incredible integrity and principle. Senator Ray knows full well—as does everyone else in this chamber—that occasionally documents come to parties on either side of the parliament. Those documents are used. The Labor Party before the last election illegally got the Fightback documents. It did not hesitate to use them. Then members of the Labor Party come in here with utter hypocrisy and talk about using documents. Let us put the documents aside for a minute. The thing is that those documents came into Ian McLachlan's possession. He himself was misled.
—Rubbish. What total rubbish.

—Senator Murphy does not know what the word `integrity' means; nor do any of the Labor ministers. How long did it take to blast Mrs Kelly out of her position for what she said—months and months, and she was doing something that was utterly illegal.
—Illegal?
—What was illegal?

—The abuse of taxpayers' money in handing out money in marginal seats. But let me go back to the point. Mr McLachlan came across some documents. It was in his absence. In good faith, he made some statements. Subsequently it was found that he was misled. It does not really matter.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chris Evans interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop blabbing on, you left wing ideologue. In good faith he misled the parliament and he did the right thing. He came forward and said, `I misled the parliament.' It was through no fault of his own. He said, `Therefore I have an obligation under the system under which we work'—not the system under which you work—`to resign my position as shadow minister.' The point of this matter is that people on the other side—and, I have to say, quite a number in the media—do not understand the principles of integrity and honesty. Mr McLachlan showed integrity and honesty. Mr McLachlan did something that no-one on your side of politics—none of your ministers—would do.
—He got caught.
—He came forward and said, `I have been misled.'

PARA.TAB: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ray should know this better than I. It is all right for Senator Ray to interject. He does not like this because what we are offering—what Mr Howard and the shadow ministers are offering—is a bit of honesty and integrity. Mr Keating does not like this. Coming from the right wing of the Labor Party in New South Wales, he does not know what the words mean either. What was the name of Richo's book?
—Whatever it Takes.

—Whatever it Takes. It does not matter what you say or what lies you tell; do whatever it takes to grab the ministerial leather. How shallow can you be. It is a matter of putting this in perspective. If it had been any other document at all and Mr McLachlan had found that he had unintentionally misled, he would have done exactly the same thing.
—He didn't know it was addressed to him?

—I can tell by the interjections that those opposite do not know what I am talking about. The Labor Party has no understanding of what is right and wrong. Even the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has misled this country. In my own shadow portfolio area, Mr Brereton has been responsible for the greatest lot of deceit and lies that the people of Sydney have ever seen. What are they up to? You do this hypocrisy one on top of the other. Yet we have a shadow minister who says, `I made a mistake. I didn't try to cover it up. Therefore, it is in the interests—'(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to address the question asked by Senator Chris Evans of Senator Collins. It is correct that we ought to put this in context, because it goes to the very question of the credibility of people who enter public life. With regard to Senator Parer's remarks about legality, the situation was put into context very well by Ross Peake. In an article on 18 March, when referring to Mr Howard, he wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: Now he has revealed that he sanctioned the actions of his now disgraced frontbencher, Ian McLachlan, the beneficiary of the wrongly delivered parcel of government and Aboriginal documents. (If the stray box of papers had been sent by Australia Post instead of a courier, Mr McLachlan's staff could be facing criminal charges now.)

They are the facts of the matter as they relate to honesty and integrity. Mr McLachlan knew this full well, and it really raises the question: when he got this box of papers, even when he first opened them, why did he not give them to Mrs Gallus, the shadow spokesperson on Aboriginal affairs? Why not?

PARA.TAB: Let us get it into context. Mr McLachlan receives the papers and consents to their copying. He then goes into the parliament and says, `The envelope in which these documents, the women's letters, were contained were not marked'—first lie. Then he launches an attack—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I would ask you to make Senator Murphy withdraw the comment that the honourable member for Barker lied in the parliament.

—I withdraw and replace it with `first untruth'. He then launches a totally misleading attack on the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner—second untruth. He got caught out again. All through this his leader, Mr Howard, endorses him; backs him up. So did your shadow spokesperson on Aboriginal affairs, Mrs Gallus. Where is she in all of this? Why did Mr McLachlan not give her the box of documents? It is really her area.

PARA.TAB: Mr McLachlan's coming back to the front bench was appropriately dealt with in some recent radio interviews. On 22 March, on ABC radio's P.M., Mr Costello commented in response to this question:

SPEECH.PARA: So you are saying that you would see a way back for him in a coalition government—a senior position?
Mr Costello replied:

Look, somebody with the talent of Ian McLachlan is somebody that you wouldn't leave on the interchange bench, but in order to get him onto the field you have to make sure the team is balanced. I just want to say about Ian that I think when people look back on it—it will be a technical issue—the ins and outs of which will probably long pass.

It was in and out all right. They took private documents out of a sealed envelope addressed to somebody else. As was pointed out by Ross Peake of the Canberra Times, you are saying that if it was somebody else's mail—the mail of anyone of these people in the gallery—you would have supported it, you would have supported a criminal action. That is what you would have done. But we can go on further. Mr Costello, in response to another question, said:

Well, the technical issue, the ins and outs of which will pass, but the point about it is this: that Ian made a decision that he didn't want to be placed in a position where it could have been said that he wasn't thoroughly honest.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't understand that, do you?
—I know one thing for sure—Ian McLachlan does not understand it. It is a new measurement of strength. Mr Costello then went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: He, as a result, took the decision to illustrate that by taking the biggest sacrifice you could in politics—and that will always be remembered about Ian McLachlan and the strength of his character.

It is a real new measurement of strength and character when you open somebody's private mail. If that is how you people measure strength and character, God help the Australian people if you ever get into parliament. It gets worse. Mr Costello went on further to say:
Well, Ian is a very honourable man.

That is a new interpretation of `honourable'. It has to be the newest interpretation of `honourable' when you can open somebody's personal mail and have that action endorsed by your leader. That is what you people have done. Yet, with all of the copies that have been distributed, not once has Mr McLachlan come forward and identified where he sent those documents, not even now. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In my short time in this parliament, if there has been one person that has impressed me, it has been the honourable member for Barker, Mr Ian McLachlan. He is a man of absolute and utter integrity. He is a man in whom I place great faith. It has to be understood that Mr McLachlan resigned before anybody on the Australian Labor Party side of politics had the idea of even suggesting that he might like to resign. The honourable member for Barker, Mr McLachlan, unwittingly misled the parliament. As soon as that became apparent to him he resigned from the opposition front bench the next day.

PARA.TAB: During the parliamentary debate I recall Mr McLachlan calling for the tabling of the document. He challenged the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, to table the envelope. He was saying to the minister, `Table the envelope.' As a result, Mr Tickner tabled the envelope. It was then that Mr McLachlan realised that he had misled the parliament and took the honourable course of action. Mr Acting Deputy President—
Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason I smiled was that I said `Mr Acting Deputy President' when in fact there is now a female in the chair. The Labor Party gets excited about the most extraneous matters. When former Senator Graham Richardson had to be forced out of the ministry with a crowbar over the Marshall Islands affair and when Mrs Kelly had to be forced out of the ministry with a crowbar there was no honour about it, there was no integrity about it and there was no apology associated with it. They did not say, `I have done something wrong.' Mr McLachlan acknowledged that he had misled the parliament, albeit unwittingly, and therefore took the honourable course of action. If we look at former senator Richardson and former Minister Kelly we find that there was no such action taken at all.

PARA.TAB: If we are talking about peddling certain documents, then what about the fact that the Australian Labor Party received documents from our advertising agency by error and then peddled them throughout question time the very next day. The Labor Party was not ashamed of that. The application of double standards is to be abhorred. When somebody abides by the principles of the Westminster system and resigns for having misled parliament, that ought to be applauded by every single Australian because it is in such contradistinction to what members of the Australian Labor Party do. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—The President has received a letter from Senator Baume proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:
The inability of Labor to handle its own money let alone taxpayers' money in the context of the federal Labor government's economic failures.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate I shall ask the clerks to set the clock accordingly. I should point out, however, that General Business must commence at 4.30 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great pleasure in putting forward this matter of public importance:

PARA.TAB: The inability of Labor to handle its own money let alone taxpayers' money in the context of the federal Labor government's economic failures.

SPEECH.PARA: The Keating government is the government of the true deceivers. Having won office by the most dishonest election campaign ever waged in Australia, it has since reneged on all its major promises. As John Howard says, we have had five minutes of economic sunshine before getting clobbered with the same sorts of higher interest rates that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, used to create the last recession, which he said we had to have.

PARA.TAB: The government's Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, in its latest set of forecasts points out that recent increases in Australia's prime business lending rates have restored them to their highest level for three years. ABARE expects further short-term interest rate rises during the remainder of 1995, with the prime rate rising from an average of nine per cent last year to around 10.5 per cent this year and 11.5 per cent in the next financial year.

Why should business believe the government's assurances that interest rates are unlikely to rise further when one of its major economic advisers is telling it that further increases will be required to control significant inflationary pressures? But when are they going to come? They will not come until after next Saturday, until after the next state election, because this government is applying the same sort of dishonest campaigning that it applied to its own election—the most dishonest campaign ever—to the state election campaign in New South Wales. Only after that New South Wales state election is out of the way will the nasties begin to hit us again from the federal government, especially interest rates, which will seriously affect the finances of all the states but in particular the very well run states like New South Wales, which has an outstanding record of economic management.

What we have to deal with here is the simple question of what sort of leadership we have both in the New South Wales Labor Party and the Labor Party federally. It is appropriate that this government is led by the right wing of the New South Wales Labor Party. Look at the names: Mr Keating, Mr Brereton, former senator Richardson—he is an admitted true deceiver—and Mr Punch. Then there is an honorary member of the Right who is a leftie, Mr Walker. This group of the New South Wales right have one interest—the exercise of power—and they seek it by hook or by crook.

In the last federal election they did it by crook. In the present state election in New South Wales they have been hooked. And the hook they are on is their own financial incompetence. How can a party run the finances of the state or of the nation when it cannot even manage its own finances? You cannot trust Labor with money, and you certainly cannot trust Labor with power because that is the way it gets money; it gets money by exercising its power. We can see the extraordinary chaos that the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party is in.

Mr Carr, the New South Wales Labor leader, says, `It's not my fault that the New South Wales Labor Party has a huge debt, $6 million on mortgage and another $4 million in various other ways with the Commonwealth Bank. It's not my fault that we have a $6 million mortgage, in particular, secured by less than $2 million of assets. It's not my fault that if the bank foreclosed, the Labor Party would be broke. It's all an administrative problem. It's the administration that does that.' Is it really a matter for Labor's administrative committee? Mr Carr is a member of Labor's administrative committee. Rule D2a(2) of Labor's constitution states:

SPEECH.PARA: The state parliamentary leader is a member of the administrative committee.
Rule D5b states:

The administrative committee will also present annual conference with a balance sheet which has been audited and also a statement of the general financial position of the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party.

Is that not fascinating—an audited statement. Let me tell honourable senators: there is no audited statement of the organisation that is in fact sending the Labor Party broke—that is, Labor Centenary House Pty Ltd. We can rely for that fact on the Australian Securities Commission because it has not received an audited statement. Not only that; in the latest inadequate annual return from this sinking ship we see that Mr John Della Bosca, who signed the return, has ticked the box that says, `There are no audited accounts. The auditor has not audited the accounts.' That, frankly, is a disgrace. The ASC received an undertaking from the Labor Party last year that it would file accounts by 30 June last year. It did not happen. Nor did it happen that the Labor Party has advised the ASC that the auditor has at last audited the accounts.

PARA.TAB: You cannot get around the law by using a sneaky device that says, `Oh, we have an auditor, therefore we don't have to present accounts to the ASC', when, in fact, the auditor has not audited the accounts. It is the sort of typical, devious, sneaky, dishonest approach that you would expect from a Labor Party controlled by the right wing in New South Wales.

The sort of style of this party is evident from a statutory declaration from a constituent of mine, who went to see Mr Paul Crittenden, a Labor MP from Toukley. He went to him because he had some problems and he wanted to get them resolved. Do you know what he was told when he went there? He was told, `If you make a $300 donation we will look into the matter further.' That is the sort of help and consideration that fits exactly into the style of the right wing dominated Australian Labor Party in New South Wales. And it starts at the top. Bob Carr is a member of the committee that is supposed to be involved in presenting the accounts of this shonky organisation.

Let us deal with the responses by Senator Evans today, because a whole series of proper questions were asked. The farmers in New South Wales are being pushed off their land by the bank. I will not go into the rights and wrongs of what the bank is doing. All I know is this: it is treating those people very differently from the way it is treating the ALP. If the spokesman for the bank says that it is not right to say that the interest rate is about 8 1/2 or 9 per cent, it is very hard to work out another interest rate, is it not, when the Labor Party has been paying this figure, either by cash or by cheque—it missed some of its payments so it had to pay by cash. The fact is when you have a situation where this bank is allowing this high risk client whose liabilities massively exceed its assets to have an extraordinarily low rate of interest—and apparently not to be involved in any repayments of the principle; there is no way that kind of payment would involve any repayment of the principle—then the people of Australia have a right to ask questions about what sort of arrangements seem to be going on when the Labor Party is involved.

Yet what do we hear from the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans? Every time I have asked him a question I have been given a misleading, disgraceful answer which he has had to withdraw and correct because he was 75 per cent wrong. He claimed that the Labor Party was repaying the debt; this is simply untrue. It is not repaying a cracker. It is simply paying the interest bill. So Senator Evans is misleading the Senate again.

What does Senator Evans have to hide? Why won't he answer the questions about whether or not cash payments—brown envelopes—have been made to pay the Labor Party's back debt? He said, `If you want any further information, you can go hopping.' That is what he told the people of Australia about this special deal the Labor Party has. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —When Senator Baume stood up to put forward this matter of public importance, I thought to myself, `Come in spinner.' If ever there was someone desperate to lead with his chin, it has been Senator Baume this afternoon. He said nothing at all about taxpayers' funds, but he tried to make a case regarding private dealings. If Senator Baume wants to help his coalition partners in New South Wales, he ought to stay clear of references to private dealings and private actions that have anything to do with the ability to manage taxpayers' funds. But if that is the path Senator Baume wants to go down, let us see where it leads us.

PARA.TAB: When it comes to the relationship between private dealings and the public management of taxpayers' funds, the New South Wales coalition government has the most appalling record. Let us look at that record. Who was a member of the New South Wales government—the government responsible for looking after taxpayers' funds in New South Wales? None other than Phillip Smiles, a convicted tax cheat. If you were going to talk about managing taxpayers' money, you would not ask Phillip Smiles, because he does not believe in paying tax. He does not like being a taxpayer.

Then we come to Terry Metherell. Do you remember Terry Metherell, the minister for education some years ago? He was a senior minister found cheating on his tax. He resigned from the ministry and became an Independent. Then a former Premier Nick Greiner and a former minister Tim Moore tried to use the public purse to get Terry Metherell to resign from the parliament so that they could get the numbers to save their sleazy government.

If Senator Baume wants us to consider business dealings as a criteria for holding parliamentary office and managing taxpayers' funds in New South Wales, then let us look at Tony Packard. Do you remember Tony Packard? He was a car salesman found guilty of illegally using listening devices to spy on his customers in order to line his own pocket. The recent actions of Chris Downy's staff member would lead one to think that the Liberal Party is actually running a course on how to intercept telephone conversations and how to threaten and abuse people over the telephone. What did Packard do? He resigned in disgrace after being convicted.

Do you remember Matt Singleton, a National Party minister who was kicked out of the ministry in New South Wales because of a conflict of interest between his personal dealings and his public responsibilities as a minister? What was that conflict of interest over? You guessed it: property development. Yet Senator Baume has the hide to come in here and attack the New South Wales Labor Party. With the record that the current New South Wales government has in respect of ministerial propriety and in respect of looking after and managing the taxpayers' funds of New South Wales, Senator Baume should be ashamed of himself.

We can go on. Remember Neil Pickard? He knew how to manage taxpayers' money; he knew how to spend it on himself. When he was Agent General in London he lived the life of luxury and had to go off to the continent occasionally for a bit of R&R all at the taxpayers' expense. Finally Premier Fahey was forced to take the step of sacking him as the Agent General. But he could not get that right; he could not even sack his own representative the right way. He bungled it so badly that Neil Pickard ended up with $400,000 of New South Wales taxpayers' money as compensation because of the Premier's own incompetence. And you try to lecture us about managing taxpayers' money!

Joe Schipp, the Minister for Housing in New South Wales at one stage, presided over the Homefund disaster—a debacle that could end up costing the taxpayers of New South Wales over $500 million. And you try to lecture us about managing taxpayers' money! What happened to Joe Schipp? Premier Fahey ultimately had to get rid of him for incompetence. Premier Fahey should apply the same standards to himself and resign over his own incompetence when, as the Minister for Industrial Relations, he was in charge of the state superannuation board of New South Wales and was responsible for a loss of $1 billion in property investments—$1 billion of taxpayers' money.

I could go on. It is a long list. Terry Griffiths, a Minister for Police charged with upholding the law, had to resign. Barry Morris was kicked out of the Liberal Party. He lost his endorsement as a Liberal candidate because of activities once again associated with the telephone. As I have already mentioned, the latest one was only a couple of days ago. A member of the minister for sports staff used the phone to terrorise and threaten ordinary decent citizens because they had the temerity to support the Labor Party. He used taxpayers' funds for that activity.

Yes, we are happy to debate this because what we can demonstrate and have demonstrated is how the coalition in New South Wales has flogged off the taxpayer's properties. It got rid of the State Bank. It would like to sell off the water board and all the other public assets, the public property of New South Wales taxpayers. But it will not get the chance because on Saturday the coalition will be thrown out of office.

Only this morning we have had the latest example of the misleading campaign conducted by the New South Wales Liberal Party desperate to cling on to office. The Premier has been running around the state claiming that the New South Wales Treasury had costed the Labor Party's program—a complete fabrication denied by the Treasury offices. This morning the Premier acknowledged it on AM. He confessed that he was wrong and he admitted he could not even add up when it came to assessing the Labor Party's program in the New South Wales state election.

The incoming Carr Labor government will be a competent manager of taxpayers' money. It has a comprehensive plan to fix New South Wales, to restore the basic services in health and education. Labor has a plan which has been independently assessed by KPMG, one of Australia's leading firms of chartered accountants. Yet, in the face of all of this, Senator Baume, in a last act to help out his mates in the New South Wales state government, comes in here and tries to talk about the relationship between private dealings and the management of taxpayers' money. The record is clear: the private dealings of members of the New South Wales government indicate that they are a pretty sleazy lot. The more Senator Baume raises those dealings, the more he will highlight the shameful record of the private dealings of members of the coalition.

The New South Wales government has proven that it is incapable of managing taxpayers' money. That is why those who remain on the government benches—the few who have not yet been sacked or forced to resign or those who have not had the decency to resign—will be thrown out this Saturday. The Carr Labor government, which will be elected on Saturday, will work with the federal government, with its impressive record of economic management in this country, to rebuild New South Wales as the premier state of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time left to me, I take pleasure in supporting Senator Baume's motion concerning Labor's fiscal incompetence. If Labor gains control of New South Wales this weekend, it will send New South Wales down the lane of profligate expenditure that it has sent other states down.

PARA.TAB: New South Wales electors must know that the New South Wales Labor Party is inconsolably in debt. Whether it will be subject to federal intervention, as promoted by Barry Jones, the ALP federal president, is irrelevant. If the federal government cannot manage its own affairs, it will not be able to manage the affairs of New South Wales.

Labor's financial record in state government speaks for itself. In Victoria, 200,000 small investors lost their money with Pyramid. There were the Tricontinental losses. It really was a state in decay. Those events gave new meaning to the term `rust belt' before Mr Kennett became the premier. Western Australia was simply a disgrace. No further comment is really needed. Where else in the world are a former Labor premier and Labor deputy premier doing time in a minimum security gaol for pilfering public funds? In South Australia, the $3 billion loss by the State Bank is the largest loss of any government instrumentality or company in this nation's history. The festival state really deserved a bit better than that. That is not including the SGIC losses. The South Australian electorate gave the answer to the Labor Party.

This federal Labor government has worked over time to help Mr Carr, who was recently described in connection with his parliamentary party as an intellectual carnivore surrounded by vegetarians. What has Labor done? Firstly, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has been AWL from the campaign. In fact, he has been overseas redesigning Berlin and talking to the Germans, of all people, about the advantages of an Australian republic. He went on to admit responsibility for the deplorable state of Aboriginal health.

Secondly, the federal government has tried to hoodwink timber workers and the conservation movement by not releasing 30-odd coupes to woodchipping when New South Wales has one of the best forestry management records in the world. Thirdly, the federal Labor government has held off another increase in interest rates, which are already causing extreme heartache amongst young home buyers, until after 25 March.

Fourthly, the federal Labor government has not told the truth about the increased number of aircraft movements at Kingsford Smith that will occur after the election. Fifthly, it has not told the truth about the environmental impact of a new airport at Badgerys Creek. Badgerys Creek electors should not trust the Labor Party on Saturday.
Next, New South Wales electors should know that the New South Wales Labor team is probably the most nondescript shadow ministry in recent time.
Senator McGauran interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will come to that. It would amuse us all a little if it were not so serious. Mr Carr's team has been described in the Telegraph Mirror as a team criticised for its low profile and male bias. The article also states that, on a head to head basis, the government appears to have it all over the Labor Party in areas of public profile and parliamentary performance. Mr Carr's shadow ministry also lacks women. There is certainly no affirmative action in the New South Wales Labor Party. Most members of Mr Carr's shadow ministry are just that—shadows. Most have never been heard of. Who are these people?

PARA.TAB: Mr Richard Face, the shadow minister for sport and racing, has no policies. Mr Pat Rogan, the shadow minister for minerals and energy, has no policies. Mr John Aquilina, the shadow minister for education, has no policies. Mr Ron Dyer, the shadow minister for family, community and disability services, has no policies. Mrs Faye Lo Po, the shadow minister for housing, has no policies. Mrs Lo Po was appointed to replace the discredited Mrs Deirdre Grusovin. As she is expected to lose her seat, her front bench experience may be the shortest in history.

We have a Mr Jeff Shaw, the shadow attorney-general: he was described recently as having had `four years of obscurity'. We have a Mr Col Markham, the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs: he has no policies, and has rarely broken his silence. Mr Brian Vaughan would escape the most wanted column—he has never been seen or heard: he is the shadow minister for small business, and he has no policies. I am told that his contribution to the public debate has been limited to the very occasional press release—very occasional. Small business in New South Wales deserves better than that. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)this Labor Government has followed a policy of increasing taxation on any industry which shows signs of being successful,
(ii)the Government and the Australian Democrats have both indicated that they favour tax increases over expenditure cuts as a means of deficit reduction,
(iii)currently there are around 3,500 grape growing establishments in Australia with some 68,000 hectares under vines,
(iv)the majority of grapes are grown on small holdings of less than 20 hectares by independent growers,
(v)in spite of a vine-pull program in the 1980s, wine grape production has now more than doubled since the early 1970s,
(vi)the wine industry set itself a target of up to one billion dollars in exports by the year 2000,

PARA.TAB: (vii)the past 3 or 4 years have seen an enormous expansion of winegrape vineyard investment, which is now locked in, and

(viii)the recent draft report by the committee of inquiry into the wine grape and wine industry has made recommendations which could seriously undermine the confidence in this one bright light in the rural economy; and

(b)urges the Government to reject both the majority and minority reports' recommendations for an increase in wine taxes, which would seriously undermine the wine industry in general but would have its most devastating effect on wine grape growers who are price-takers and not price-setters.

SPEECH.PARA: I have much pleasure in moving this motion because of the widespread concern in the wine industry, particularly amongst the wine grape growers of Australia, due to some of the recommendations in the report of that committee of inquiry.

PARA.TAB: The report is of great concern to the constituents of my own state of South Australia and also those of New South Wales in particular because between them those two states produce some 80 per cent of the grapes grown in Australia. Although other states contribute greatly towards the wine grape production and the wine industry in Australia, 51 per cent is grown in South Australia and 29 per cent is grown in New South Wales. I know the people in the industry in those two states are particularly concerned at the ramifications of any adoption of some of the recommendations in this inquiry.

As background, the Senate ought to know the place of the wine industry in Australia. Currently, there are some 68,000 hectares of Australia under vines; including something like 3,500 different establishments with a gross value of production of some $530 million; and the industry employs something like 5,000 people throughout Australia.

Of even more importance and concern to those grape growers is the fact that this government has followed a policy of increasing taxation on any industry which shows some signs of being successful. So there is great concern in the industry that it has at last managed to show some signs of success. It is fair to say that that industry is probably the only bright light in the rural economy. The industry is concerned that the recommendations of this inquiry would see an increase in taxation which would make it far more difficult for grape growers to continue on the successful path they have been on over the past few years.

It is also interesting to note that wine grape production has risen from 330,000 tonnes in the early 1970s to over 770,000 tonnes in 1993-94. That is in spite of the fact that in the early 1980s there was a vine-pull program because the industry was in such a state that it was in danger of becoming non-viable. Throughout Australia there are some 800 wineries, mainly small businesses and mostly owner-operated. Seven large companies produce 75 per cent of Australia's wine but there are 600 businesses which produce around two per cent of all the wine. It is important that we make sure that the smaller businesses, which are producing only two per cent of the wine, remain viable because of the employment they provide and because they have now reached the stage of just being able to stand on their own.

The committee of inquiry, amongst its recommendations, suggested that wine be subject to a composite tax, comprising an ad valorem wholesale tax and a volumetric tax based on alcohol content. It said the ad valorem component should be adjusted in accordance with any future adjustments to the general rate of wholesale tax and that the volumetric component be indexed to the consumer price index and be levied on wholesale sales in conjunction with the wholesale sales tax, not as an excise on production.

Any increase in the tax burden on the wine industry will represent a disaster for what has been one of the few bright lights in the rural economy, particularly over recent years. The regionally dispersed nature of the wine industry makes it a leading contributor to regional economies and its technological skill requirements and connection with urban and international markets makes it a contributor of expertise and business leadership that otherwise would be impossible to sustain in rural areas.

The structural shifts towards wine and wine consumption have been influenced by several factors. Amongst those factors are a change in diet towards Mediterranean and Asian food styles, reflecting both climate and health considerations; the increased dining out which is taking place today and a consequent shift in beverage choice; the increased consciousness of health issues leading towards a shift to fruit juices, flavoured milk and mineral and spring water, and away from alcoholic beverages in general—but with the health benefits of moderate wine consumption being recognised.

The road safety programs have led to a reduction in alcohol consumption. In my state of South Australia there used to be early closing and the 6 o'clock swill. It was certainly not what would be considered today to be a civilised attitude towards drinking patterns. There has been a reduction in alcohol consumption and a shift towards a moderate consumption with food; and a reduction of what we would always have called sessional drinking.

It also takes into account the changing role of women in society. We all accept that changing role with the economic and social dependence increasing the acceptability of women consuming alcohol which was not the case some time ago. We are pleased that that is also a change that has taken place and one which is generally accepted in our society. It is interesting to note the committee's conclusions as to whether wine is a luxury good or not. The report states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Some might argue that wine is a luxury characterised by occasional and discretionary purchasing patterns, being relatively price inelastic and having a relatively high income elasticity.

It is probable that a disaggregated analysis of wine consumption would establish that ultra-premium wine demonstrates many of the characteristics of a luxury. However, Mr Crosser and Professor Freebairn have elected to apply their taxation recommendations to all wine in a uniform fashion and therefore it is appropriate to measure wine's behaviour in aggregate fashion.

Wine is consumed uniformly across all age groups with the exception of the very young (18-24 years), both sexes, and comprises approximately the same proportion of household expenditure across all income groups (0.4 to 0.5 per cent), with the exception that it is a higher proportion of the lowest income quintile (0.87 per cent). The generally uniformed proportion of income spent on wines shows it is popular across all income groups.

There is no evidence that wine has an income elasticity of greater than one, while there is considerable demographic empirical evidence that wine has become an increasingly significant everyday component of Australian lifestyle.

In Mr Crosser and Professor Freebairn's judgment, wine in aggregate does not exhibit the luxury good behaviour of electronic goods, jewellery, leather goods or luxury cars which are taxed for revenue at 31 to 45 per cent of WST.

It is also worth noting that many real luxuries such as fashion clothing and gourmet meals are not taxed at all. The WST system is very inconsistent in its treatment of luxury items, demonstrating a lack of determination to target obvious luxury goods.

Australian wine is internationally competitive because of both its natural and man made advantages. We have in Australia the right environment, the right heritage of viticulture and winemaking, the right technological resources, the right scope for innovation, the right human resources, the right industry structure, the right amount of diversity and the right market signals. All of those things combined have over the past few years given us a very internationally competitive place in that market and one which cannot bear tampering with if the recommendations of this report or some of the recommendations to increase taxes in this report are adopted by this government.

PARA.TAB: The committee of inquiry recommends a specific tax on alcohol content to apply to wine to bring wine into line with other alcoholic products and to help offset costs associated with alcohol abuse. This argument ignores some very basic facts. For one thing, it is based on the premise that the current tax on other forms of alcohol—beer and spirits—is at the right level. I would question whether that basic premise is right at all. It also ignores that in both the production and consumption of wine, which I will outline shortly, there are some very basic differences.

However, I would first like to point out that at least part of this argument has the support of the Australian Democrats whose leader, Senator Kernot, in this place on 30 August 1993, when the increase in wine tax was being debated after the 1993 budget, said:

SPEECH.PARA: There may be a case for increasing the tax rate on wine to bring it more into line with other alcoholic beverages such as beer, but not at the expense of the viability of an increasingly export oriented industry.

The later part of these remarks would suggest that Senator Kernot may have been well intentioned in her position, however, she missed the point that comparing the wine industry with the beer industry is like comparing apples with oranges. She also missed the point that any tax increase in wine would have a significant effect on the Australian wine industry's attempts to compete on world markets.

PARA.TAB: Let us talk about some of the wine production differences. For a start, you only get a grape crop once a year. It is subject to seasonal variations, so it is totally different and totally unlike other forms of alcohol production.

Investments made in vineyards are locked in over a period of time. Decisions made four years ago are now starting to bear fruit and over the next couple of years some return on that investment will start to be realised. But once the investment is made, it is locked in. As this investment has already been made under a certain set of rules, to change the taxation arrangements later has a tremendously adverse effect on that investment, particularly in the wine industry. There is a three- and four-year lead time to expand grape supply, the annual utilisation of the winery processing equipment is limited to some three or four months, the time to market for quality bottled wine is one to three years and there is a high degree of value adding. There is value adding seven times in wine production. There is an extent of vertical integration, and human skill, judgment and creativity are required.

I mention the differences between the consumption of wine and the consumption of other alcoholic beverages. Demographically, wine tends to be consumed by an older age group of people and by a higher proportion of females. The place of consumption has a great effect on our social lives and impacts on society. The interesting thing is that the main place for wine consumption is either the home or the restaurant. In many cases, I think wine adds to the quality of life in our society because of its place of consumption.

In relation to the occasion of consumption, over 80 per cent of wine consumed is consumed with food or with a meal. This certainly has a health benefit and certainly leads to fewer social problems, particularly with regard to drink driving and other things of that nature. Then there is beverage choice behaviour. If people in that environment are not drinking wine, they prefer non-alcoholic alternatives. Overall, these patterns show moderate consumption of wine. That has been proved over time.

I will talk briefly about the wine industry because I know that my colleagues have contributions they want to make. The wine industry in Australia has been very successful. It has successfully, and perhaps uniquely, combined market responsiveness with quality focus, value adding, technological sophistication and social responsibility.

If one of the reasons there is a recommendation to increase the taxes on wines is to offset the cost of treatment of alcohol abuse, I think it does not take into account the fact that the wine industry, above all others, has been very conscious of consumption behaviour. Although there will always be extremes and there will always be people who abuse alcohol, the moderate consumption patterns of wine have led the wine industry to be a very responsible one. It has been very socially responsible.

We also foresee a problem in the timing of this report. In 1995 the wine industry is suffering some adversity. It looks like there will be a 200,000 tonne loss of grapes from the 1995 vintage due to drought and cost increases from higher grape prices. There is an increase in the wholesale sales tax anyway from 24 per cent to 26 per cent in July and a two per cent or more interest rate rise adds to the cost and the working capital requirements of holding wine stocks for maturation. There is also a fall in domestic wine sales of some 1.6 per cent for 1994, including a 2.4 per cent fall in cask wine for the 12 months to January 1995.

There has been widespread concern. The reason I have raised this issue in the Senate this week is that I think the wine industry, and particularly the wine grape growers, who are my particular concern, needs to have some of those worries alleviated by the government rejecting both the majority and minority report recommendations for an increase in wine taxes.

It seems as though this government is prepared to tax anything that moves and it seems to be also taxing lots of things that do not move. The current uncertainty brought about by the release of this report can be alleviated by the government announcing that it will reject both the majority and minority report with regard to increases in wine taxes. It will take away the uncertainty in the industry and it will reinstate investment confidence. The wine industry is one that currently has a lot of positive investment and these investments are being made in the long term. They need to be made with the investors having the certainty that they will be under the same rules they thought they were going to be under when they made that initial investment.

I have a particular concern for the grape growers, which is the same concern I have always had for primary producers. The grape growers, who are primary producers, are price takers and not price setters. All of the difficulties we have seen in primary industries over the past few years are due to the fact that the primary producers have no control over the amount they receive for the goods they produce. Regardless of the cost of production, they take only what the market offers. But, because it value adds, the wine industry can be a price setter. It can reclaim its costs. It can make sure that it sells its product at a profit while the grape growers cannot.

Currently, the grape growers are undergoing a boom. Although production is down significantly this year—by up to 40 per cent in some places in the Barossa Valley—the increase in prices means that the growers are remaining viable and are going through good times. I remember a time, not so very long ago, particularly in the vine-pull era, when they were struggling just to hang on to their properties. I therefore urge this government to reject the recommendations of this commission of inquiry for an increase in taxes so that this industry, which has a target of $1 billion of exports by the year 2000, is allowed to get on with its job without any impediments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in this debate on Senator Ferguson's motion relating to the wine grape industry. Our wine industry is one of Australia's success stories. It is most appropriate that the draft report of the committee of inquiry into the wine grape industry in Australia be debated at this time and over the next few months as the final report is being prepared. The issue will be open to further comment when the second round of hearings begin in a few months.

PARA.TAB: Reading through the notice of motion before the Senate this afternoon, I was concerned that only the tax issue was being emphasised.
