When I look at the very last section of it I see that we are being asked, prematurely, to urge the government to reject part of what is only an interim report. By all means, senators should be free to express opposition to it—I will be talking about the Australian Democrats' opposition in just a moment—but I do not believe that it is appropriate, when a report is in a draft form, has not been presented to government and the government has not responded, that we should start urging the government to reject certain sections of it.

Obviously, the recommendations will not be acted upon in this year's budget because the government does not yet have the final report. We are not expecting to see any changes in this year's budget as a result of anything that might be in this interim report. It is fine for us to express our opposition here today, but we must look at the specifics of the motion. For example, I note that part (a) section (ii) refers to the Australian Democrats and the fact that we favour tax increases over expenditure cuts as a means of deficit reduction. The Democrats are happy to say that we favour a fair and adequate tax system rather than ongoing expenditure cuts.

I note here some comments made in this chamber yesterday by Senator Gibson and Senator Abetz about what is happening in New Zealand, and praising the New Zealand economy. The Industry Commission would have been happy with that debate; it was all about numbers and economic indicators with absolutely nothing about people. Senator Abetz said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard here today, so ably set out by Senator Gibson, that New Zealand is now truly bringing home the bacon . . .

I ask the senator what that means for people and what effect the policies of that government have on individual New Zealanders. In an article in the Bulletin of 28 March, titled `NZ's forgotten children', the New Zealand Commissioner for Children, Laurie O'Reilly, says:
We are heading towards a socially toxic environment. No longer can we see New Zealand as a safe place for children and families.
He then goes on to give some statistics:
. New Zealand has the highest youth suicide rate in the industrialised world.
. It has the sixth highest infant death rate from child abuse.

PARA.TAB: The country also has the industrialised world's second highest percentage of single-parent families, a state which a UNICEF report last year described as having "a close and consistent connection" with children growing up in poverty.

A Public Health Commission survey in February this year found that 22,600 schoolchildren were perceived by teachers to be regularly hungry, and more than one in three schools provide free food for some pupils.

A Department of Social Welfare Study, also published in February, found that 365 charity food banks across the country distributed more than 40,000 food parcels a month to families, a high proportion to solo mothers.

SPEECH.PARA: There are only 900,000 New Zealanders under the age of 17, so they are really startling statistics. The final point about this economy that the Liberal Party likes to trumpet as being so successful is this:

PARA.TAB: Salvation Army figures show that the number of people it provided with food parcels nearly quadrupled from 2124 in the first quarter of 1991—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order: I am wondering what relevance this has to Senator Ferguson's general business notice of motion on the wine tax.
—I am addressing specifically the general business notice of motion on the wine tax, part (a), section (ii), where you have stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Australian Democrats have both indicated that they favour tax increases over expenditure cuts as a means of deficit reduction . . .
I point out that what your colleagues said yesterday about New Zealand only included economic indicators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order.
—I will start that final quote again:

PARA.TAB: Salvation Army figures show that the number of people it provided with food parcels nearly quadrupled from 2124 in the first quarter of 1991, before major benefits cuts of up to 25%, to 10,261 in the same period the following year. In the first three months of 1994, it topped 14,900.

SPEECH.PARA: That is just a small sample of what is happening to people in New Zealand. If we look further in this motion, after some comments about the wine industry itself and various characteristics of it we see there are some comments on the recent draft report, which is really what we are talking about today.

PARA.TAB: I would like to go back in history a little bit and look at how this inquiry came about. The Democrats insisted upon this inquiry as part of the compromise package negotiated after the 1993 budget. As I said at the time, the Democrats wanted to see an industry plan developed—that is, a plan for the wine industry that would enable the development of a comprehensive package for the industry.

The Democrats will continue to oppose any increase in tax on wine unless any such rise can be demonstrated as an acceptable and integral part of an industry plan. I do not believe that anything I have read in this draft report supports the minority view of Mr Scales that any tax increases for the wine industry can be justified. The Democrat stance remains consistent, and we look forward to seeing further justification by Mr Scales in the final report because he is a long way from proving his case that there is a need for any increases. We were opposed to the involvement of the Industry Commission in this inquiry in the first place. On 7 October 1993, I said:

The government's offer that the Industry Commission can conduct a study is unacceptable to the Democrats. In its current form the commission, with it entrenched ideological bias towards extreme economic rationalism, is not going to be the way to proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: All I will say now is that what we were concerned about has actually happened. The stamp of the Industry Commission goes far further than Mr Scales's minority report as far as the taxes are concerned. I hate to do it but I really cannot resist the temptation to say to the industry, `We told you so.' The outcome it wanted may be a long way from happening following the involvement of the Industry Commission.

PARA.TAB: I believe it is far too early to actually be asking the government to reject any parts of this report. We still have several months of negotiations, discussions and hearings to go. To debate the merits or otherwise of this draft report is certainly appropriate. Hopefully, what we are also doing as members of this place is encouraging grape growers, wine makers, those involved in this industry—particularly those employed in the industry—regional tourist authorities, wine companies, regional development authorities and those interested in the future of the Murray-Darling Basin to get involved, give an input and express their concerns, if they have any, about this draft report. They can do that either by written response or, as they have been invited to do in this report, by participating in the next round of hearings.

I will now look specifically at the tax issues. The Democrats do not believe that there is any case presented in the draft report that supports the minority view. However, we congratulate the majority finding, which is based on evidence, that a shift towards a volumetric tax is to be recommended. The industry has in the past acknowledged that, for some people, the consumption of wine is a health hazard. The industry has used its own resources to contribute to the national harm minimisation goals by, for example, introducing clear indicators on wine containers and bottles that show how many glasses or standard drinks are in each container. That is something that the alcohol industry has finally recognised and will adopt generally.

The industry has also realised that telling men and women how many standard drinks per day is safe is only part of the solution. People must then be able to judge what a standard drink is. I see the recommendation of the inquiry as an extension of this commitment to harm minimisation. The industry has acknowledged that its product can be misused and, indeed, is misused and that it must contribute to the results.

I will now outline the major problem. While I believe the industry has been doing what it should be doing in this area, the government certainly has not. I draw the attention of the Senate to a recent report of the Alcohol and Other Drugs Council of Australia entitled Drugs, Money and Government. This report looks at the amount of money collected by government through wine taxes, alcohol taxes and tobacco taxes. It then looks at the actual expenditure that government makes on various drug and alcohol programs.

We can see from the executive summary of that report that it has been conservatively estimated that drug abuse actually costs the community more than $14.3 billion each year. When we look at these statistics we find that very little is actually made up by government in terms of government expenditure. Government collects vast amounts of revenue from both alcohol and tobacco taxes. This varies from state to state, but obviously the Commonwealth adds to that.

The actual proportion of this revenue that is then put back into drug and alcohol programs is minuscule. Page 7 of this report refers to revenue and indicates that the Commonwealth raised $3.8 billion from these taxes, but actually only returned one per cent of that to drug programs. Funding per head of population amounts to only $2.06.

The Democrats will be very cautious about even moving in the direction that the majority recommends until we see some evidence that the government is actually going to put that money towards the drug and alcohol programs that it is supposedly collecting that money for. One of the recommendations of ADCA is that governments must make more money available for prevention, research, education, intervention and treatment of drug related problems. The amount of money being spent has to be increased and has to be sustained. Therefore, the Democrats will be very reluctant to support a shift to a composite tax until such time as we see the federal government expenditure on these programs significantly increased.

In closing, I will mention a few other concerns the Democrats have. Again I go back to the emphasis on tax which we have seen in the media generally and in this place today. This is overshadowing a huge number of other recommendations in this report, some of which are very positive. If we look at the recommendations in this report relating to tax, we find that they account for only nine out of 38. I again ask those members interested in the industry to read further and to get involved in the other issues.

Of particular concern to the Democrats is chapter 7, on irrigation and water issues. While we agree that there should be price incentives for water efficiency and adjustment towards that, and penalties for contributing to river salinity, there are no recommendations in here that tell us how we get from where we are now to where the industry eventually has to be. We need to look at a variety of solutions rather than just the broad brush approach of charging full price for water and freeing up licences by open auction. Again I see this section as being heavily influenced by the economic rationalists in the Industry Commission. The Democrats will be looking at putting in a full response to this section of the report and other sections. I hope that the Liberal Party will also be putting its comments in writing to the committee as the debate continues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this motion moved by my colleague Senator Ferguson. It is very sad that 18 months after the last wine sales tax debacle we are lining up yet again for another tax impost on one of the most successful industries in Australia. We debated this issue extremely thoroughly 18 months ago. We had the Democrats initially supporting us on this issue, quite correctly, but they eventually went to water under pressure from the government. I ask them to consider what they did last time, to consider the people in the regional areas in one of our most successful industries and to support the growth of the industry by stopping this tax which will kill the goose that lays the golden eggs.

PARA.TAB: The government has a habit of doing finding a growth industry and taxing it to death. The government should realise that it will end up with greater revenue in the long run if it leaves these taxes off. Last time the government proposed an increase in the sales tax on wine from 20 to 32 per cent first up—a massive 55 per cent increase in one hit. An industry with the potential of $1 billion a year in export income by year 2000 would have been cut off at the knees if that measure had gone ahead then. There would have been a permanent loss of jobs in the wine industry of 45 per cent at a time when the country had 800,000 people unemployed.

Yet the government is proposing further increases in sales taxes, which will have exactly the same effect—to cut jobs. Not only will it cut jobs; it will cut investment. You do not plant a grape vine, harvest it a few weeks later, produce a bottle of wine and sell it a few weeks later. This is a long-term process. If twice in 18 months the government proposes to put up taxes, what is the effect on business people who are thinking about money invested and returns seven, eight, or nine years out? I will tell the government the effect: they do not invest. If you look at the total effect of what you are doing in the long-term, you might get more marginal revenue from increasing taxes now, but 10 years down the track you will be taking in a lot less industry and you will have created a lot more unemployment.

Labor does not seem to have learnt from this debacle. It is right that we raise these issues now. The Democrats' representative Senator Lees said: `Why are you bringing this up now? This is only an interim report.' We want to create a groundswell in the community, starting to protest long and loud before it is a fait accompli on budget night, that they do not want increases in taxes on wine, that they do not want tax increases that will destroy jobs, that they do not want tax increases that will destroy our already weak and fragile rural and regional infrastructure. Why kill one of our best industries? The government is proposing just that.

I mentioned that due to the complicity of the Democrats 18 months ago the government managed to get through some increases—not the huge increases it originally proposed, but a graduated sales tax increase to 26 per cent from 21 per cent originally on 1 July this year.

The package that was brought in at that point included some concessions on depreciation rates and grants for export wine promotion. A national inquiry into the wine industry was also announced. That is why we have this problem today, because that inquiry, headed by Bill Scales of the Industry Commission, has been taking evidence since mid-1994 and has now come down with a very alarming interim report. There will be further public comment until the final report goes to the government in June 1995. That is why, unlike what the Democrats have suggested this afternoon, we are saying that the public, particularly regional and rural Australia, which has been dudded again by this government, should be protesting that the government is trying to kill off yet another successful industry with these tax measures.

Already, across the wine industry and the grape growing industry, alarm bells have been ringing about the two main options put forward in this report. Let us look at the options that this report is suggesting. In the draft report, the commissioners were unable to agree on the amount of tax that should be paid on Australian wine at the wholesale level. There was agreement on the format that the indirect tax on wine should take. Instead of the present straight sales tax mechanism, it was recommended that the industry should pay a rate of sales tax plus a volumetric tax to be set at $4 a litre of alcohol. This option is a disaster for the wine industry. The majority of the commissioners opted for a wholesale sales tax of 10 per cent plus the volumetric tax of $4 a litre of alcohol to be phased in between now and 1998. The impact of this measure has been set out starkly by Hunter Valley vigneron Bruce Tyrrell in the Newcastle Herald today. Under the first option the price of a wine cask would increase by $1.50. Also, wines which currently sell for about $5 or less would become more expensive and those over $5 would be cheaper. Clearly, the increase in price at the cheaper end of the market and the wine cask would have the effect of putting wine outside the reach of low income earners. The price increase would take the marginal drinker back to beer, which has received a reduction in tax for lower alcohol products. Where is the logic in curtailing the growing wine industry with tax policies which would benefit the foreign-owned brewing industry?

The second tax option in this report is more horrendous for the wine industry. It would see sales tax go up to 32 per cent, plus a $4 volumetric tax. A $10 bottle of wine would increase by $1—a 10 per cent increase, which is way out of line with inflation, quite obviously—and a wine cask would increase by $3. Bruce Tyrrell from the Hunter Valley, whom I mentioned earlier, claims that this second option would see domestic sales decline by up to 20 per cent immediately. It is disgraceful, when we are trying to get growth in exports, that the government would even consider a proposal like this.

This debate is timely in order to lay out the options that this Labor government has waiting for the Australian wine industry. Budget decisions based on either or a mix of these recommendations would show that the ALP has no regard for the industry and the employment potential for rural and regional Australia. The marginal seats in the next federal election, including Paterson and Hunter in New South Wales and McEwen in Victoria, will be waiting to pass judgment on this issue. I am sure my colleague Senator Troeth will have something to say about that a little later.

The Australian wine industry, like its vines, must be nurtured with care. Tax policies such as those being proposed could destroy the industry very quickly. There is already a noticeable decline, because of the tax measures which the government has introduced over the last 18 months, in the rate of growth of our wine exports. An inappropriate and harsh tax policy could totally cripple this industry and leave an oversupply of wine from when recent plantings begin producing.

The wine industry, consumers and regional Australia await with dread the outcome of this report and what the government is proposing to do. Today we call on the Australian Democrats not to buckle like they did last time, but to support the wine industry, support rural and regional Australia, support increased growth in exports and support increased growth in our economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am particularly pleased to support the motion of my colleague Senator Ferguson. With regard to Senator Lees's comments that it is rather early in the piece to be having a debate on the wine industry, I point out to her that it would be extremely remiss of responsible senators not to flag the issues involved and talk about them at this stage.

PARA.TAB: My electorate office in Victoria is located next to the federal seat of McEwen, which encompasses one of the best wine producing regions in the country. There are some 50 wineries in the electorate, and they are a typical mix of large industry operations and small family vineyards. A few of these include Mitchelton Wines, the DeBortoli winery, the Delatite winery and the Cleveland winery.

Any increase in the wine tax, such as is proposed in this report, would have devastating consequences for the wine industry. Seasonal effects of drought and frost are already hurting grape growers badly, and the Australian Bureau of Statistics is forecasting a 50,000 tonne shortfall of grapes in the 1995 vintage, which follows a 30,000 tonne shortfall in the 1994 vintage. Bad weather has imposed cuts in grape yields, which is expected to lift grape prices 20 per cent as it is. Recent drought and frosts have cut yields by between 20 and 30 per cent in some areas. On 10 March this year, the Sydney Morning Herald reported:

SPEECH.PARA: The 1995 wine grape harvest, hit by drought and other adverse weather, is a disaster that will cost the industry an estimated $500 million and force up prices by an unprecedented 10 to 15 per cent.

In addition, the industry is already being harmed by an unfavourable exchange rate. Given these existing factors, this is the worst time to be even considering an extra tax on wine producers. To add insult to injury, this is the third time since the federal government's introduction of a sales tax on wine that an increase in the tax rate has been floated.

PARA.TAB: As it is, the current tax system provides little incentive for growers to produce grapes for higher quality wines. As my colleague Senator Tierney pointed out, it takes around seven years to get a bottle of wine on the market. For this to occur effectively, it is essential for planning purposes that winemakers have some certainty in taxation policy. The new tax regime being proposed by the Industry Commission is an attempt to bring the tax on wine into line with that for spirits and beer. Stephen Shelmerdine, the President of the Victorian Wine Industry Association, said that this regime does not:

SPEECH.PARA: reflect the different production base, manufacturing processes, stockholding levels, consumption patterns, regional economic contribution, tourism aspects, investment time frames, export potential and cultural composition.

The proposed tax changes to wine could net the federal government an extra $200 million per year—almost double the present tax take from the industry of about $265 million a year. At the extreme end of the proposal, as Senator Tierney outlined, consumers could expect to pay an extra $1 for a $10 bottle of wine and an extra $2.76 for an $8 cask of wine.

PARA.TAB: In the past, tax increases have led to a slowing in consumption. In 1986 when sales tax on wine went from 10 per cent to 20 per cent, the Australian wine industry lost 3.9 litres per capita per annum of domestic consumption over a five-year period. That cost the industry $200 million per year in lost sales, 64 million litres per annum of less wine, 90,000 tonnes per annum less grapes from 9,000 hectares of potential vines, 1,000 potential jobs in vineyards and 1,000 potential jobs in wineries.
The BRL Hardy Managing Director, Mr Stephen Millar, was quoted in the Australian Financial Review on 14 March this year as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: It is just outrageous to severely disrupt an industry which is earning valuable export dollars, creating tourism, providing jobs, acting as a model for value adding and which has done more than its fair share in promoting alcohol in moderation.

In 1993, when the government was proposing wine tax increases as part of the budget, I remember the present member for McEwen, Mr Cleeland, making a lot of noise opposing any increases. At the time I was pleasantly surprised that Mr Cleeland should be taking such a concerned position in relation to all the wine producers who would be so badly affected by any increase in tax. Mr Cleeland was quoted as saying:

. . . all we (the Government) have done is penalise wine producers for their efforts by increasing the tax on wine . . . The Prime Minister and the Treasurer have lost sight of the most important economic issue facing the country, the current account deficit, which is not really diminishing at all. They appear to have forgotten that exports are crucial if we are to turn the current account deficit around.

Those were Mr Cleeland's very words. These comments are somewhat ironic in view of the confirmed increase in the current account deficit in the 20 months since that time. The press release went on to say:
Mr Cleeland said it was clear that the economic advice of Treasury was still being followed to the letter despite the fact that Treasury was dangerously out of touch with reality.

It is somewhat of a first for me to find myself actually endorsing comments by the present member for McEwen. However, Mr Cleeland, despite registering his opposition to the increase in the wine tax in the 1993 budget, still voted for it. It is all very well for Mr Cleeland to get up in the other place and say that he really cares about the people in his electorate, the people who work in those wineries that I detailed at the start of my remarks, but it might have been more beneficial if he had done more than just pay lip service to the sentiments but not take any action to defeat them.

PARA.TAB: I would be very happy to be corrected, but I have not seen any comments by Mr Cleeland in relation to this most recent proposition to increase wine tax and I wonder why it is that Mr Cleeland has not seen fit to defend his constituents in relation to this issue. In regard to his comments on the current account deficit, which he said, you will remember, is not really diminishing at all, one might have assumed that since he was so concerned with this fact two years ago he must positively be beside himself today with the March figures showing a $2.2 billion current account deficit. Continuing high levels of export wine would play a role in reducing this amount and the wine industry is very typical of the positive attitude that we need to provide exports.

If our wine is to be really competitive overseas, we must start to come in line with those countries with which we compete. In 1993, Californian wine was taxed at 50c a litre and French wine was taxed at 67c a litre. At that time, if all the 1993 budget hikes had gone through, Australian wine would have been taxed at $1.47 a litre.

The regional nature of wine production, as both my colleagues Senator Tierney and Senator Ferguson remarked, means that whole areas will be hurt by increasing taxes which may lead to a drop in investment or different business arrangements by wine growers. Wine growing is an important source of employment, especially in rural and regional areas. Casual seasonal work provides important additional income for rural families. The work in vineyards and wineries gives rural people and particularly women a chance to make extra income for their families over the 12-month seasonal growing period.

Given an increase in the wine tax, the negative effects on employment give lie to the government's reputed concern about the number of jobless Australians, particularly in rural and regional areas. I conclude by reiterating in the strongest sense my opposition to any increase in the wine tax. A further tax on wine is a tax on exports and is a direct deterrent to future investment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ferguson's motion before us today urges the government to reject the wine industry inquiry's recommendations for further increases in the wine tax. I have great pleasure in speaking in support of that motion. I congratulate Senator Ferguson on bringing it before the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Before I go on, I want to reflect upon Senator Lees's quite extraordinary intervention into this debate with the matter of New Zealand. None of us could quite work out its relevance to this debate about the Australian wine industry. For some reason, she departed from the issue to discuss New Zealand and again exhibited the Australian Democrats' unbelievable ignorance of economics. Clearly, these people are the great economic irrationalists of Australia. They hate free markets and do not understand that good economic performance means good outcomes for people. They keep insisting that those who talk numbers are not talking people, which simply reflects their incredible ignorance of how one gets good outcomes for people.

I recently spent a week in New Zealand. The performance of its economy is outstanding. It has lower unemployment, much higher growth and much better industrial relations than us. It is leaving this economy behind. Therefore, New Zealanders will very soon have a higher standard of living than Australians. The Democrats have a lot to learn about what is good for people.

I want to base my comments this evening on the subject that is before us, which is the wine industry. I want to focus particularly on the devastating regional impact that further increases in wine tax will have, particularly for the state of South Australia, which a number of us represent. The impact will be particularly devastating there.

I place on the record how important the wine industry is to the state of South Australia. Many people are ignorant of the fact that South Australia, which is a relatively small state, nevertheless accounts for 51 per cent of total national wine production. It accounts for 48 per cent of total employment in the wine industry. About 2,500 people are directly employed in South Australia in the wine industry. South Australia is responsible for no less than 65 per cent of all wine exported from Australia. Wine produced in South Australia represents seven per cent of the value of South Australian exports. Clearly, this industry is vital to the state of South Australia.

I balance that position by referring to the economic position of South Australia, which remains very fragile. That is a result of the fact that for 23 of the last 30 years we have had state Labor governments in South Australia. Surprisingly, for 15 of the last 23 years, we have had Labor governments federally.

TALK.START.PARA: —A double disaster.

—Exactly. As my colleague Senator Chapman says, this double disaster has had a devastating impact on the state of South Australia. We have only had a year in South Australia to try to correct the damage done to it over nearly 30 years by Labor. Labor left South Australia with a residue of massive debt, very low growth and very high unemployment relative to the rest of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The federal government goes on and on about the terrific results in national growth that we now have following the recession. On the face of it, the national growth figures are reasonably good following the devastation of the recession. But these overall figures disguise what is really going on in Australia. The fact is that, under Labor, Australia has become two nations. It is no longer one nation. It is severely divided into two countries. Queensland and Western Australia are growing very much faster than the rest of Australia. Those two states form one nation, while the rest fall a long way behind. Senator Sherry's state of Tasmania is also doing very badly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—Because of Labor governments, as he should well know. Growth in the year to September 1994 nationally was 6.3 per cent. But it disguises this very important point, which Senator Sherry insists on ignoring. In Western Australia, growth was 10.1 per cent, and in Queensland it was 9.4 per cent. Look at the other states. South Australia had only 1.7 per cent in the year to September 1994, which covered the tail end of that disastrous Labor government. Tasmania had only 0.1 per cent growth. Again, that reflects the residue of many years of Labor government in that state.

PARA.TAB: These are really very alarming differentials. Tragically, the federal government seems to be completely indifferent to this very important fact. It continues to talk in the dream world of one national economy when, quite clearly from these figures, there is no national economy. The difference between Tasmania's economic growth of 0.1 per cent and Western Australia's 10.1 per cent in the year to September 1994 is quite alarming and represents a massive difference.

Terry McCrann wrote a very good article in the Weekend Australian of 11-12 February, which I commend to everybody, particularly the government, about this problem of having two nations. In particular, he described the facts as I have put them and then went on to explain why he believes this federal Labor government is so indifferent to this fact and governing as though this fact did not exist. As he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The perceptions of Australia and command of the policy debate are captured in the Sydney-Melbourne-Canberra axis, where 6 out of 10 Australians live, including all—
I say all—
the decision-makers.

The problem is that we really have what is very much a Sydney-Canberra government—most of its members come from Sydney and are guided by bureaucrats in Canberra. There are a couple from Tasmania and hardly any from South Australia. They completely ignore the four out of 10 Australians who do not live in the Sydney-Melbourne-Canberra axis.

PARA.TAB: The real problem for regional economies like South Australia and Tasmania is particularly highlighted in the deliberate government policy of high interest rates aimed at restraining growth, which on the face of it appears high, for the national economy as a whole. But South Australia is only growing at 1.7 per cent and Tasmania at 0.1 per cent. These economies are hardly overheating; they are hardly in need of a high interest rate policy to contain growth. It shows how ludicrous the government's macro-economic policy really is.

So you do have a very fragile South Australian economy that is growing at only 1.7 per cent after all those years of inept, incompetent Labor government. Any further increase in the tax on the wine industry—an industry which is so vital to South Australia—would have a particularly devastating effect in that state.

I will describe some of those effects. The South Australian Development Council estimated that if the recommendations in the minority report by Mr Bill Scales were introduced, they would result in the loss of 8,000 hectares in new plantings of grapes and a loss of over 1,000 jobs in South Australia alone. Just this week in the Adelaide Advertiser, Southcorp Wines revealed that it is seriously considering placing on hold $15 million worth of vineyard investment because of its concerns with this draft report of the wine industry inquiry. So the situation is quite serious: if this report were implemented, it would have a huge impact in South Australia.

Unfortunately, what worries us on this side is the contempt which Labor has consistently shown for South Australia. The Labor government was responsible for the $3,000 million lost by the State Bank in South Australia—the biggest corporate loss in Australian history and one which South Australians will be repaying and my nine- and four-year-old children will be repaying for the rest of their lives. The wine tax, which most impacts on South Australia, has already been increased by this government by nearly one-third in the last two years. The rate will have gone from 20 per cent to 26 per cent by July this year. So we have already had a one-third increase in tax. We do not need any more tax increases. I urge the government to reject completely this proposal for any further increases.

Most particularly, I hope the government will reject the proposal for what amounts to an additional tax levied on the alcohol content. That is the killer disguised in this report—the introduction of a new tax on wine. If this government accepts this report, it will be guilty of introducing a new tax on the wine industry and a new tax on Australians in the form of this proposition that there should be some special tax based on alcohol content.

I was horrified today to hear the Australian Democrats indicate their willingness to support such a proposition. I hope every grape grower, every wine industry person in South Australia and everybody employed in the wine industry in South Australia takes careful note of what the Democrats revealed today—their support for a new additional tax on wine and on the people of Australia in the form of this special tax on alcohol content.

The proposition that there should be some sort of community tax because of the effects of alcohol really is absurd. You might as well have a special tax on motor vehicles because people get killed by motor vehicles; or a special tax on coffee because coffee is bad for people's health. The proposition is ludicrous. The industry is taxed heavily enough already. We do not need a new tax on wine. I urge the government to reject this draft report.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Sherry would like to speak before me to defend his Tasmanian wine growers against any increased tax, I would be happy to let him to do so. Perhaps he does not want to. I will keep the length of my remarks commensurate with the size of the wine industry in my electorate. There are only two wine growers in the Australian Capital Territory but it is an important industry in the region. A number of groups, such as the Canberra Region Campaign, look at the area as a region. That is much more appropriate for the size of the population and everything else.

PARA.TAB: Within the Canberra region, including Murrumbateman, Queanbeyan and Bungendore, there are 17 wineries of which approximately eight are full-time professional operations and 21 wine growers who grow grapes for sale to other people. The whole economy in the ACT relies on small business—and these are part of those small businesses. Any impact on them is significant to the whole of the community. The wineries here are all family run operations, normally not employing extra staff but doing so at peak periods and other particular times during the year. It is expected that production this year will be around 25,000 cases, the biggest crop for 20 years. The industry is growing and expanding. One tour operator specialises in wine tours in this district. At different times of the year there are promotions and other tourist activity which are a significant part of our economy.

I found the remarks of Senator Lees most incredible. She suggested that it was inappropriate for us to be debating this matter today. She suggested to the government that it should reject the increases in tax which are proposed in the draft recommendations to the report. I would have thought that it would be more appropriate, given the report and recommendations are a draft, for us all to be expressing our views now on what that means.

When I first looked at the recommendations they looked a bit like a draft April Fool's Day production for some newspaper. To ignore the opportunity to tell the committee what we think would be very foolish. I did not follow the argument of Senator Lees, who suggested that the wine industry, the tourist industry and all these other groups should respond to the draft report but that the Senate ought not have a say. It seems to me to be totally appropriate for us to express this afternoon our views on the impact these recommendations would have on the businesses and industries in our electorates. I urge the government to make it quite plain, right now, that there will be no further increase in tax on the wine industry. The committee can then get on with drafting its final report and recommendations, hearing loudly and clearly what the views are.

A dramatic increase in tax, as this report recommends, would have a great impact on the small wineries; and the wineries in the Canberra region are all small. The impact on them would be much greater than would be a similar increase in tax on the larger wineries. If we are to do anything to help the smaller wineries and make them more attractive as small businesses and as part of a tourist industry, we should take away the sales tax on cellar door sales—or something of that nature to give them an opportunity to succeed. To increase exports to try to achieve the target of $1 billion by the year 2000 would entail considerable investment in the wine industry. It can be achieved only if there is a stable domestic market and that has to be the basis of any export market. No industry can maintain a strong export effort without a strong and stable domestic market.

The sales already indicate some decline, and that decline will only steepen if another tax is placed upon wine at the present time. Export growth must have continued investment, but wine growers and winemakers are not going to be able to put money into investing further to meet the year 2000 target if they are going to be hit so hard by the additional taxes recommended in this report.

It is the smaller wineries and the tourism that so often goes with the smaller wineries which will be affected. The impact will not just be on the wineries themselves, on the restaurants and the other tourism industries in their vicinity. It really is a most extraordinary thing that for an industry like this, which really has been doing quite well, is growing, export markets are growing, overseas acceptance and liking of Australian wines is obviously increasing, anyone could contemplate a course of action which would interfere with that. It really defies imagination.

The wineries in the ACT district are ones which would be, like other small wineries, particularly affected. We do not need this sort of thing. I will not go into detail as Senator Ferguson has done. As I said, I will keep my remarks in time consistent with the size of the industry in my electorate. I support wholeheartedly the motion put forward by Senator Ferguson. I hope all of the Senate will adopt that approach and tell the committee inquiring into the industry that it is on the wrong tram.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the suggestions, proposals and recommendations that were made by the inquiry into the wine industry. In some contrast to Senator Reid's position, the wine industry is indeed an extremely important and extensive one in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: The turnover per annum in the 1992-93 year was $285 million. Victoria does represent some 20 per cent of national wine production and it is at the level of 100 million litres of wine. In 1993 there were over 1,800 establishments involved in viticulture. Traditionally, and perhaps still most importantly, along the Murray approximately 1,600 establishments are concentrated, reaching down into the Mallee. Sunraysia is the second biggest producing region after the Riverland in South Australia.

The industry is of course growing and spreading right across the whole state. Vineyards have been established in the far south-west in the Hamilton-Portland area; the Otways, including around Geelong and Werribee; western Victoria, the Grampians and the Pyrenees where some excellent high quality wines are now produced; central Victoria, Bendigo-Heathcote and Macedon; Gippsland, Bairnsdale and Leongatha; the north east, the King and Oven Valleys; the Mornington Peninsula near Dromana and Merricks; and of course the Yarra Valley regions close to Melbourne. Perhaps the most famous of them all is the Rutherglen area where one of the world's acknowledged best wines in the so-called stickies, the dessert wines, the muscats, the ports, the tokays, the frontignacs are produced.

The wine industry is an extremely important industry for Victoria. This is also reflected in the employment that it provides. Several thousand jobs depend on it directly and the estimated multiplier of at least two—I would suggest three—extends it into the industries of tourism and generally the hospitality industry which, to a large extent, is now intertwined with the wine industry in Victoria.

As a consumer, I happily acknowledge, but more importantly as a proud promoter—whenever I have visitors from overseas, I make sure they get to know first hand the wine industry in Victoria—and, of course, as the Democrat spokesperson on industry and regional development, my personal view is that the recommendations made by Mr Bill Scales for an effective increase in wine taxation should be rejected firmly and categorically. I know that the process is not completed and I know that it may be said that it is a little premature for us to be doing that, but that certainly is my strong reaction from my first-hand knowledge of the wine industry, which is primarily based on my contacts and my direct experience in Victoria.

There are two specific reasons I make that statement. I think the concept of avoiding tax distortions between products is fine as a textbook, economic, theoretical approach, but this approach fails to take account of community impacts of what people like Mr Scales like to call `industry adjustment'. There is a big difference between levying an industry which is marketing a mass product throughout the nation, such as the beer industry, and belting an industry which is located in pockets of geographic concentration.

Secondly, the knock-on effects of adjustment for grape downs supporting non-premium wine might be significant both economically and socially. Bold economic assessments of avoiding relative economic price distortions do not take into account these sorts of community impacts which we will get and which people who live in those areas will experience. I believe it is the human, economic and social aspects of these changes and these recommendations that the government, the parliament and this chamber must take into account.

I pick out just one other aspect of the recommendations made; that is, more funding is required for viticulture courses in country TAFE colleges. Of course, that is a recommendation that we must support; however, the Industry Commission representative then seems to argue that since the wine industry will benefit, the wine industry should pay. My concept of education is that it is a function of government, that it is provided to the community by government out of taxes raised. If we enter into a situation where we say that people must pay for education, we are entering a period of inequality because education offers opportunity for employment.

If we say, `You cannot have education, you cannot have training,' be it for general education or for a specific TAFE based training course, then we are saying, `If you are disadvantaged you will remain disadvantaged because you will only get that education or that training if you can pay for it.' It seems to me that we must take a very strong stand on this issue and realise that if we are going to further the wine industry for Victoria's sake, for Australia's sake and for the whole community's sake, then we must be prepared to foot the bill as a community for further education and training that is required for that industry.

There are a couple of other angles that I want to cover that affect Victoria in particular. It is clear that the tax proposals in the Industry Commission report, particularly the Scales proposal, will hit growers of non-premium wine grapes harvest, yet two major Victorian grape producing regions, Sunraysia and Kerang-Swan Hill, produce a high proportion of non-premium wine grapes. What is passed off as a minor industry adjustment by Mr Scales could have a significant negative effect on those regions and the communities that live there. It is worth mentioning that one of those regions, Sunraysia, was belted recently with the damage done to its citrus industry by the recent tax changes on orange juice following the WTO bills that went through the Senate before Christmas.

There is no understanding in Mr Scales's concept that many towns in country Australia have their entire economies relying on one or two industries. Sunraysia is heavily dependent on both its citrus industry and its grape growers. To attack both of these industries in the space of a few months sends a pretty clear message to the people of Sunraysia about how much economic fundamentalists in Canberra care about them. It is a concept that we must resist.

Mr Scales's main argument seems to be that there is some substitution between beer and wine; therefore, they should be treated the same. That is not the point. The point is that the tax levy should be covering the cost to the community of alcoholism, health care, public disorder, car accidents, and so on. As pointed out by my colleague Senator Lees, no case is made that wine is responsible for anywhere near as much damage to the community as beer. Certainly, casual observation would suggest it does not.

Thankfully, the report that the Senate is debating this afternoon is not the end of the story. This is only a draft report. There are still several months of public hearings and consultations to go before the report is finalised and written submissions can still be put. I know that wine growers and people engaged in the viticulture industry have already been put to a fair amount of effort and expense in providing their submissions, but at least there is the consolation that we can continue with our efforts.

I would invite Victorian wine growers in particular to make their views known yet again to the inquiry. They should comment on any or all of the draft proposals that have been submitted so far, even on matters that have not been covered by the recommendations.The next round of public hearings starts in Melbourne on 26 April. I suggest that industry leaders bury Mr Scales's fundamentalist proposals under the weight of continued submissions. The Australian Democrats will certainly be there to put across the need for fairness and a real commitment to the future of the wine industry and the communities that depend on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least Senator Spindler, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, has made a more promising series of comments in relation to these proposals in the Industry Commission's draft report than did his colleague Senator Lees who, I was disappointed to hear—
—She's strong on the issue.

—Senator Spindler obviously did not listen to what Senator Lees said. At least Senator Spindler rejected outright Mr Scales's proposals and recommendations in this draft report, although he did say that some would argue that it is premature to comment on a draft report. However, he came to the conclusion that it was appropriate for us to make the point that these recommendations should be rejected because, given that it is a draft report, this is the very time that the public, and we as their representatives in this parliament, should be making known our stand against these particular proposals.

PARA.TAB: Earlier in the debate, it was disappointing to see that Senator Lees did not stand up at all for her home state of South Australia. In contrast to what Senator Spindler said, she said it was not an appropriate time for us to be publicly putting arguments against the draft report. As I said a moment ago, that is absolute nonsense. It seems that Senator Lees was trying to have two bob each way.

This is a draft report and, because of its very nature, this is the time when public comment ought to be made by people involved in the industry, by members of the public who have an interest in this industry and, most importantly, by us in this place who represent them in the parliament. I am disappointed that Senator Lees has not joined those of us in the Liberal and National parties today who are supporting strongly this motion put forward by my South Australian colleague Senator Ferguson.

I am glad that at least Senator Spindler, in contrast to Senator Lees, has rejected the Scales recommendations out of hand. Even Senator Spindler did not make any comment about the majority recommendations in that draft report. I would be very interested to know where Senator Spindler stands on those particular recommendations because we also oppose those proposals, as does the overwhelming majority of people involved in this very important industry. At least Senator Spindler came part way down the track towards supporting what we are about today. But in our view, as senators representing the Liberal and National parties and senators concerned about this really important industry, he really did not come the full way, as we would have liked, and reject absolutely all the aspects of this report that deal with changes to the tax structure for the wine industry.

Could I also comment on what Senator Spindler said about economic fundamentalists. He said that the changes being made in tax to the wine industry, and also to the citrus industry, have recently showed the citrus and grape growers in the Sunraysia what the economic fundamentalists in Canberra think of them. I put it to Senator Spindler that this has absolutely nothing to do with economic fundamentalism, whatever that might mean. In many respects, so-called economic fundamentalism has been made a straw man and blamed for all sorts of ills in this country over the last few years. This current proposal for tax increases, the earlier tax increases on the wine industry and, indeed, the tax increases on the citrus industry have nothing to do whatsoever with economic fundamentalism; they have everything to do with a rapacious government that needs more and more revenue to fund its extravagant spending programs because of its inability to bring discipline to its fiscal program. That is what this issue is about. It has nothing whatsoever to do with economic fundamentalism.

The importance of this issue was demonstrated today by the large number of people who have spoken and who are still to speak in this debate in support of the motion moved by my colleague Senator Ferguson about the proposed increase in the tax structure for wine. We are somewhat limited in the time available for debate, and I do not want to revisit a number of the issues that have been raised by my colleagues in this debate or that were discussed at length during the debate on the budget bills in October 1993. It is sad that we have to revisit these issues so soon. Having had a massive increase in tax in that 1993 budget, less than two years later we are revisiting a potential tax increase being imposed on this industry.

I will not canvass the issue of a comparison of like industries and the illogicality of comparing the wine industry with other alcoholic beverage manufacturers; nor will I deal in detail with the need to encourage a successful but nevertheless vulnerable industry because it provides significant employment in Australia and most importantly in regional areas rather than in the capital cities. This employment occurs not only at the agricultural coalface—the actual growing of grapes for the wine industry—but also in adjunctive manufacturing industries which produce labels, bottles, cartons, harvesting equipment and so on. It also generates employment in service industries ranging from the waterfront to restaurants. These are issues of great importance which have been dealt with to various degrees by others in this debate.

The main point I wish to make concerns the contribution the wine industry makes to the Australian economy through export sales. That contribution cannot be ignored given our dismal current account deficit and the consequent need for an urgent improvement in that regard. Month after month under this government we are racking up a further current account debt. That in turn increases our foreign debt year after year. The wine industry has a remarkable record in recent years with regard to lifting its export performance. Therefore, it needs every encouragement if we are going to do anything at all to overcome our current account deficit problem.

The government ought to remember that if we are simply going to stabilise our foreign debt at its current level, four per cent of our current domestic production has to earn export income. That is an enormous task which will not be achieved under the policies of this government but will certainly be achieved when there is a change of government. It is an enormous task, but one which the wine industry is making a successful contribution to. Even so, the wine industry is now targeted for a further tax increase which would destroy its capacity to make that contribution in the future.

The wine industry has had very little help from the government during its developmental stages. Last year was the first time an Australian wine company was granted a federal government loan—BRL Hardy was granted $3 billion. That was the biggest loan provided to an Australia company under the international trade enhancement scheme. I emphasis the point that that was the first time the wine industry had been helped in that regard.

This was certainly an extraordinary recognition of the contribution that the wine industry makes to Australian export earnings. Was this a turnaround in the government's attitude from its failure to have any appreciation of the impact of its intended 55 per cent increase in wholesale sales tax on wine in the 1993 budget? Apparently not. Yet again we face the menace of tax increases staring the industry in the face less than two years later. The government is true to its word. When the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, taunts us with tax rises, without any mandate whatsoever to do so, for once we can believe him and know that he means what he says.

As a wine producing country, Australia's effective wine taxes are the second highest in the world—more than 2 1/2 times greater than the average imposed in other wine producing countries and a staggering eight times higher than the tax of the lowest taxed wine producing country, Italy. It is worth bearing that fact in mind when we are considering this very important issue.

In 1993-94, Australia's wine exports hit a record 130,619 million litres which is worth almost $359 million in export earnings. The compound annual growth rate of wine exports to countries such as the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Sweden, the United States, Canada and Japan over the 10-year period from 1983-84 was 27.1 per cent. That is a remarkable performance from this industry. This strong international growth is attributed to the competitive productivity of Australia's wine industry when compared with traditional wine producing countries which do not have our advantages of relatively low land costs, mechanised harvesting and pruning equipment, and which are often restricted by traditional wine making methods.

We need to remember that this march on the market may be eroded as new entrants come into the industry. Chile, Bulgaria and South Africa are all expanding their wine grape production. Chilean nationals are currently being trained in viticulture in my home state of South Australia. While there are benefits to be gained for South Australia by being involved in such a training program, we need to remember the downside of that and the inherent risk which is the benefit it gives to Chile as a competitor.

Again, we must do everything possible to ensure that Australia retains its competitive advantages in this industry and not load it up with taxes, as it seems this government wants to do. The industry's key challenge is growth in the supply of premium grapes. The 1993 vintage was affected by disease and bad weather, which led to a supply shortage. This has to be appreciated in the context of competitive threats posed by a fruit surplus in traditional European wine making countries such as Italy, France, Spain and Portugal. Although the 1994 national grape crop was a record 715,000 tonnes, the inevitable impact of drought on the 1995 vintage cannot be ignored. Australia's international position in wine exporting is not assured without growth in supply. It is widely acknowledged that the next three years will be much more difficult than the previous three years of record export performance.

Industry expectations of the government's inquiry and the committee's report were for a better government understanding of the wine industry's vulnerabilities and strengths. It seems the industry was a little too optimistic. There are many wine grape growing regions throughout the country, all of which will feel the effects of an increase in wholesale sales tax on wine. In my home state of South Australia, the Riverland, the Barossa Valley, the Adelaide Hills, the Clare Valley, the Eden Valley, the Southern Vales regions and the Coonawarra depend on the wine industry for jobs and regional economic boosts generated by tourism to their vineyards. But this government seems intent on decimating the wine industry, which is essential to rural and regional economic viability.

I conclude with a comment I made during a speech I made the last time the government wanted to raise the wholesale tax on wine. I think it is worth repeating: it does not matter if you drink wine or not, the fact is that this tax will hurt, unjustifiably and in a regionally discriminatory way, ordinary and already tax burdened Australians who derive their income from that industry. In August 1993—it is good to see that he is in chamber at the moment—Senator Sherry came up with the astonishing comment that, for a couple paying $100 to dine out in a restaurant, an additional $1.50 to $2 retail price increase on a $20 bottle of wine is not such a significant proportion of the total cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not everyone is as rich as Senator Sherry.

—He can probably afford it. But this cynical statement by Senator Sherry misses the point by a mile. It is insulting and myopic, and confirms the inability of the government to see the wisdom of supporting, rather than inhibiting, our viable export industries. If we are going to continue to provide the opportunities for this industry to grow, we need a tax regime that has some long-term stability and consistency to ensure that there is certainty for investors. Investors must know they can invest, given that there is a long time frame involved in investment in this industry before returns are obtained. They need to be confident that the tax regime will remain stable so that they can make some long-term assessment of returns from their investment. If they do not have that, then we are not going to get the investment required to continue the expansion of this industry. So I strongly support Senator Ferguson's motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also support the motion that has been moved by Senator Ferguson, somebody who comes from a state that produces some very nice wines, some of them most probably nearly as good as the wines that come out of the Hunter Valley and district where I live. The first part of the motion sums up entirely the policy approach the Labor government has followed—a policy of increasing taxation on any industry which shows signs of being successful. One only needs to look at various rural enterprises to know that any time any industry looks like doing well, the monkey gets put firmly on the back of that industry by the Labor government. It is a fact of life. Recently I did a trip through the wine growing areas down around Griffith in the south of the state, and people were saying how hard it is to make a living there. They were fearful of this IC report, fearful of what the government is mooted to be going to do. They are not too happy about it.

PARA.TAB: Tax collection has become this government's most successful activity. It is just about the only thing that it does well. The federal Labor government is expert at tax collecting. This year it will collect in excess of $100 billion dollars in tax, and over its period in office it has fine-tuned this tax collecting activity. For example, in 1983-84, fuel tax raised about $2.1 billion for the federal coffers. This year it will bring in about $9.7 billion. Sales tax has jumped from about $4 billion to $11 billion. Income tax has gone from about $29 billion to $71 billion. All the people in the gallery tonight know how tax is affecting them.

TALK.START.PARA: —All of them!

—Yes. It is not the number of people in the gallery; it is the quality. They all know how this government has slugged them. They all pay their taxes and they know how they are being hit the whole time with extra taxes. Now you want to have a crack at the wine industry. You have had a sorry time in office. It has been hallmarked by your ability to extract tax from anything that is living. If it moves, you want to tax it. If it is growing in the field, you want to tax it. You want to tax it at every level. The way you are going, you most probably want to reintroduce death duties. Most probably, you want a death tax. It has been talked about in New South Wales by Mr Carr. You have talked about a carbon tax. You always want to tax.

PARA.TAB: The wine industry is currently enjoying a bright period of sunshine. Australian wines are booming on export markets. This year, export sales will be about $370 million—no small amount of money. The domestic industry is not doing quite so well but it is still a large rural industry generating sales of about $1.8 billion. We all enjoy wine. Last time we talked about wine, Senator Sherry was talking about how he enjoys one.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enjoyed a good one last Friday.

—Enjoy wine, but do not kick the industry in the groin every time it starts to get up off the ground and produce things. We should be proud of our wine industry because, for a start, it is a classic example of a value adding rural industry.
—What's that?

—Senator Burns knows all about it. We have got an inquiry into value adding at the moment. Here again, do not knock it. The wine industry is also a great tourist attraction. That point has been made by numerous colleagues here today. There is not one area in Australia that has heaps of grape vines growing that is not being used by the tourist industry. It is great for the region and great for the people who live there. As I said earlier, though, when it looks like prospering, the government gets right into it.

PARA.TAB: The industry is extremely well skilled. Australian winemakers are extremely well qualified. There is a high level of technical understanding amongst those people. In fact, a lot of our expertise has been exported to other parts of the world. We are world leaders in winemaking. Honourable senators should visit Charles Sturt University in Wagga Wagga, for example, and see what it is doing for the wine industry both in Australia and around the world. They should look at what all of those industries in my home state, between Cowra and Wagga, are doing. They do not want to be kicked in the teeth by an extra tax just when it looks as though they will add more to our export income.

Honourable senators will recall that it was the treatment of the wine industry in the 1993 budget that caused the budget to be delayed while acceptable arrangements were worked out with the wine industry on what was a feasible and affordable taxation regime. The government had wanted to raise sales tax on wines at that stage to 31 per cent, having given no warning to the industry and having provided no consultation.

The outcome of those discussions—and it must be remembered that if the government takes up these recommendations it will represent a backdown; Dawkins made some promises then and the government will probably break those promises that he made at the time—resulted in a phasing-in of increases in sales taxes, offset by the depreciation over four years of the costs of establishing vineyards. We all know how long it takes to get a vineyard operating. You have to prepare the soil and get the vines growing until they can start to produce grapes. A cash benefit for all commercial winemakers and increased financial assistance for the industry's wine exports were also put in at that stage.

The Industry Commission, in timely prebudget fashion, has published its draft report on the industry, and the government may use it as justification for its continuing practice of hitting an industry when it looks like getting prosperous. The three-man committee appointed to review the wine industry has concluded that the tax structure should be overhauled and replaced by a tax system that reflects the wine's alcohol content—a system similar to that for beer and spirits. The wine industry is a much different industry to beer and spirits. You have to grow the vines and actually harvest the crop.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the hops?

—If you really want the good wine that I know Senator Murphy likes to drink, you have to put it away and store it for a while so it matures. Then people really enjoy it. The wine industry is different to the beer industry. In the beer industry, the ingredients go from the paddock to the factory, with somebody else growing the barley for the malting purposes. Beer gets drunk pretty quickly, but wine is different. It has a much longer lead-up time, and it needs a different appreciation.

PARA.TAB: There is disagreement, however, amongst the committee members who wrote this IC report as to how such a tax regime should be structured. The chairman, Bill Scales, has proposed a sales tax increase from 24 to 31 per cent plus the introduction of an excise duty of $4 per litre of alcohol. The other two members of the committee supported the introduction of an excise duty but recommended that the sales tax be lowered to 10 per cent. That is a good idea. This, in effect, would be revenue neutral for the government. It is probably a safe bet to suggest that the government will not accept the revenue neutral line because, in its usual style, it will try to rip more tax out of the industry and the consumers—straight from the people's pockets.

The introduction of an excise duty is likely to increase the cost of fortified wines and also push sales of wine from cask to bottled. From a wine lover's point of view—and, as I said, Senator Murphy likes his wine, and so do I—and certainly from a winemaker's point of view, this latter outcome is probably a good thing. While we laud the success of the Australian wine industry and its export drive, many in the industry are suggesting already that the industry is not as buoyant as some would like to think. In fact, this has already been mentioned earlier today by Senator Minchin.

The Business Review Weekly suggests that the targeted $1 billion sales by the year 2000 has already been pared back to $750 million. In fact, the volume of wine exports for the first four months of the 1994-95 financial year is down 7.8 per cent compared to 1993, although the value is up by five per cent. Investors in the industry in recent years have reacted to this decline in sales volume, and the price of wine companies listed on the stock exchange has dropped. That is not good, either. We want good companies producing good wines in buoyant circumstances; we do not want companies hit by extra taxes.

The Business Review Weekly suggests that, for many smaller listed companies, the crunch is yet to come. The difficulty for the industry at both the large export level and the small boutique winery level is that the industry cannot afford dramatic changes in the tax regime that affects sales. As I said earlier, because there is such a lead-up time from planting to production, the wine industry has to be treated differently to other industries.

Vine growers were encouraged to expand and others were encouraged to invest in this country in order to meet the new export demand that has been some years in coming, but it is possible that the response has been too good. Recently, and I have mentioned this before, we have seen new competition from Chile, South Africa—which has just come on stream—and, would you believe it, our little friends across the Tasman, New Zealand. New Zealand is now producing wine and trying to get under our necks in other parts of the world.

If you look at it on a state basis—everyone on this side has an interest in our state industries, whether it be the wine industry or any other—you will see that Western Australia has had an increase in production of some 28 per cent; South Australia, about which Senator Teague is going to speak in a moment, has had an increase of 23 per cent; Victoria has had an increase of about 41 per cent; and New South Wales, which is the state I represent, has been a little more cautious and has only increased by about two per cent but there have been big increases before that stage. Establishment costs for the industry are around—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Tasmania—50 per cent in Tasmania last year?

—Just listen to this. Tasmania actually has some quite nice wines, not quite as good as New South Wales though. Minister, you can talk about Tasmania. I would have thought you would stand up in a moment and speak about Tasmania and stick up for your state. The establishment costs for the industry are around $10,000 an acre. There is a lead-up time of four years, as I have said. Once the grapes are harvested there is a further 12 or more months before the wine is ready for marketing.

PARA.TAB: The whole thrust of the industry's objections to the 1993 budget proposals was that it was not an industry that could respond quickly to any change in its cost structure. That inflexibility cannot and has not changed, but the federal government appears to be unwilling or unable to understand this. I think you have to listen, minister, because you have a voice in structuring what is going to happen in the budget; you are a part of it. If you are going to slug the industry in Tasmania or anywhere else in Australia with extra taxes, you will stand condemned for it.

Behind the figures that I quoted earlier about expansion of grape planting there is a great deal of investment. This investment has been good for Australia; it has been good for agriculture. It has increased the value of land in wine growing areas, provided alternative land use options for farmers and encouraged money from both Australia and offshore to be invested. If you are going to turn around and say, `Now we have got you in we will milk you for all we can'—or squeeze you, I suppose, if you are thinking about grapes—that investment money will simply go elsewhere, including offshore. It will go to Chile; it will go to New Zealand; it will go to South Africa and you will lose it here. Once you have lost it, it will be pretty hard to get the industry going again.

The Industry Commission has delivered a report that appears to sit nicely with the need of the federal government to find money to balance its budget. That is why we are speaking about it at this particular stage. We can see that it is going to be so easy for you to squeeze a bit more out of every little grape that goes through—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you doubting the Industry Commission's integrity?
—The Industry Commission's report largely ignores its own terms of reference and focuses solely on tax implications for the industry. The Industry Commission was supposed to focus—

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just listen to this; you might learn something for a change. Use your ears instead of your mouth. The Industry Commission was supposed to focus on the development potential of the industry, the identification of impediments to achievement of that growth and also the appropriate form and level of taxation. Clearly taxation was supposed to be subordinate to the industry's development objective. But there is little in the report about regional development implications of and for the industry—its enormous tourism potential. Basically this report is all about how to get more money for the government. That is the way you are looking at it.

PARA.TAB: Far from focusing on how to squeeze the last tax drop out of every grape, why doesn't the Industry Commission and the government ever focus on a vision for the future? When did we last hear of a vision for the future from your side of the chamber? When did we hear what you were going to do to secure the future of the wine industry so that people like Senator Ferguson would know that the industry in South Australia will have a long-term future? When has this government ever focused on saying that it was going to do something for the future of agriculture generally?

TALK.START.PARA: —Many times.

—No. You people push up interest rates. You stuffed everyone during the 1980s. You killed agriculture during the 1980s. There is no need to shake your head. You were getting your salary as a union representative or whatever it happened to be; you were doing all right. But I tell you what, people out there in agriculture were not doing too well and they are still not doing too well because they were hit with high interest rates and high taxes during the 1980s.

PARA.TAB: Australian agriculture is moving into the 21st century. It is time that government members used their ears and listened to the industry. It is quite right when it says that it will be taxed out of existence if Labor takes up the Industry Commission report. The government should take heed of that fact and make sure that this industry prospers. It should make sure that it will really do something for the future of our agricultural exports in Australia. If the government increases taxes on the wine industry, it will stand condemned forever not only by the wine drinkers and producers but by everyone else, because it will knock our export industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —The overwhelming conclusion of all senators who have spoken today on the important matter of the wine industry is that there should not be any increase in wine taxes. This government should take heed of the overwhelming view expressed in the Australian Senate, in response to this wine industry inquiry, that there be no increase in taxes on wine grapes or wine so that this flushing industry will be able to contribute to not only exports but also the prosperity which it is bringing to so many states, especially South Australia.

PARA.TAB: I am proud to be a Liberal South Australian senator. I am proud that my colleague Senator Ferguson has initiated this important debate. My colleague Senator Brownhill has just spoken on the wine industry in New South Wales, which is his home state. Senator Troeth has spoken about Victoria. Senator Reid, the Liberal coalition whip in the Senate, has spoken about the wine industry in the national capital, the ACT. We have referred rightly to the wine industry in Western Australia and Tasmania. Not one government senator has spoken on behalf of the rural communities that are dependent on the wine industry.

As a South Australian, I join with so many of my Liberal colleagues from South Australia. They have been the predominant participants in this debate, because South Australia produces the great majority of Australia's good wine. Those in the chamber who like a glass of red find that South Australia produces the great majority of quality red wine in Australia.

I speak on behalf of the South Australian rural communities in the Clare Valley, the Barossa, the Eden Valley, the Riverland and the Gawler districts. A small remnant of the very best wines is grown in the Adelaide plains. There is also the Southern Vales community, Langhorne Creek, Padthaway and Coonawarra. These are the premium wine producing areas of South Australia and, as I see it rather parochially, of Australia.

There are more than 3,500 grape growing establishments in Australia. The number of hectares put to vines has doubled in the last 20 years. This has been rightly included by Senator Ferguson in the preamble to his motion, which rejects increases in tax on the wine industry.
