If part of those taxes were added to the increased taxes that were put on the industry two years ago, we would see disastrous effects with regard to the families who are employed in this important area domestically. It would also have a totally counterproductive effect upon exports and the investments that are generating those exports in the most successful rural producing industry in Australia in the last several years.

It has been right for us to recognise in this debate that there is sunshine on the wine industry. There is a twinkle in the eye of wine producers. That twinkle will go if there is any increase in taxes. The sun will be blackened if there is any increase in wine taxes.

I note, as have a number of those who have contributed to this debate, that wine is not just any other drink. It takes seven years to produce a quality wine. In my view, it takes at least another seven years in the bottle for red wine to reach peak maturity for consumption.

Most other liquids that we consume are easily produced. However much the quality which comes with skill and professionalism in the production of beer or a whole range of citrus drinks, a whole range of milk drinks, or a whole range of mineral waters, there are important liquids that we all consume, to which I would add spirits, particularly some of the bottles of scotch, many of which, frankly, are imported to this country. A huge amount of skill, carefulness and centuries of tradition go into producing some of these bottles. But nothing that we drink has the same carefulness of production required of wine. We must be realistic and practical in understanding the unique product that is wine. We should look very carefully before we kill any goose that is laying golden eggs, before doing anything that jeopardises this important industry.

I mention these characteristics of wine because Australia is so well placed, given the qualities of our wine producing regions, to export wine to the whole of Asia—indeed, the whole of the world. We have had an enormous increase in wine exports to Europe, Asia and even the United States. I believe that our exports have only just begun that upward path. This glimmer in Australia's eye at the moment is caused by our wine exports increasing at a greater rate than any other product, primary or secondary. It is that observation which has led Mr Keating and the Labor government to say, `Let's tax them some more.' The message of the Senate today in this debate, overwhelmingly, is: do not kill the goose that lays the golden egg; make sure that we see that export growth increase in the same way that it has over the last few years.

I move on to make a direct point about investment. If the profitability of the last two years is recognised by all of us on any side of this debate, it ought to be also recognised that, if there are increasing profits from the wine industry, they are to repay and consolidate investments that have led to the doubling of wine grape production over the last 20 years, which is the consolidation that is needed at this stage in the development of the industry. If there is an increase in a wine tax, whether of the variety advocated by Mr Scales or the variety advocated by Brian Croser—the majority or minority report—it will jeopardise the consolidation of the investment base of this important industry.

Let me get close to home and say that in my first speech in this Senate some 17 years ago, I touched upon the plight of South Australian grape growers because of my own government's meddling with an increased tax on the wine industry. I see Senator Murphy warming to agree with me. I ask him to show the same criticism of any move by his own government that would in any way accept either of the recommendations of this wine industry inquiry. Like all governments, the Fraser government, back in 1978, was looking for more revenue. That is what is driving Mr Keating at the moment—more revenue. The Fraser government saw the possibility of increasing imposts on the wine industry—and the brandy tax was to go up.

I remember my first speech in the Senate, in which I said that 99 sheep were safe, but one was in danger of being lost. I referred to the wine grape growers of my state of South Australia—and I was right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you call that a mixed metaphor?

—It is, indeed. A man with your scriptural knowledge is right to observe that. But I sometimes use a mixed metaphor to make the point all the more dramatically and there was at that time one part of the Fraser government which was in danger of being lost. It turns out that the Fraser government was not deterred by this new, young—I think at the time the youngest senator in the chamber, and certainly the newest—senator saying, `You are wrong about the brandy tax.' It was imposed anyway. Guess what happened? Revenue over the next couple of years went down because brandy sales plummeted and the increase in the tax led to a disaster for government revenue—that means all consumers of government services—and it was a disaster for the grape growers because, as we know, in any harvest of grapes, the grapes that are not just right for a particular variety of wine production are made into straight alcohol and blended with caramel to make brandy. When the grape growers could not sell the grapes that were ready for this remaindering, they suffered extraordinarily in 1978 and 1979.

PARA.TAB: I put it as a warning to the government that if there is any increased impost on the wine industries there will be one hell of a reaction from the rural communities around Australia. This government will feel it in the ballot box in the election that is less than a year away. I put it to everyone in the Senate—we all know it to be true—that the next election will be won or lost principally in rural communities. To some extent, it will be won or lost in New South Wales.

In my state of South Australia there is a pivotal seat, a seat that is represented by Mr Gordon Bilney of the Labor Party: the seat of Kingston. It includes the Southern Vales, a very important wine growing area. I admire Mr Bilney's care to support the wine industry. The other day when I, along with other South Australia senators, was briefed by the Premier of South Australia, Dean Brown, he put to us the South Australian government's analysis of this wine industry inquiry. He announced clearly that the South Australia government was opposed to both the majority report and the minority report. The state was opposed to any increase in the wine tax because of its calculated impact upon South Australia; it would be to the detriment of our state. Mr Bilney put in a clear apology to that meeting and identified himself with the need for all of us to be briefed and to get the facts about the wine industry, not only in the seat of Kingston in the Southern Vales, but in every part of South Australia. I would say, generously as a South Australian, that that stands for New South Wales, Tasmania, Western Australia, the Australian Capital Territory and Victoria. There will be an organised reaction against any proposal that would increase tax on the wine industry. That will have its effect on the ballot box.

I again commend Senator Ferguson. I should say to members of the public who are listening to this debate about this important industry, the wine industry, that only twice a month in the Senate do we have what is termed an opportunity to contribute to general business. The priority of determining the topic for discussion in general business is much fought over. Today, in this one of two opportunities in the month, there was overwhelming support for Senator Ferguson's proposed motion. It is topical. It has been said by so many speakers that it is the right time for senators to put their views so quickly after we have been able to read the outcome of the wine industry inquiry and to make it abundantly clear to this government that we reject the tax proposals in that inquiry.

There are some 20 or 30 other very substantial and worthy recommendations in the report that ought to be supported for the improvement of the industry. I commend Brian Croser, Bill Scales and Professor Freebairn for including those positive, qualitative arrangements for the industry. The only issue that attracted attention in this debate in the Senate related to increase in tax.

Senator Ferguson has won the full support of the Senate in seeing this matter as the matter of priority for these two hours. I look forward to his summing up the contributions that have been made to the debate from the various states, from various points of view, all of which rightly reject any increase in taxes on the wine industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak in this debate tonight but Senator Chapman and Senator Teague have inspired me to stand and for a minute or two make some comments. I was fascinated by Senator Teague's description of the wine industries around Australia. However, I think Senator O'Chee would agree with me that there is one that he omitted. We do have a wine industry in Queensland around Warwick, Stanthorpe and Roma. It is a significant wine industry for those people involved. It would be good if next time when you are enumerating the extent of the industry you could include Queensland.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chapman, I am afraid, to a certain extent did misrepresent what Senator Lees said. For that reason, I think I should put some comments on the record. I do not think he really understood what she was saying. Senator Lees does have a very sophisticated and extensive knowledge of the wine industry. I realise that this is in contrast to the rather simplistic approach taken by Senator Chapman. I guess we can forgive him for that.

Senator Lees is very clearly on the record rejecting the imposition of any extra taxes on wine, but she did have a fairly sophisticated approach to the report which has been handed down. I think she would agree with Senator Teague that there are a number of other recommendations that really should be taken account of, some of which, I believe, probably are even worse than the imposition of tax and others which do have something to commend them.

It is on the public record, and I could produce the press releases which are available that show clearly the position that Senator Lees has taken publicly. One of the things that I think Senator Lees would want to underline in this debate is her concern that people will take the opportunity to make their concerns heard, particularly growers, producers and sellers. They all have a contribution to make to this debate. The point that I think she would want to make and underline in the debate is that we need to hear the contribution that each of these would make, particularly as they read the majority and the minority report, look at all the recommendations and take part in the debate. That is what we need. We need not only to listen to ourselves, as we do in this chamber at great length sometimes, but also to listen to those people who are most concerned because their lives and livelihoods are involved. Clearly—I have noticed her operating—Senator Lees has been lauded by the wine industry for her efforts on its behalf.

I note in closing that there is a clause in the motion in which Senator Ferguson has stated that the Australian Democrats have indicated that they favour tax increases over expenditure cuts as a means of deficit reduction. Our balance of cuts and revenue is very clearly on the record and it does not include an increase in wine tax. What we in this place would like to know is: what are the coalition's proposals? As we have seen in previous budgets, the only thing we really hear is, `Block, block, block.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Woodley left out Ballandean, Bungawarra and Stanthorpe. Being both a contributor to the income of those wine growing districts and a Queenslander, I should mention their names.

—in reply—In closing the debate I will be brief, but a couple of issues have been raised which I think need to be commented on, particularly in Senator Woodley's comments about what I think is a new interpretation of what Senator Lees actually said in the debate. In her comments in this debate Senator Lees did not make it clear that she opposed any increase in the tax on wine. As a matter of fact, I will read the transcript tomorrow very carefully. I am sure grape growers in South Australia will also read very carefully what Senator Lees had to say.

PARA.TAB: To my understanding, Senator Lees said that she opposed the minority report, which was the report of Mr Scales. That report proposed a far larger increase in the tax on wine than did the majority report, which I believe she said in her speech she had some sympathy for. That was the introduction of new tax, a tax by volume of alcohol, as well as a wholesale sales tax. If my recollections are clear—I did listen very carefully—I am quite sure Senator Lees has some sympathy for the majority report, the draft report of the inquiry, with regard to an increase in the tax on wine.

If that is the case, I am quite sure the grape growers of South Australia, whom Senator Woodley says Senator Lees has such sophisticated communications with, will be very disappointed to find out that she does in fact have some sympathy for the majority report of Mr Brian Croser and Professor Freebairn, which advocated a change in the taxation treatment of wine which would in effect be an increase in the taxation on wine.

The grape growers in the Riverland produce 33 per cent of Australia's grape production, of which only 25 per cent are premium grapes. The other 75 per cent is basically for the bulk market, which is where the new proposed taxation treatment in the recommendation of Mr Croser and Professor Freebairn will hit. It will hit the low priced, bulk producer far harder than it will the premium grape grower, which Mr Croser is himself with his Petaluma Wines. It will hit the bulk producer far harder than it will hit the producer of premium wines. I would like to know what Senator Lees's attitude is to that particular recommendation. As I said, I will read the transcript very carefully.

I wonder what the people in the irrigation areas of the River Murray in Victoria and the others would think—the bulk producers of wine. I wonder what they would say to the Democrats's position, which was reinforced by Senator Spindler. Senator Spindler said that he rejected outright the minority report of Mr Scales, which proposed massive increases. But he never said that he rejected the majority report of Mr Croser and Professor Freebairn, which in this motion we urge the government to reject.

The reason we are bringing this issue up today, the reason we want this discussed and brought out into the open and debated today, is that there are people involved in investment in the wine industry and who have invested in the past four years. Some of those investments were made on the premise of tax arrangements existing prior to the 1993 budget. Some of them rely heavily on export promotion and on remaining competitive in the export fields. When there is a long lead time, as there is with grapes—we are talking about seven years; I know it takes a lot less than that to actually drink a bottle of wine—I think it is important that we provide some certainty for those people who are prepared to invest in the future of Australia and in the future of Australia's wine industry.

In my own state of South Australia there have been literally thousands of hectares of new plantings of vines over the past couple of years. We must give those people some certainty that they are investing in an industry which is going to work under the same taxation treatment rules that it has over the past couple of years. We cannot do anything about the effect of international markets, droughts or the quality of the wine year by year, but we can put some certainty into the framework that would allow investment with some certainty.

As Senator Teague said, we would like to know where government senators stand on the issue of an increase in taxation on wine. Not one government senator spoke on this motion. Not one government senator indicated whether they would oppose a taxation increase on wine. Not one government senator got up and said that they supported this industry, which is the one bright light in the rural economy, the one industry that has got off its backside and done the promotional work and got into the export trade.

We are talking about an export trade by the year 2000 potentially worth $1 billion. When we think about our current account deficit, $1 billion in exports is absolutely essential to economic recovery and to doing something to reverse the balance of payments trend that we have seen over the past few years. I would like to think that at least one government senator could have got up and supported the wine industry and said, `We believe that the wine industry is an industry that on its own behalf has managed to drag itself out of the difficulties it was in in the 1980s, and we will make sure that we leave in place the existing framework of taxation treatment which allows them to plan with certainty and to invest with certainty.'

If just one government senator had got up and said, `We support the wine industry and we will do our utmost to make sure that the framework that is in place will remain so there is certainty for investors,' those in the wine industry, particularly the grape growers, would be very relieved to know there was someone on the government side who supported them in their endeavours.

There is no need for me to go over any of the other remarks that have been made by my colleagues. They have all been generous in their support of this motion, recognising its intent: to highlight the recommendations in the report; to make sure it is in the public arena; and to let the people who are writing the final report know the feelings of people with knowledge of the wine industry and of the impact that an increase in taxes would have on the future of grape growers and of the industry in general. I urge all senators to support this motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Crowley) agreed to:
That general business be not further proceeded with this day.
Debate resumed from 22 March, on motion by Senator Teague:
That the Senate endorse the finding contained in paragraph 10 of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this report because it does concern me directly, and I think it is appropriate for me to give a response to the report. I need to point out that the reference to the Privileges Committee was made not by me but by a couple of Liberal Party senators. I do not want to question their motivation but I suspect that they had some thought of embarrassing me over the issue. The reference was:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether Senator Woodley was threatened in relation to the Port Hinchinbrook development in the manner referred to by him in debate in the Senate on 21 September 1994, and, if so, whether any contempt was committed.

As I read the reference, and the way in which the Privileges Committee has interpreted this, I understand that the matter of the threat was in relation to me and the matter of contempt was in relation to developer Mr Keith Williams. The committee was convinced apparently by both the submission and the documentation which I gave to it that in fact Mr Williams had threatened me. I will read some of the relevant parts of the report:

As the documents tabled with this report indicate, it is clear that Mr Williams sought to protect his own interests vigorously and outspokenly. The aggressive way in which he prosecuted his campaigns understandably gives rise to a perception that such behaviour is threatening.
I will leave a little bit out and come back to it:

All Senators and Members of Parliament receive threats of this nature and regard them, in Senator Woodley's words, as "part of the risk of public life". The Committee believes that Senator Woodley was threatened by Mr Williams in this sense.

Whether or not there was some motivation in the reference to embarrass me, the Privileges Committee certainly agreed that I was threatened. So that dispenses with that. Although the committee upheld my submission, it is interesting that the Liberal senators failed in their attempt to have Mr Williams cited for contempt. The report reads:

However, the Committee does not regard the actions in this case as having had the effect or tendency of substantially obstructing a senator in the performance of his duties . . . but observes that he was not in fact deterred, nor was he obstructed, by these threats. In this context, the Committee notes that it was not Senator Woodley who raised the threats as a matter of privilege, which he might have chosen to do if he had felt himself deterred or obstructed in the performance of his duty as a Senator.
The report concludes:
The Committee has not found that a contempt was committed in respect of the matter referred.

Whatever the motivation of referring this matter was, it certainly vindicated the comments I made in the Senate which were the subject of the reference, but it failed to bring the conclusion which those who referred it were seeking—to cite Mr Williams for contempt.

PARA.TAB: I have a mild criticism of the decision of the Privileges Committee. I am a little curious about the reason given as to why Mr Williams should not be cited for contempt. The reason seems to be that Mr Williams was not in contempt of the Senate because I refused to be deterred from doing my job. If I had said that I was inhibited by him and was unable to do my job, the committee may have come to a different decision. But I certainly did not feel that I needed to be threatened by Mr Williams to the extent that it would stop me from doing what I believed I ought to do. However, it is an interesting question for the committee to contemplate.

I now turn to the report and indicate to the Senate that there were three main issues that I raised in my submission which resulted from the reference and the context in which the reference was made. The first relates to the style Mr Williams uses when he responds to criticisms of things that he does. I cited a number of documents that go back some years. One was a threat that was made on Mr Doug Jennings, a National Party MLA. Unfortunately, he has died since this exchange took place.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was a fine man, Doug Jennings.

—He was remarkable MLA. I have no equivocation in saying that he really was afraid of no-one. He was threatened by Mr Williams. I cited the letter of apology from Mr Williams which was tabled in the Queensland parliament in 1982. Mr Williams had apparently told Mr Jennings that he would punch him right between the eyes. He also said, `You're a prize germ and I warn you I have my way of dealing with germs.' This is the style of the gentleman we are dealing with. To say the least, he is a very colourful person.

PARA.TAB: I cited a number of other documents that supported my reference to the style Mr Williams uses when he approaches these matters. I cited a facsimile of last year from the Office of the Coordinator General of the Queensland government. That office seems to be afraid of what Mr Williams might do. The fax states:

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier today I had a telephone conversation with Mr Williams in which he told me he was about to instruct his solicitors to proceed against various ministers and senior executive officers of the state. This shows you the extreme pressure we are under.

Again we can see the rather aggressive style this gentleman uses when conducting his business. Another part of my submission dealt with the threats that Mr Williams made against other people such as Mr Bissmire and Mr Whitehead. The one that distresses me most is his legal action against an aged pensioner from Cardwell, Mrs Margaret Thorsborne. She is a wonderful lady. She is an inspiring person and a great Australian. She was named Cardwell citizen of the year and has received numerous awards. The Thorsborne Trail on Hinchinbrook Island is named after her and her husband. I could go on and on. Mr Williams has taken it upon himself to take her to court in relation to, what in my mind, is a very trivial matter.

PARA.TAB: I am more concerned about the threats on people like Mrs Thorsborne than the threats on me because I believe they are very unfair. I detailed the threats against me and gave details of two telephone conversations and produced a number of press releases which again are fairly colourful. On one occasion Mr Williams said:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Woodley is smart enough to shield his errors behind parliamentary privilege and has already refused my challenge to make his statements in open forum and then face the consequences.

I inform the Senate that I made the statements to which Mr Williams refers on the ABC. Although I simply repeated matters that I had raised in the Senate, the ABC apparently was not quite game to broadcast the particular interview. The Senate needs to know that we are dealing with a very interesting and colourful person and someone who at times is a little more aggressive than he needs to be.

PARA.TAB: I close with some quotes from a recent address that Mr Williams gave to the Rotary Club of Innisfail. It is recorded in much detail in the Innisfail paper. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Keith Williams is an achiever. He is one of the great characters of Queensland. He left school and established himself, I think repairing motor cycles. He went on from there developing the Surfers Paradise raceway. He developed waterskiing as a competitive sport in Queensland, and was one of the major developers of Surfers Paradise. He then went on to develop Hamilton Island. He is now developing Port Hinchinbrook. He is one of the great characters of Queensland. He is one of the great developers of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: Keith Williams has provided more employment than Senator Woodley ever will in his lifetime. He provided employment in all these enterprises, all of which are still going. He did not do that by sitting on his backside or by being a milksop and he did not do that by lying down and letting people walk over him. He did it by getting out and doing things. He got finances and went forward. He is a bit of a bulldozer in his own way, but he is the sort of character we need in this country to get us out of this million unemployed. The million unemployed will not get employed unless we get people like Keith Williams to come forward and create employment for them.

He is a robust character. He is colourful. I wish that there were more like him because he is the sort of person we need in Australia today to go out and get opportunities going, to get developments going and get people employed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, as you are the deputy chairperson of the Senate Committee of Privileges, you are very aware of the way our committee has deliberated over this matter. In introducing the findings of our committee report as chairman, I moved that the Senate endorse the findings of the committee. It is fully appropriate that Senator Woodley has spoken. I have listened carefully to all that he has said about the matter of any person in Australia, whether they are rich or poor, whether they are greatly achieving or not, and I fully accept from my good colleague Senator Herron that Mr Williams has been a great achiever in Queensland. That does not come into the issue of matters that are in the principles directly needing to be upheld by the Senate through the Senate Privileges Committee's considerations.

PARA.TAB: In this case, a senator other than Senator Woodley, noting his speech at the time that referred to the confrontation between himself and this developer, heard the nature of the threat that was being made. We had to therefore consider whether that threat was of such a nature that it would lead to the Senate finding that the person making the threat was in contempt.

I have already outlined our findings. That is all set out in the report so I will not repeat it, but it may be useful to clarify one matter raised in Senator Woodley's speech. He acknowledged very much what we had observed in his submission—that he was not deterred by the aggressive, even hectoring, way that Mr Williams was in confrontation with him. Senator Woodley raised the question,`I guess if I had said that I had been inhibited perhaps a finding of contempt would have followed.' It is just that leftover area that was still in doubt in Senator Woodley's mind that I wish to address.

It is my view, as Chairman of the Privileges Committee, that when we would bring a recommendation about such a matter to the Senate, we would need to establish: was a threat actually made? Was it a threat of such a nature that it obstructed a senator from his or her course of duty? More than that, there is a third question: was the threat that deterred or inhibited the senator from prosecuting a matter that was being followed by that senator substantial, credible and almost to the point of being unlawfully inhibiting of the senator?

We would not wish to make it automatic that if a senator is deterred from some action by a threat that any citizen makes, therefore, because the senator admits he or she was inhibited or deterred, the finding of contempt would flow to the person who made the threat. No; we are not in the business, and Senator Woodley is certainly not in the business, of protecting what we would call uncourageous or weak-kneed behaviour on the part of any senator. It would also be just too easy for us, when we receive threats virtually on a daily basis, to entrap a person who would be threatening us if that were automatic.

No; we have to ask the third question: was the threat which the senator admits inhibited him or her of such a nature, to such an extent, even of an unlawful kind, that a recommendation ought to be made that that person was in contempt of the Senate? There is not anything automatic.

I think in this case it was all the clearer because Senator Woodley was not deterred. I would wish, as one senator, to commend Senator Woodley and, indeed, the great majority of senators who go about their work and follow up their conscientious views. They are part of public debate and public life in this country; they may be threatened every day but they are not deterred from going on with their conscientiously held views.

It is a wonderful thing in this chamber that we all recognise that we all have a right to be here. We were all elected to be here. We all have different views but we are to be protected by the mechanisms of the Senate in holding our views conscientiously and we should not be inhibited from following them through. Whether we are Labor senators, Democrat senators, Liberal or National Party senators, we will not make decisions in these matters that are in any way related to the particularity of the debate or the particularity of the views being expressed.

We wish to make sure it is understood in Australia that if any person threatens a senator in such a way that it is not only deterring that senator from what he or she would ordinarily do but which, almost by its own nature, is an unlawful action, they will not just be subject to the criminal law in a particular state but they may well be subject to a finding of contempt of the Senate. I hope that the Senate will now adopt the motion that I moved previously.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Teague for that clarification.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Canberra By-election: New South Wales Election

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty years ago as a teenager in grade 12 I witnessed the overwhelming humiliation of the ALP in the electorate of Bass in a by-election which was so ably won by Kevin Newman, the husband of Senator Jocelyn Newman. That huge by-election result for the Liberal Party was the beginning of the end for the then Labor government. Similarly, this coming Saturday the electors of Canberra have a unique opportunity to continue the momentum of the polls by sending a clear and direct message to this tired Labor government, so tired in fact that the bleeding heart letter from Dr Carmen Lawrence sent to Canberra women was a pathetic replica of a letter used by her in another campaign in South Australia. That is how genuine Dr Lawrence and Labor are to the women voters of Canberra.

PARA.TAB: In this letter, Dr Lawrence led with her chin. The opening sentence stated, `Things still need to change for women.' What a true statement. After 12 years of Labor things definitely need to change for women and the best change would be a vote for Brendan Smyth who would be a further voice for choice for the women in Canberra in the incoming Howard government. Under Labor, women have no choice. They cannot find work if they want it and if they don't want to work they have to to help pay off the mortgages with the high interest rates resulting from Labor's economic mismanagement.

What issue is closer to the hearts of women than health? Labor's record is a record hospital waiting list of 4,400 Canberrans under the past Labor administration of the Australian Capital Territory and, whilst that waiting list grew and grew to 4,400, who was advising the then ACT Minister for Health? None other than the Labor candidate for Canberra. You would have to wonder what the Labor candidate would do to the waiting lists of the public hospitals all around Australia if she got the chance to come into this parliament and provide advice to Dr Lawrence.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're desperate, Senator.
—It is interesting that Senator Crowley would seek to give such support to such a dismal record on health, which is an issue of such fundamental importance to women.

PARA.TAB: The Labor candidate was also a member of the national executive of the Australian Labor Party, which of course was involved in the Centenary House scandal. The Labor candidate hypocritically sent out brochures on glossy, chemically treated paper made from woodchips but she says, and it is in here, she would be against woodchippers destroying our native forests. From that, one is led to assume that the paper used for her brochure was not made from Australian woodchips but from woodchips and paper imported from overseas from countries that do not have the sorts of forest practice codes that we have in this country.

So it is no wonder that, when asked today about the Labor candidate for Canberra, the Prime Minister was so eager and keen to distance himself from her comments on woodchipping. The Labor election woes do not stop there, because this coming weekend the electors of New South Wales will also have a choice. An independent candidate, Mr Jim McKenzie, is running in the New South Wales elections. He stands for certain policies, such as bringing back the death penalty and stopping all immigration now.

Guess to whom he is giving his preferences. They are going to none other than the Australian Labor Party. Those who want to bring in the death penalty and stop—not even lower—all immigration now in that electorate would vote first for Jim McKenzie and then the Labor Party, because they will apparently deliver. One has to ask on what basis Mr McKenzie would make such a statement and suggest that the Australian Labor Party would be supportive of his policies. A little research shows that the current leader of the Labor Party in this parliament has this view on migrants. I will read it:
The Government—

SPEECH.PARA: this was at the time the Liberals were still in office; we will soon return to government—
. . . hopes to be able to offset the present population situation by immigration. It is time we considered the enormous cost of bringing migrants to this country.
He then went on to make this shameful statement:
After all, the best migrant is the infant Australian.
They are the words of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, as reported in Hansard on 17 March 1970. They were his views of migrants.

PARA.TAB: Is it not interesting that, as I was reading that out, the Labor senators opposite went deathly quiet. So they should have. They ought to hang their heads in shame. They have been trying to convince the electors of Australia, including New South Wales, that they are the ones to look after the immigrants. They have said for some reason that the deferral of the Racial Hatred Bill was because we did not want to discuss the matter before the New South Wales election.

I say to the Labor Party that I am willing to discuss our immigration policy on any day of the week at any time. Each time I will quote the comment of the honourable member for Blaxland that, after all, the best migrant is the infant Australian. How does Senator McKiernan, who is from the government side, feel about that term `an immigrant to this country'? How should I feel about it, as an immigrant to this country? How should the hundreds of thousands of immigrants in New South Wales feel about those comments?

They are shameful and hurtful comments and they reflect on a person that the Prime Minister embraces. The Prime Minister moved to have him reintroduced into the Labor Party. Indeed, he is a former Labor premier of New South Wales whose anti-Semitic views and white Australia policy are well known. Yet the Prime Minister of this country embraced him as an idol. It becomes absolutely clear why Jim McKenzie, with these outrageous policies, such as stopping all immigration now, would give his preferences to the ALP. That policy is in the hearts and minds of people like former Premier of New South Wales Jack Lang and his underling, the Prime Minister of Australia. That is what the Prime Minister said. Now that the Prime Minister has achieved high office, he makes all the right sounding speeches.

But we then have the migration legislation. The comments of Senator McKiernan and others in this place show that they have no regard for migrants in this country. All they are interested in from time to time is funding a few groups and bodies, as the former member for Canberra did so shamefully in the sports rorts affair. It all comes back to why we are having a by-election in Canberra. Mrs Kelly was forced from the ministry because of her shameful activity on sports rorts. She then resigned from the parliament, as she should have done at the very beginning.

It gives me no joy to have to reflect on the Prime Minister of this country in this way but the truth needs to be spoken about his attitude to migrants. Let me simply repeat what he said: `After all, the best migrant is the infant Australian.' Every single migrant in the electorate of Canberra and in New South Wales ought to keep that in mind when they cast their vote on Saturday, 25 March because, if they want to look after themselves, they cannot vote for a Labor Party with such an outrageous leader who has made such outrageous statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously this is the third silly season of the year—there is always the Christmas lead-up, the budget lead-up and the election lead-up. I had not intended referring to the Camden candidates but, seeing it has been brought up by Senator Abetz, I will: I would like the Liberals to tell us what they know about Ann Light. I am told that might be an interesting disclosure if they cared to make it.

PARA.TAB: If you looked at all of the tickets lodged for the election on Saturday, you would find that people tend to order the ballot papers to make it easier for voters to fill them in. It is quite obvious that in any electorate the Australian Labor Party will be running one or two. Presumably, the Liberal Party is running its ticket down, six, five, four, three, or whatever; but we have run our ticket up and then come back down.

The order of the ballot means absolutely nothing as to where our preferences are going because our preferences are going nowhere, they are staying with us. The concern is about how those parties will order their how-to-vote cards.

PARA.TAB: I would like to now go on to some of the things I wanted to say in the MPI debate today relating to a number of the issues that are current and important in this issue. I would draw the attention of honourable senators to page six of the Australian and the headline, `Libs admit Treasury didn't add up promises'.

The Liberals have spent days wandering around saying, `Treasury has added up the promises and they cost $14 billion.' The article states that Treasury was not given all the information. That seems to me to be an untruth that they have been peddling and perpetuating.

TALK.START.PARA: —A whopper.

—Yes, and a porky and all those words that go close to being unparliamentary. That is one point that is very important to raise. The other one that I would draw senators' attention to appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday. It was a great interview with John Fahey entitled `John Fahey on full throttle'. The article talked about his plans for privatisation. He is not going to tell us what he plans to privatise but he has a government trading enterprise review unit, headed by the Minister Assisting the Premier, Virginia Chadwick. PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—It is the second time during the adjournment debate that there has been a point of order taken just to make a debating point. I will not allow the standing orders to be breached. I call Senator West.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am sorry those opposite are being so difficult for you. However, I really feel I must draw this article to the attention of senators and the listening public. It is important that people know that Mr Fahey has said there is a government enterprise review unit.

—Yes, he puts his foot in his mouth but he will not tell anybody what he is going to privatise; he will not tell us what hospitals he is going to privatise. PARA.TAB: Let me tell senators about some of the things that government has been promising in the election campaign. Let us examine two seats, the electorates of Bathurst and Coffs Harbour. Coffs Harbour is a marginal National Party seat. There is a good campaign being run there. Bathurst is a safe Labor seat. New hospitals are needed in Lithgow and Coffs Harbour. What happens? Coffs Harbour is a marginal National Party seat whereas Bathurst is a safe Labor seat. This is the sort of thing this government has been doing in New South Wales. It has the hide to say we have been underfunding it by $300 million; but it took $300 million out of the hospital budget. The Liberal government also will not tell us what are the waiting lists in New South Wales for the last six months. It has obliged by not telling us.

TALK.START.PARA: —They cannot count.

—They probably cannot get their shoes and socks off. I can tell from constituents who come through my door that even in provisional New South Wales there is a problem with hospital waiting lists. Last year a woman I know of was kept waiting two years at least for a knee and hip operation—orthopaedic surgery. I am sure it was because she had a psychiatric problem. PARA.TAB: The other issue that people need to be conscious of, as was mentioned earlier, is what Mr Fahey did as minister for industrial relations when he was in charge of the State Superannuation Board. DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Australian Labor Party: New South Wales Branch

TALK.START.PARA: —I will now proceed on the adjournment debate which I had prematurely entered into some minutes ago. Today the Labor Party scored some cheap shots in this chamber at the expense of former state MP, Mr Phillip Smiles—
—Cheap shots!
—Cheap shots!

—I am glad for those interjections. I enjoyed them. Those opposite will smile on the other side of their face in a minute. The cheap shots were scored over a few thousand dollars involving a problem with the tax office. Tomorrow, some anti-Liberal people who are supporting the Independent state MP for Manly, Dr P. Macdonald—and it would astound me if amongst those anti-Liberal people there would not be people from the Labor Party—will be dropping what is known as a bucket on the Liberal candidate for Manly at the last minute in the campaign for the state election, so denying Mr Oldfield the opportunity of an effective response.

PARA.TAB: It is for these reasons that I am intervening in this matter. If the purpose of the bucket job is to demonstrate that Dr Macdonald is a man of greater integrity than his opponents, then it simply will not work. The reason is that Dr Macdonald's own taxation record shows a lack of integrity that must be of major concern to his constituents in Manly. I have evidence which I now seek leave to table.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to the Senate for allowing me to table the evidence. It shows that Dr Macdonald understated his income by more than $100,000 over the few years leading up to his election to the State parliament before his tax was adjusted upwards in 1992 as a result of a tax audit. Dr Macdonald's tax, that had been avoided over all these years, was then of course significantly increased. The details of this are evident from the document I have just tabled. It is clear from that document that Dr Macdonald claimed that he had a taxable income in 1988 of $7,192. After being adjusted by the tax office after its audit, his taxable income rose to $47,816. In other words, he understated his income by $40,625. That is a considerable amount.

PARA.TAB: These are the taxes that go to providing the services for schools, hospitals and so on, that this member claims he is doing his best to bring to his area. In 1987 he said his taxable income was $4,850. The audit increased his tax by $28,595 so that it ended up at $33,445. Similar substantial adjustments, but not quite as large as that, occurred in previous years. For example, his tax in 1986, which he claimed to be $5,213, was adjusted up to $17,000. His 1985 tax of $5,200 was adjusted up to $19,600. In 1984 his $4,019 tax was adjusted up to $12,648. Over these six years he had claimed that he earned only $58,000 whereas the revised figure shows $160,000. In other words, he understated his income by something like $102,000.

One of the intriguing things about this is that this emerged from an audit of Dr Macdonald's income tax returns according to the tax office's letter of 26 February 1992. By the way, the tax office thanked Dr Macdonald for his time and cooperation during the conduct of the audit. There is no suggestion that Dr Macdonald tried to disrupt or impede the tax audit.

It is interesting that the adjustments were made in accordance with Dr Macdonald's advice dated 10 September 1991. I remind the Senate that Dr Macdonald got elected to the Legislative Assembly in New South Wales in March 1991. Either his conscience took six months to gestate or it was an interesting coincidence that he became notified of the fact that he had significantly understated his tax only after he became a member of parliament.

It does strike me as strange that this avoidance is, in relative terms, massive when compared with the few thousand dollars involved in the notorious Smiles affair that this Labor government seems to enjoy parading around the place as some kind of significant matter. I would hope that the Labor Party would show equal enthusiasm about the fact that Dr Macdonald not only had understated his income but also was then obliged to provide substantial additional tax.

It gives me no particular pleasure to do to Dr Macdonald what his supporters are seeking to do to a Liberal candidate. If the game is going to be played like this, so that at the last minute buckets are going to be dropped, then I think people who drop buckets—I acknowledge this for myself, too—have to face the risk of having buckets dropped on them. I acknowledge that and I have always been prepared to cop it in this place. I remind senators opposite that I copped buckets which certainly did not belong to me for two years after I first came into parliament. You will have to give a lot better interjections than you have managed so far.

This is certainly, I believe, not the way to fight the state election in New South Wales. I think it is most regrettable that Mr Oldfield is going to be subjected to a bucket job tomorrow, at the last minute. The only reason I am doing this, as I have said before, is to indicate to Dr Macdonald and his supporters that this is not the proper way to conduct an election campaign. If he wants to play it that way, he should know that he has some other hardball players down here.

I make one remark in conclusion, because I notice that Senator Neal is to speak after me. It relates to the accounts, if they exist, of the New South Wales Labor Party's building company, Labor Centenary House Pty Ltd. The normal auditor's qualification when a company's liabilities exceed its assets would be that the company can continue in business only with the support of its bankers; in this case, the Commonwealth Bank. I do not know whether any such qualification exists on this company's accounts because there appear to be no accounts.

If Senator Neal is going to get up and tell us that there are accounts and that they have been audited, I can then say to her: why on earth has the Australian Securities Commission not been so advised? The only advice the Securities Commission has received is that the accounts are not audited. I encourage her to explain, perhaps on behalf of her husband, how this curious situation came about.

I would also like to hear her tell us what penalties have been imposed by the Australian Securities Commission for breaches of ASC regulations involving the late lodgment of this company's accounts for 1991, 1992 and 1993, all of which were lodged on the same day in 1994. I would hope penalties have been imposed and, frankly, with this curious situation, I wonder about the prospect of prosecutions, because it seems to me that flouting the law would not be a matter entertained by the Australian Securities Commission.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Australian Labor Party: New South Wales Branch

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I am very pleased to have the opportunity tonight to refute some of the blatant untruths that have been peddled by Senator Baume. I must confess that I consider myself unfortunate to have entered the Senate at a time when we have a senator such as Senator Baume because, as he said earlier this evening, what goes around does come around.

PARA.TAB: I have seen that there are two types of senators. There are those who make a reasoned and worthwhile contribution. They have their points of views, which may be different from mine, but they work to the best of their ability. Their interests are the interests of the people of Australia. There are people like that on both sides. It is unfortunate that Senator Baume is not one of them.

I do not think I have ever heard Senator Baume say anything on any issue that does not require him making some kind of slanderous or derogatory remark about someone else, be they in this chamber or elsewhere. A person like that, who sees his role entirely limited to that sort of activity, should examine whether he is doing anything for the people of Australia, particularly the people of New South Wales.

I would like to comment briefly on the situation in Manly. I was not going to comment on that matter but, since Senator Baume has raised it, I will. I am not aware of the allegations that he has made about Peter Macdonald. It is unfortunate that he has breached Dr Macdonald's right to privacy by obtaining access to his tax returns. I am sure that he has used means that he considers proper but which the vast number of Australians would consider improper. I suggest that he could have raised these matters at an earlier time were it not for the fact that Peter Macdonald was instrumental in keeping the coalition government in power in New South Wales for so long. I will leave it to Senator Baume's own conscience to deal with that.

There was an ad today in the Manly Daily, purporting to come from the Labor Party—it did not come from the Labor Party—which said, `Message to Labor voters: if you are voting Labor in this election, vote No. 1 Brian Green, the Labor candidate, and do not distribute preferences.' Isn't that amazing. I wonder whom that came from. Very clearly, it came from coalition supporters. If you are going to talk about dirty tricks in Manly, you should look at that because it will be raised after the election and will probably have severe repercussions for the people involved.

I would like to deal with some of the untruths Senator Baume has stated over the last week. He has this affliction—he has to embroil himself in matters in a negative and unconstructive manner with scant regard for the truth in certain matters. I probably cannot deal with all of his untruths but I will deal with a few of them.

His first untruth is that Labor Centenary House has not lodged its annual returns. That is not true, as Senator Baume well knows. I saw him looking at those returns as he went down the stairs one day. The returns have been lodged and I am happy to table them tonight. The next return is not due until July 1995 and I suspect that even Senator Baume could work out that that date has not been reached yet.

I add here that in a debate on the adjournment earlier this week, Senator Baume stated some untruths about me peddling untruthful facts to the press gallery. He did that without giving me the courtesy of advising me that he was going to make some comments about me so that I could be in the chamber. Again, he made blatantly untrue statements.

The second untrue statement was that the 1993 annual return was not complete. If a company is an exempt proprietary company, as Labor Centenary House is, and it has appointed an auditor under the Companies Code, it is not required to provide the full accounts or the key financial information required of a non-exempt proprietary company.

The Labor Party does meet this criterion. It is an exempt proprietary company and has appointed James Farley Meyer and Co., as has been noted previously, as its auditors. Therefore, it is not required to provide any further financial information. Its annual return is complete, and I am happy to table advice from Ernst and Young, the accountants for the ALP, which substantiates the opinion that Centenary House is an exempt proprietary company.

The third untruth Senator Baume put forward earlier this week was that Labor Centenary House is technically bankrupt. That is not true. These are the facts: Labor Centenary House is not bankrupt, no creditor of Centenary House has taken action in this regard as petitioned, and there has been no agreement with its creditors. As all debts have fallen due, they have been paid in full.

The fourth untruth by Senator Baume is that the Commonwealth Bank `allowed the New South Wales Labor Party to expand its debts by $4 million or so to enable the party to massively out spend the Liberal Party on election advertising.' The truth is that the ALP's debts have not increased during the campaign, and nor will they. In fact, the ALP has no other debts to the Commonwealth Bank apart from a mortgage of under $6 million. The ALP in New South Wales is funding its election campaign from its cash flow—that is, from the money it collects during the campaign. The contribution it has received will in fact exceed its expenditure.

The fifth untruth was when Senator Baume claimed the ALP was not paying a commercial rate of interest on its loan. Maybe he should borrow my calculator because he has a major difficulty in working out exactly what the rate is. The ALP is paying a commercial rate of just under 10 per cent, negotiated at a set rate at some prior time. The debt owed by the ALP is a mortgage debt; it is not an overdraft, as Senator Baume continues to refer to it. It is at a commercial rate. In many cases, the rates being offered were substantially less but because the ALP is a political party—bearing in mind its circumstances—the rate was above the commercial rate when it was originally negotiated.

The sixth untruth was when Senator Baume claimed that the New South Wales Labor Party has made its mortgage payments in cash. I do not know what little fairy told Senator Baume this, it is completely untrue and I call upon him to tender any evidence he has. Every single payment made to the Commonwealth Bank for payment of the mortgage has been by cheque.

We are running an honest campaign that no doubt will bring us victory this weekend in New South Wales while the Liberals, as usual, are spending money on a big poll driven campaign. Once again, it will give them an ineffective result. They have been spending not only their own money in their usual useless and wanton fashion but also $36.7 million of taxpayers' money on government advertising.

Let us talk for a moment about the fact that the ALP has been very effective in its core business. That is, it has actually won a lot of seats. In the last federal election we ended up with a surplus of $350,000, and we only got 33 seats out of that. How many seats did the Liberal Party get in that election by going into debt? It obtained 11 seats.

It is also worth noting that the New South Wales Labor Party has not lost a seat—state or federal—for the last seven years. The Liberals, in contrast, have not managed to pick up one single Labor seat—either state or federal—in all that time. That is not a result of understaffing; in its head office, and in terms of officials, the Liberal Party has a staff of approximately 10 times that of the Labor Party. In fact, on one occasion when they restructured they sacked 70 people. We have only 10 in our office. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I note, Senator Neal, that you were willing to table a document. It cannot be tabled unless you seek leave of the Senate. Do you wish to do so?
—I seek leave to table the document.
