The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to reports that the British Defence Minister has assured the House of Lords that British manufactured weapons sold to Indonesia will not be used against the civilian population in Indonesia:
(1) Has the Australian Government sought similar assurances from the Indonesian Government in relation to sales of defence equipment to Indonesia.
(2) Have such assurances been given; if so, at what level of Government and in what form was the assurance received.
(3) Does the Australian Government monitor the use to which its defence equipment is put when sales are made to other countries.
(4) Does the Australian Government seek such assurances from other countries; if so, with what success.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (3) While the Australian Government has no specific mechanisms in place to monitor the end-use of defence exports, we are generally aware of political and other developments in other countries and these are taken into account when considering defence export proposals. If the Australian Government became aware of any inappropriate use of Australian-supplied equipment it would draw a foreign government's attention to that use.

(4) The Australian Government does not seek such assurances from other countries. In considering an application for the export of defence goods, cognisance is taken of the strategic, foreign policy and commercial circumstances prevailing at the time. The Government does not directly attempt to control or monitor how a bona fide customer uses material supplied under an Australian Government permit. Unacceptable use by a customer of Australian material previously supplied by Australia (or others) would be taken into account in considering any future applications for permission to export controlled goods to that customer.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 16 January 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the major tariff and non-tariff barriers to Australian manufacturing exports to the following countries which will not be phased out with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) agreements: (a) Cambodia; (b) People's Republic of China; (c) Taiwan; (d) Fiji; (e) Hong Kong; (f) India; (g) Indonesia; (h) Japan; (i) South Korea; (j) Malaysia; (k) New Zealand; (l) Papua New Guinea; (m) the Philippines; (n) Singapore; (o) Thailand; and (p) Vietnam.
(2) What negotiations are currently underway to remove these barriers.
(3) For those countries which are signatories to the GATT are there any expected problems in fulfilling their GATT obligations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Uruguay Round resulted in the biggest market access tariff reductions package ever achieved in GATT negotiations, being 30 times larger, in terms of trade covered, than outcomes achieved from previous negotiating rounds. In general, tariffs will be cut by between 35% and 60%. Tariffs will be reduced in five equal steps commencing on 1 January 1995. The reductions will be from 1986 base tariff rates.

On products of interest to Australia the average cut is around 50%. The average bound tariff facing all Australian exports of manufactured products will be less than 2%. Nearly 50% of all Australia's exports will enjoy duty free access to major markets. Less than 6% of Australia's manufactured exports will face a tariff higher than 15% when Uruguay Round commitments are fully implemented. Based on Industry Commission analysis, the long-term export gains will be about $3 billion a year for manufactured products.

An important result of the Uruguay Round on manufactured products is the commitment by participating countries to "bind" their tariffs. When a country commits itself to bind a tariff at a certain level, it cannot increase this tariff beyond that binding without negotiating compensation for affected trading partners. As a result of the Uruguay Round, developed countries will have tariff bindings at or close to 100% of tariff lines. Developing countries have more than trebled their tariff bindings from 22% to 72% of tariff lines.

Nevertheless, significant tariffs and other barriers remain in some markets. For example, most ASEAN members did not bind their passenger motor vehicle tariffs during Uruguay Round negotiations. Tariffs in this sector are high—up to 200%. Some non-ferrous metal tariffs in Asian countries remain higher than industry requested. When tariffs were bound, some were bound at high rates. For instance, Indonesia generally bound its tariffs at 40% in the areas it participated in. Further efforts will be necessary to deal with non-tariff barriers.

Additional security for negotiated reductions in trade barriers is provided for by GATT/World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules which ensure that countries do not use other trade measures to restore previous levels of protection. In the area of manufactures, these include revised rules on the use of anti-dumping and countervailing duties, of fees and other charges for customs services and the requirement to grant national treatment (nondiscriminatory treatment) to imported goods once they have entered the customs territory of the importing country.
The barriers to Australian manufactured exports detailed below have been compiled from discussions with industry and input from Australia's overseas posts.
Specific details on the tariff rates applied to Australian manufactured exports by the following economies are available from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.
Exporters have not identified any particular tariff or non-tariff barriers which are impairing market access for Australian manufactured goods to Cambodia.

In the context of China's application to accede to the GATT/WTO, Australia is negotiating bilaterally to reduce tariffs and, to the extent possible, eliminate non-tariff barriers. Industry has identified tariff and non-tariff barriers which are impairing market access to China for Australian manufactures of coal, some petrochemicals, zinc, information technology (IT) goods, telecommunications equipment and passenger motor vehicle parts.

In the context of Taiwan's application to accede to the GATT/WTO, Australia is seeking significantly improved access for a wide range of products where there are a range of tariff and non-tariff barriers, including aluminium, steel, passenger motor vehicles (PMVs) and parts.

No significant tariff or non-tariff barriers impairing market access to Fiji for Australian manufactured goods have been identified by exporters. The Government, however, continues to seek reductions in Fiji's bound tariff ceilings, which remain high. Average tariff levels in Fiji fell from 80% in 1987, to 22.5% in 1995 as a result of the unilateral trade liberalisation program begun in 1987.
No significant tariff or non-tariff barriers impairing market access to Hong Kong for Australian manufactured goods have been identified by exporters.

Industry has identified tariff barriers which are impairing market access to India for Australian manufactures of wool, leather, coal and scientific and medical equipment. Non-tariff barriers identified by industry which impair market access include State trading and licensing requirements on coal and coke, steel and some nonferrous metals.

Industry has identified tariff barriers which are impairing market access to Indonesia for Australian manufactures of petrochemical products, paper, carpets, nonferrous metals and PMVs and parts. Non-tariff barriers identified by industry which impair market access include licensing requirements for some steel products and PMVs and parts.

Industry has identified tariff barriers which are impairing market access to Japan for Australian manufactures of some products. Some nonferrous metal tariffs remain a concern. Despite the deletion of a number of non-tariff barriers, many at Australia's request, some remain on coal and coke, sheet glass, pharmaceuticals and medical equipment.

Industry has identified tariff barriers which are impairing market access to South Korea for Australian manufactures of some minerals and pharmaceuticals. Non-tariff barriers identified by industry which impair market access include licensing requirements for pharmaceuticals, some nonferrous metals and consumer electronics.

Industry has identified tariff barriers which are impairing market access to Malaysia for Australian manufactures of coal, leather, paper, carpets, aluminium and PMVs and parts. Non-tariff barriers identified by industry which impair market access include licensing requirements for pharmaceuticals, nonferrous metals and PMVs and parts.
Australian manufactured exports which meet Rules of Origin requirements under the Closer Economic Relations agreement enter New Zealand duty free. There are no non-tariff barrier issues outstanding.
Industry has identified tariff and non-tariff barriers which are impairing market access to Papua New Guinea for Australian manufactures of wool, cement, steel, nonferrous metals and PMVs and parts.

Industry has identified tariff barriers which are impairing market access in the Philippines for Australian manufactures of pharmaceuticals and nonferrous metals. Non-tariff barriers identified by industry which impair market access include licensing requirements for furniture.
There are no specific tariff or non-tariff barriers identified by exporters which are impairing market access in Singapore for Australian manufactured goods.

Industry has identified tariff barriers which are impairing market access to Thailand for Australian manufactures of aluminium, nonferrous metals, IT equipment and PMVs and parts. Non-tariff barriers identified by industry which impair market access include licensing requirements for PMVs and parts.

Industry has identified tariff barriers which are impairing market access to Vietnam for Australian manufactures of a wide range of consumer goods. Non-tariff barriers identified by industry which impair market access include non-automatic import licenses.
(2) The Government continues to use all available fora to pursue market access issues for Australian firms at multilateral, regional or bilateral levels.

GATT/WTO accession negotiations present Australia with the most important opportunity for continuing to pursue market access issues. The accession process includes a rigorous examination of an applicant's policies to determine modifications which would be required to make its foreign trade and industry policies conform with the WTO.

This process includes extensive bilateral market access negotiations with interested WTO members which seek to remove or reduce barriers to trade. Relevant parties in Australia are consulted during market access negotiations.

Australia's objective in WTO accession is to ensure that applicants agree to abide by the rules and to gain maximum binding commitments to market access liberalisation. Every effort is made to ensure that Australian market access concerns with applicants are addressed during the accession process.

APEC provides a second approach through which Australia can pursue trade liberalisation: 12 of the 16 countries in question are members of APEC. APEC leaders, meeting in Indonesia last year, agreed to implement free trade in the region by no later than 2020. We will be seeking to reach agreement this year on a process that will begin to implement that commitment.
A third approach includes Ministerial representations, formal bilateral forums, regular officials discussions and direct representations through Australian posts.

Australia has notified that it will participate in negotiations to ensure continued good market access for Australian manufactured exports when Cambodia commences its accession process to the WTO. Australian industry interests, where identified, will be fully reflected in our demands for access.

China is currently in the process of negotiating its accession to the GATT/WTO. In the context of China's application to accede to the GATT/WTO, Australia is negotiating bilaterally to reduce tariffs and, to the extent possible, eliminate non-tariff barriers. China sought to finalise negotiations on its accession to the GATT by the end of 1994, but was not able to make offers which were sufficient to enable the negotiations to be concluded. Australia is strongly supportive, in principle, of China's accession to the GATT/WTO and continues to play an active part in this process. While it is in the best interests of the world trading system that China does become a member of the GATT/WTO, China can only accede in a manner fully consistent with the rules of the GATT and the WTO.

Like other countries participating in the negotiations, Australia accepted that the proposed trade liberalisation commitments currently on offer from China are a step forward but are not sufficient to enable its accession to proceed. Australia is negotiating bilaterally with China to open the Chinese market in a way which provides practical new commercial opportunities for a wide range of Australian exports.

Taiwan is currently in the process of negotiating its accession to the GATT and the World Trade Organisation. Australia strongly supports Taiwan's accession to the GATT/WTO and continues to play an active part in this process. As a member, Taiwan will be required to abide by the multilateral trade rules thus securing maximum opening of Taiwan's market to Australian goods.

To date, Taiwan has placed on the negotiating table a wide range of trade reforms and market access offers which will be of considerable value to Australia's manufacturing industry when Taiwan does join the GATT/WTO.

Regular Ministerial contact allows Australia to discuss market access issues with Fiji. Australia has also used the Fiji/Australia Officials Bilateral Trade and Economic talks to pursue our market access objectives.
Any market access issues which might arise with Hong Kong are discussed at regular senior officials meetings.

The issue of India's high level of protection for its industrial sector has been raised in Ministerial meetings, including the Australia/India Joint Ministerial Commission. The Commission provides the opportunity to pursue market access issues as they arise.

Market access issues are raised in the Australian-Indonesia Ministerial Forum Working Group on Trade, Industry and Investment. They will next be raised during Senator McMullan's visit to Indonesia from 1-3 May 1995 for the Australia-Indonesia Business Council Conference.

In response to Japan's announcement of its proposed five-year deregulation action program, Australia has lodged a submission on regulatory issues relevant to Australian market access concerns. These cover, among others, food and agricultural products, government procurement and other market access and distribution issues.

The Government of Australia has also participated in Japanese Government processes addressing market access problems facing foreign enterprises (i.e. through the Office of the Trade Ombudsman Annual Review on Standards and Certification and the meetings of the Import Board).

Selected priority issues are raised, as appropriate, in multilateral (WTO/GATT) and regional (APEC) forums. They are also addressed at annual bilateral officials meetings and during ministerial visits.
Market access issues will be again raised at the next meeting of the Australia/Korea Joint Economic Committee.
Market access issues will be raised again during the April Australia/Malaysia Joint Trade Committee meeting.
Any market access and wider CER issues which arise are discussed at the annual Australia-New Zealand Trade Ministers' Talks.

Papua New Guinea became a Contracting Party to the GATT in December 1994. It has also accepted the WTO Agreement and when its market access schedules are finalised it will become a WTO member. Australia has presented a list to Papua New Guinea detailing our market access concerns. In this process Australia expects improved access and appropriate commitments on bound tariffs.
Market access issues were raised at the Australia/Philippines Joint Commission in April 1994.
Any market access issues which arise with Singapore are taken up through bilateral representations.
Market access issues will again be raised at the next meeting of the Australia/Thailand Joint Trade Commission scheduled for September this year.
In January 1995 Vietnam applied to join the WTO. No date has yet been set for the accession negotiation process to begin.

(3) The first round of cuts were implemented concurrently with the establishment of the WTO on 1 January 1995. As noted in the answer to question one, the cuts are from 1986 base tariff rates. Many countries, Australia and some ASEAN members included, have undertaken unilateral trade liberalisation programs which have current applied rates lower than their Uruguay Round negotiated end bound rates. For example, Thailand bound PMV tariffs at 80% down from a peak of 200%, but the current applied rate is at a peak of 68.5%. From 1 January this year, Thailand's bound tariff for PMV's is 175%, but this is meaningless as the current applied rates are well below this. What is important though, is that where applied rates are lower than bound rates, exporters know that the bound rate is the maximum countries can "increase" tariffs to without negotiating compensation.

Although the implementation appears to be progressing in accordance with the procedures agreed during the Uruguay Round, the Government, in conjunction with industry, must be vigilant to ensure that the outcomes promised by participants are delivered. At this stage, we know of no instance where a signatory will be unable to fulfil its obligations under the Uruguay Round agreement on industrial products.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 31 January 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) What progress has been made in response to requests from the NSW Government for the transfer of land at Holsworthy to be used as an Olympic facility for shooting sports; (b) when will the land be transferred; and (c) what will be the long-term future of Holsworthy after the Olympics.

(2) (a) Why is the Malabar Rifle Range no longer required for defence training; (b) why did the department take 20 years to bring the range to acceptable standards and, almost immediately after achieving this, declare that the Army, Navy and Air Force no longer needed the land for the training of personnel; (c) what will be the total cost to the Commonwealth of abandoning Malabar Rifle Range; (d) what will be the total cost of establishing Holsworthy as a rifle range; and (e) what contribution will be made by the Commonwealth.

(3) Has the Commonwealth given any consideration to private sector offers to improve the Malabar Rifle Range to meet standards for the Olympic Games and to accommodate Commonwealth Games and other shooting events.
(4) What will be the increase in training costs for the department when the Malabar Rifle Range is abandoned and Holsworthy is used, in particular to city-based personnel.
(5) Is the department actively seeking to discourage civilian shooting events; if so, why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a)&(b) The request for the land at Holsworthy was received in the context of the Sydney 2000 Olympic bid. The Commonwealth gave in principle agreement and negotiations are proceeding on terms and conditions. Current planning is for the transfer of the land to be completed by 30 June 1995.

(c) The NSW (Department of Sport Recreation and Racing) Government has advised that the Olympic Bid candidature file provides that the investment for the Games will provide a long term legacy for the sport. Accordingly, the NSW Government is seeking to acquire sufficient land to ensure that the long term needs of shooting sports can be accommodated on the site.

(2) (a) Closure of the Malabar Rifle Range was a Government decision made in the context of the 1987 Budget. It was considered the continued use of the Malabar for shooting was less appropriate than releasing the land for urban development. In addition, Defence needs were able to be met at existing military facilities at Holsworthy or elsewhere.

(b) The type of ranges constructed at Malabar do not require constant on going maintenance. Since 1970 only minimal Commonwealth funds have been expended on the ranges and these costs were associated with the maintenance of the site and ensuring the existing facilities were safe.

(c) As stated above, the Commonwealth, through the Department of Administrative Services proposes to release the Malabar Rifle Range for alternative urban land uses and does not intend abandoning the land. However, in 1988 the NSW Rifle Association Incorporated was successful in its application for an injunction preventing the Commonwealth from disposing of the land.

On 22 July 1994 the court issued a decision supporting the Government's proposal that the Association vacate Malabar Rifle Range. The Association has appealed this decision, and that is still to be heard in the courts.
The Government's future actions and associated costs are therefore contingent on the outcome of this appeal process.
(d) Establishment costs for the Holsworthy shooting complex are the responsibility of the NSW Government.
(e) The Department of Defence is not making any contribution and it is planned the land transfer will take place on a commercial basis.

(3) No. I am advised that the NSW Government undertook a thorough review of potential sites prior to the decision of the Sydney 2000 Olympic Bid Ltd to nominate Holsworthy as the preferred Olympic shooting site.

(4) There will be no increase in training costs. The Department of Defence has not used the Malabar facility since 1988 and is not intending to utilise the Holsworthy international shooting complex facilities as they are not designed for ADF training purposes. ADF training will continue to be undertaken on special-to-purpose facilities at Holsworthy and elsewhere.

(5) No, the Department of Defence is not seeking to discourage civilian shooting events and this is demonstrated by making available, for purchase, the 168 hectares of land at Holsworthy for the shooting complex.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 7 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: Did the Minister take any action in relation to a request from the former Chief Executive of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), Mr Roser, on 13 October 1994 for an Australian Federal Police investigation into suspicions of a `serious cover up' with CAA; if so, (a) when was it taken; (b) what was that action; (c) has any subsequent report, interim or final, been received in relation to any investigation of Mr Roser's concerns; and (d) will that report be made available to the Senate; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Transport received a request from the former Chief Executive Officer of the CAA, Mr Roser, on 13 October 1994 for an Australian Federal Police investigation. The purpose of the investigation was to examine the conduct of CAA staff associated with the operations of Seaview Airlines, the handling of official information, the relationships between CAA staff and this operation and any other matters of relevant concern.
(a) on 13 October 1994;
(b) the Minister for Transport on 13 October 1994 wrote to the Minister for Justice supporting the request and asking that the matter be referred to the Australian Federal Police as soon as possible;

(c) on 3 February 1995, the Australian Federal Police wrote to the CAA advising that the investigation has, to date, not revealed any criminal offences being committed by CAA staff. The Australian Federal Police report was provided to the Minister for Justice;
(d) This is a matter the Honourable Senator will need to address with the Minister for Justice.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 10 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) How much money has the Government paid Professor Peter Baume of the School of Community Medicine, University of NSW, for being the Deputy Chair of the Australian National Council on AIDS committee, since he left Federal Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 14 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to claims by the South Australian Minister of Primary Industries (Mr Groom) that the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) review `Cyclodiene Insecticide Use in Australia 1992' concluded that there was no medical basis for placing a ban on the use of organochlorine termiticides, is this claim correct; if so, why did the NHMRC recommend a ban on the use of cyclodienes, including forthwith in established buildings.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The National Health and Medical Research Council issued the report `Cyclodiene Insecticide Use in Australia' in November 1992.

The report refers to studies exploring health concerns and states `The conclusion from these studies is that the available epidemiological studies, although limited, do not indicate any adverse effects as a result of cyclodiene exposure.'
It is noted, however, that the report's Executive Summary includes the following statement:

`Overall, the cyclodiene termiticides are highly effective low-cost agents and with no currently recognisable adverse human health effects at the present levels of exposure. However, the compounds are environmentally widespread and persistent, and can lead to bioaccumulation in animal and human tissues. The possibilities of as yet unrecognised effects (including interaction with other chemicals) of these cyclodiene compounds and other environmental or ingested materials, remain unknown. It seems apparent that with time the unrestricted use of cyclodienes would cause unacceptable concentrations to be reached in the environment. It is therefore appropriate to reduce their use to the lowest practicable level to avoid this possibility. Suitable alternative and cost-effective chemical and/or physical methods of termite control could replace the use of cyclodienes altogether.'
The Report's recommendations section includes the following:

`The basis for the following recommendations are: (i) the potential for the cyclodienes to persist in and potentially damage the wide environment; and (ii) the possibility of as yet unrecognised adverse human health effects as a consequence of their bioaccumulation.

1. The NHMRC recommend to the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council (AAVCC) that the cyclodienes, aldrin and dieldrin should cease to be registered for all pesticide uses, when current stocks are exhausted. Further importation of these chemicals should not be permitted.
2. The NHMRC recommend to the AAVCC that chemicals of the same class (that is endrin, isobenzan) not be considered in the future for registration as pesticides.

3. Chlordane and heptachlor should be permitted to be imported and registered for use only as termiticides in the construction of housing and buildings and that this use be restricted to under slab usage and in crawl space under and around housing in accordance with the newly developed Standards Australia code.
4. The sale and use of chlordane and heptachlor should be confined to licensed pest control operators.
5. Registration for the use of chlordane and heptachlor in agriculture and other non-termiticidal applications should cease. This should be considered as a matter of priority for the AAVCC.'

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 27 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why is it that of the $31.8 million worth of funds appropriated in the 1993-94 Budget to the National Program for the Early Detection of Breast Cancer only $21.3 million was actually spent, despite the fact that women in remote Australian towns are still having difficulty gaining access to screening facilities and could have stood to have benefited from the spending of the remaining $10.5 million on breast cancer screening in their communities.
(2) What happened to the unspent $10.5 million.
(3) How much was spent on breast cancer research or related areas.
(4) With reference to the organised approach to cervical cancer screening, $8.6 million was appropriated and $6.5 million was actually spent, on what was the remaining $2.1 million spent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The source of the figures used by Senator Knowles is unclear. The 1993-94 Budget appropriation for the National Program for the Early Detection of Breast Cancer totalled $31.785 million and consisted of $3.45 million for national activities and $28.335 million for payments to the States.
Actual 1993-94 expenditure totalled $22.17 million and consisted of $0.995 million for national activities and $21.175 million for payments to the States.

The underspend of $9.615 million consisted of $7.720 million allocated to the States for screening but not spent, and $1.895 million for open biopsy not performed within the Program in 1993-94. This former amount reflects a shortfall in the number of women screened in the first phase of the Program, which was calculated over the full three years to June 1994 and only adjusted in the last year.

In their initial plans some States had been found to be overly ambitious in estimating their capacity to develop and deliver services. In their planning the States have made provision for rural screening services and when the Program is fully operational in 1996-97 all women in the target age group should have access to screening under the Program.

(2) Of the unspent $9.615 million, $2.45 million was subsequently used for a national recruitment strategy for the Program and the remainder was declared as savings and repaid to consolidated revenue.

(3) Research funds allocated by the NHMRC specifically to breast cancer in 1994 (the NHMRC operates on a calendar year) were $1.4 million. Much of the other research supported by NHMRC would relate to breast cancer to varying degrees (eg fundamental mechanisms of cancer) but it is not possible to give a dollar figure to the relationship between this more general research and breast cancer.
(4) The $2.1 million has been rolled-over into the 1994-95 financial year, but is still allocated for use under the organised approach for the prevention of cancer of the cervix.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) In 1996, is an air show by the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) planned for Western Australia to celebrate the 75th Anniversary of the RAAF.
(2) Are any other air shows planned for capital cities; if so, where.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. However, the major RAAF 75th Anniversary event for Western Australia is an Open Day to be held at RAAF Base Pearce on Sunday 12 May 1996. Static and flying displays of aircraft are planned.
(2) No. Only one major 75th Anniversary Air Show is planned and this will be held at RAAF Base Amberley on the weekend of 4 and 5 May 1996.
